It shall be unlawful for any person conducting or participating in any parade or meeting to address profane, indecent, abusive or threatening language or other fighting words to or at any person which would tend to provoke such person or others to a breach of the peace. 
(Code 1967, § 16-18) 
Sec. 11-21. - Picketing. 
(a)  Permitted; conditions. Peaceful picketing, including demonstrating, in the furtherance of a lawful purpose shall be permitted in the town, provided the picketing is done under the following conditions: 
(1)  Picketing shall be conducted only on the sidewalks or other town-owned area normally used or reserved for pedestrian movement, including easements and rights-of-way, and shall not be conducted on the portion of a street used primarily for vehicular traffic. 
(2)  Not more than ten (10) pickets promoting the same objective shall be permitted to use the sidewalks within one (1) block in the town at any one (1) time. 
(3)  Such pickets may carry written or printed placards or signs not exceeding two (2) feet in width and two (2) feet in height promoting the objective for which the picketing is done, provided the words used are not defamatory in nature or would not tend to produce violence. The staff on which such placard is carried shall not exceed forty (40) inches in length, must be made of wood, shall not exceed three-fourths inch in diameter at any point and must be blunt at each end. 
(4)  Pickets must march in single file and not abreast and may not march closer together than fifteen (15) feet, except in passing one another. 
(5)  If pickets promoting different objectives desire to use the same sidewalk for picketing and such use would result in the presence of more than ten (10) pickets thereon, the chief of police shall allot time to each group of pickets for the use of such sidewalk on an equitable basis, but each group shall be permitted to picket subject to the provisions of this section at least once every two (2) hours. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any picket to address profane, indecent, abusive or threatening language to or at any person which would tend to provoke such person or others to a breach of the peace. 
(b)  Interference with pickets. It shall be unlawful for any person to physically interfere with such pickets in the use of the sidewalk or to address profane, indecent, abusive or threatening language to or at such pickets which would tend to provoke such pickets or others to a breach of the peace. 
(c)  Authority of police. The police officers of the town may, for the assemblage of persons in such numbers as to tend to intimidate pickets pursuing their lawful objective through numbers alone or through use of inflammatory words, direct the dispersal of persons so assembled and may arrest any person who fails to absent himself from the place of such assemblage when so directed by the police. 
(d)  Maintenance of free passage. Whenever the free passage of any street or sidewalk in the town shall be obstructed by a crowd, the persons composing such crowd shall disperse or move on when so directed by a police officer as provided in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 16-22) 
State Law reference- Picketing with intent to obstruct justice, G.S. § 14-225.1. 
Sec. 11-22. - Unauthorized use of police or fire whistles, horns or sirens. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without special authority from the town manager, to carry or use any whistle, bell, horn or siren similar in appearance or sound to the whistles, horns or sirens used by the police department or fire department. 
(Code 1967, § 16-23) 
Sec. 11-23. - Disturbing school children or school functions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person at or near any school house or property within the town to engage by conversation or sign or otherwise attract the attention of any of the pupils therein or thereon, to the disturbance of the pupils and to the detriment of the discipline of such school, or otherwise loiter or cause any disturbance whatsoever on or near school property. It shall further be unlawful for any person to cause any disturbance or to disrupt any school function, sport or other gathering within the town, whether the same be on or off school property. 
(Code 1967, § 16-29) 
Sec. 11-24. - Spitting; deposit of cigar or cigarette stubs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate tobacco juice or other saliva from the mouth or put, place, throw or deposit any amber juice, chewed tobacco, cigar or cigarette stubs on any walls, floors, stairways, walks or halls in any public buildings or streets or sidewalks in the town. 
(Code 1967, § 16-30) 
Sec. 11-25. - Unlawful assembly. 
    It shall be unlawful for any two (2) or more persons within the town to assemble together for any unlawful purpose or, being assembled, to act in concert to do any unlawful act with force and violence against the property of the town or to the person or property of another or against the peace or to the terror of citizens or other persons or who shall make any movement or preparation therefor. No person shall knowingly suffer or permit any assemblage for the purpose of committing any unlawful act or breach of the peace or any riotous, offensive or disorderly conduct in or upon the premises owned by him or under his control within the town. 
(Code 1967, § 16-31) 
Sec. 11-26. - Cancellation of traffic citations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic citation in any manner. 
(Code 1967, § 26-47) 
Sec. 11-27. - Obstruction of drainage by railroad company. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to obstruct the drainage of the town in any way or by any means whatsoever. 
(Code 1967, § 22-9) 
Sec. 11-28. - Unnecessary whistle blowing of trains prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company or its employees operating or running a train through the town to blow or have blown the whistle of the engine of such train, except for the purpose of blowing for the board or semaphore as required by the rules of such railroad or in an emergency as additional warning of any impending danger to life or property. 
(Code 1967, § 22-11) 
Sec. 11-29. - Boarding, alighting from moving railroad cars. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not an employee of the railroad to get on or off a railroad passenger coach, freight car or engine while such car or engine is in motion. 
(Code 1967, § 22-12) 
Sec. 11-30. - Boarding standing railroad boxcars. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the railroad to climb upon any boxcar which may be standing upon any of the side tracks or switches located within the town. 
(Code 1967, § 22-13) 
Sec. 11-31. - Playing, loitering around railroad yards or side tracks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to play or loiter around the yards or side tracks of the railroad. 
(Code 1967, § 22-14) 
Sec. 11-32. - Use of parking lots. 
(a)  Definition. "Parking lot" means, for the purposes of this section, any area within the town of sufficient size to provide space on which more than five (5) automobiles may be parked and shall include public parking lots and those parking lots which are for the principal purpose of providing parking during business hours for shopping centers, stores, restaurants, drive-ins, theaters and other business or commercial establishments. 
(b)  Congregation prohibited. It shall be unlawful for more than five (5) people to congregate on any one (1) parking lot in the town between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., if the closest part of the parking lot is within three hundred (300) feet of a private residence, except for the purpose of patronizing a business establishment which is actually open for business between such hours and which is actually open at the time of such congregation. 
(c)  Enumeration of offenses. It shall be unlawful for any person on a parking lot in the town, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., to do one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  Talk in a loud or boisterous manner; 
(2)  Drink beer or any kind of alcoholic beverage; 
(3)  Throw any type of bottle, can, container, trash or paper on the parking lot; 
(4)  Use profanity or curse in such a manner that those standing in the immediate vicinity of the person may hear the profanity or cursing; 
(5)  Make such noise or disturbance that persons living in homes or other dwelling accommodations within three hundred (300) feet of the parking lot are disturbed in their place of living and deprived of their peace and quiet. 
(Code 1967, § 26-183) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate off-street parking lots, G.S. § 160A-302. 
Sec. 11-33. - Loitering for the purpose of engaging in drug-related activity. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, "public place" means any street, sidewalk, bridge, alley or alleyway, plaza, park, driveway, parking lot, or transportation facility, or the doorways and entranceways to any building which fronts on any of those places, or a motor vehicle in or on any of those places, or any property owned by the town. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, a "known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller" is a person who has, within the knowledge of the arresting officer, been convicted in any court within this state of any violation involving the use, possession or sale of any of the substances referred to in the North Carolina Controlled Substances Act, G.S. section 90-86 et seq., or has been convicted of any violation of any substantially similar laws of any political subdivision of this state or any other state or of federal law. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a person to remain or wander about in a public place in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose to engage in a violation of any subdivision of the North Carolina Controlled Substances Act, G.S. section 90-86 et seq. Such circumstances shall include: 
(1)  Repeatedly beckoning to, stopping, or attempting to stop passersby, or repeatedly attempting to engage passersby in conversation; or 
(2)  Repeatedly stopping or attempting to stop motor vehicles; or 
(3)  Repeatedly interfering with the free passage of other persons; or 
(4)  Such person is a known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller; or 
(5)  Such person behaves in such a manner as to raise a reasonable suspicion that he is about to engage in or is engaged in an unlawful drug-related activity; or 
(6)  Such person repeatedly passes to or receives from passersby whether on foot or in a vehicle, money or objects; or 
(7)  Such person takes flight upon the approach or appearance of a police officer; or 
(8)  Such person is at a location frequented by persons who use, possess, or sell drugs; or 
(9)  Any vehicle involved is registered to a known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller, or is known to be or has been involved in drug-related activities. 
(d)  Violation of any provision of this section shall be a misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with the provisions of section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 89-24, § 1, 10-9-89) 
Secs. 11-34-11-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MALT BEVERAGES AND UNFORTIFIED WINE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 2-7 of Ordinance No. 95-21, adopted November 13, 1995, did not specifically amend the Code; hence codification of such sections as §§ 11-61-11-66 was at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit the consumption and possession of malt beverages and unfortified wine, G.S. § 18B-300(c). 

Sec. 11-61. - Definitions. 
    In addition to the common meanings of words, the following definitions shall be applicable herein [this article]: 
    Malt beverage means beer, lager, malt liquor, ale, porter, and any other brewed or fermented beverage containing at least one-half (1/2) of one (1) percent, and not more than six (6) percent, alcohol by volume. 
    Open container means a container whose seal has been broken or a container other than the manufacturer's unopened original container. 
    Public street means any highway, road, street, avenue, boulevard, alley, bridge, or other way within and/or under the control of the town and open to public use, including the sidewalks of any such street. 
    Unfortified wine means wine that has an alcoholic content produced only by natural fermentation or by the addition of pure cane, beet, or dextrose sugar, and that has an alcoholic content of not more than seventeen (17) percent alcohol by volume. 
(Ord. No. 95-21, § 2, 11-13-95) 
State Law reference- Malt beverage defined, G.S. § 18B-101(9); unfortified wine defined, G.S. § 18B-101(15); open container defined, G.S. § 18B-300(c). 
Sec. 11-62. - Consumption on public streets and municipal property prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an occupant of a motor vehicle to consume malt beverages and/or unfortified wine on the public streets. Furthermore, it shall be unlawful for any person to consume malt beverages and/or unfortified wine on any property, whether located inside or outside the corporate limits, owned, occupied, or controlled by the town, including, but not limited to, public buildings and grounds appurtenant thereto, municipal parking lots, public parks, playgrounds, recreational areas, tennis courts, and other athletic fields. 
(Ord. No. 95-21, § 3, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 11-63. - Possession of open containers on public streets and municipal property prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an occupant of a motor vehicle to possess any open container of malt beverage and/or unfortified wine on the public streets. Furthermore, it shall be unlawful for any person to possess any open container of malt beverage and/or unfortified wine on any property, whether located inside or outside the corporate limits, owned, occupied, or controlled by the town, including public parks, playgrounds, recreational areas, tennis courts, and other athletic fields. 
(Ord. No. 95-21, § 4, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 11-64. - Possession during special events. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess malt beverages and/or unfortified wine on public streets, alleys or parking lots which are temporarily closed to regular traffic for special events, unless the governing body adopts a resolution making other provisions for the possession of malt beverages and/or unfortified wine at the special event. 
(Ord. No. 95-21, § 5, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 11-65. - Exemptions. 
    Possession and consumption of malt beverages and/or unfortified wine shall be permitted within buildings or premises on the town-owned property known as the Blount-Bridgers House and its premises bounded on the south by Bridgers Street, the east by the east prong of St. Andrew Street, the north by Philips Street, and the west by the western prong of St. Andrew Street and the Police Hut and its immediate premises located adjacent to the wastewater treatment plant and the police firing range where appropriate permits have been obtained, if any are required by law for the possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages for the period of time permitted thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 95-21, § 6, 11-13-95) 
Cross reference- Persons under the influence of intoxicating beverages or narcotics at Blount-Bridgers House and Pender Museum, § 2-213. 
Sec. 11-66. - Penalty. 
    Violation of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable in accordance with G.S. section 14-4. 
(Ord. No. 95-21, § 7, 11-13-95) 
Chapter 12 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Recreation Enabling Law, G.S. § 160A-350 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-1. - Department of recreation created; employment, compensation and duties of director. 
(a)  Subject to the general control and supervision of the town manager, there is hereby created the department of recreation and the position of recreation director. 
(b)  The director shall be employed by the town manager to serve at the pleasure of the town manager. The director shall be paid a salary to be determined by the town manager in accordance with the personnel manual, pay plan and budget of the town. 
(c)  The director shall have general supervision, direction and control, under the overall direction and supervision of the town manager, over all matters pertaining to all recreation and recreational areas and facilities such as but not limited to playgrounds, community centers, recreation buildings, swimming pools, lakes, tennis courts, ball fields, picnic areas of the town and school facilities rented and other facilities and grounds that might be rented or borrowed by the town for recreational activities wherever located. 
(d)  Subject to the approval of the town manager, the director is authorized to promulgate additional policies, rules and regulations that are consistent with and that further the provisions set forth within this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 17-31; Ord. No. 12-03, § 2, 5-14-12) 
Secs. 12-2-12-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOATS AND WATERWAYS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Boating and water safety, G.S. § 75A-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-26. - Operation of boats generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any boat, raft or canoe on the Tar River within or adjacent to the corporate limits of the town in a careless, reckless or wanton manner or at such a speed or in such a manner as to amount to a gross disregard for the rights and safety of persons and property. 
(Code 1967, § 17-2) 
Sec. 12-27. - Anchorage of boats restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tie, chain, anchor or otherwise fasten any boat, raft or canoe closer than thirty (30) feet on either side of the municipally owned concrete boat landing on Tar River. 
(Code 1967, § 17-1) 
Sec. 12-28. - Speed of boats near pumping station. 
    All boats operated on Tar River shall be operated at less than half speed from the river bridge to the pumping station, but in no event at a greater speed than five (5) miles per hour. 
(Code 1967, § 17-3) 
Sec. 12-29. - Discharge of firearms near boat landing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm either on the boat landing, the town property adjacent thereto or on the river adjacent thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 17-4) 
Secs. 12-30-12-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITIZENS ADVISORY RECREATION COMMITTEE 

Sec. 12-46. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the word "committee" means and refers to the citizens advisory recreation committee of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 17-15) 
Sec. 12-47. - Established. 
    A citizens advisory recreation committee, with the duties and responsibilities to assist in creating opportunities for citizen participation in recreation, is hereby established in and for the town. 
(Code 1967, § 17-16) 
Sec. 12-48. - Membership. 
(a)  The citizens advisory recreation committee shall consist of nine (9) members who shall represent, insofar as possible, a cross section of all elements of the community, particularly business, professional, civic, educational, public information and minority groups. Appointments shall be made to individuals who are deeply interested in and willing to work for improvement of the total community recreation programs. 
(b)  The town council shall appoint one (1) member of the committee from among the residents of each of the town's election wards from persons recommended by the town councilman from his ward, and one (1) member from among the residents of the town at large from persons recommended by the mayor. 
(Code 1967, § 17-17; Ord. No. 96-15, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 12-49. - Terms of office. 
    Members of the committee shall serve terms of two (2) years each. Members may be reappointed. 
(Code 1967, § 17-18; Ord. No. 96-15, § 2, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 12-50. - Compensation. 
    The citizens advisory recreation committee members shall serve without monetary compensation, but members may be reimbursed for travel and subsistence to professional recreation meetings, conferences and workshops, such reimbursements being made in compliance with the personnel manual of the town, when authorized in advance and when within budget appropriations. 
(Code 1967, § 17-19) 
Sec. 12-51. - Meetings; attendance. 
(a)  The meetings of the citizens advisory recreation committee shall be held at least three (3) times a year in January, April and November, but the chairman or, in his absence, the vice-chairman may call a special meeting of the committee at any time by giving each member twenty-four (24) hours' notice. 
(b)  Any member who misses more than three (3) consecutive meetings shall lose his status as a member of the committee and shall be replaced by the town council, pursuant to section 12-48. Absence due to sickness, death or other emergencies of like nature shall be recognized as approved absences and shall not affect the member's status on the committee, except that for a long illness or any other such cause for prolonged absence the member shall be replaced. 
(Code 1967, § 17-20) 
Sec. 12-52. - Officers; duties. 
(a)  There shall be a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary of the citizens advisory recreation committee. An annual election of the chairman and vice-chairman shall be held by the committee members and shall occur at the regular meeting in November. Officers shall serve for one (1) year from election with eligibility for reelection. If an officer's appointment to the committee is terminated, a replacement to his office shall be elected by the committee from its membership at its next regular or special meeting following the termination. 
(b)  The committee chairman or, in his absence, the vice-chairman shall preside at all meetings and sign all documents relating to the action taken by the committee. If both the chairman and vice-chairman are absent, a temporary chairman shall be elected by those members who are present. 
(c)  The director of recreation shall serve as secretary to the committee. He may delegate all or part of his duties to another department employee with the approval of the committee but shall hold the office of secretary and shall be held responsible for the satisfactory accomplishment of the secretarial duties. The secretary shall mail to all members copies of official reports and official minutes of all regular and special meetings prior to the next scheduled meeting. 
(Code 1967, § 17-21; Ord. No. 96-15, § 3, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 12-53. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The citizens advisory recreation committee shall serve as an advisory body for the town department of recreation. The committee shall suggest policies to the department of recreation, the town manager and the town council, within its powers and responsibilities. The committee shall serve as a liaison between the department of recreation, the town manager, the town council and the town citizens. The committee shall consult with and advise the department of recreation, the town manager and the town council in matters affecting recreation policies, programs, personnel, finances and the acquisition and disposal of lands and properties related to the total community recreation program and to its long-range projected program for recreation. 
(b)  The committee shall assume duties for recreation purposes and make recommendations: 
(1)  For the establishment of a system of supervised recreation for the town; 
(2)  To set apart for use as parks, playgrounds, recreation centers, water areas or other recreation areas and structures any lands or buildings owned by or leased to the town and for approval by the town council and may suggest improvements of such lands and for the construction and for the equipping and staffing of such buildings and structures as may be necessary to the recreation program within those funds allocated to the department of recreation; 
(3)  For the acquisition of lands and structures through gifts, purchase, lease or loan or by condemnation by the town as provided by chapter 40 of the General Statutes and as approved by the town council; 
(4)  For the acceptance by the town of any grant, gift, bequest or donation of any personal or real property offered or made available for recreation purposes and which is judged to be of present or possible future use for recreation. Any gift, bequest of money or other property, any grant, devise of real or personal property so acquired shall be held by the department of recreation, used and finally disposed of in accordance with the terms under which such grant, gift or devise is made and accepted; 
(5)  For the construction, equipping, operation, and maintenance of parks, playgrounds, recreation centers and all buildings and structures necessary or useful to department of recreation functions and will advise in regard to other recreation facilities which are owned or controlled by the town or leased or loaned to the town. 
(Code 1967, § 17-22) 
Sec. 12-54. - Subcommittees. 
    The citizen's advisory recreation committee chairman is hereby authorized to appoint such subcommittees as, in the opinion of the committee, are needed, including but not limited to subcommittees on programs and activities, areas and structures, budget, personnel and policies and procedures. Temporary and project subcommittees may be appointed as needed. 
(Code 1967, § 17-23) 
Sec. 12-55. - Reports. 
    At least annually in March, the citizen's advisory recreation committee shall prepare a written report and submit the report to the mayor and town council. The report shall show the activities and recommendations of the committee and department of recreation and the progress made and shall outline new goals recommended to be accomplished in the future. 
(Code 1967, § 17-24) 
Secs. 12-56-12-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RULES AND REGULATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses, Ch. 11. 

Sec. 12-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means the person, corporation, unincorporated association, or other legal entity in whose name an application is filed and who, by filing such application, agrees to act as the sponsor of the event for which the application is submitted and who agrees to be responsible for compliance with the provisions of this article. 
    Department means the parks and recreation department. 
    Director means the director of the parks and recreation department, or his or her designee. 
    Event means a gathering together of two or more persons within a recreational facility to attend or participate in an activity that has been previously planned and publicly or privately advertised. 
    Event sponsored by the town means an event with respect to which the town (i) exercises substantial managerial control over the planning and/or staging of the event, (ii) expends town funds for the planning and/or staging of the event, or (iii) receives revenue from the event pursuant to an agreement entered into between the town and the event sponsor. The town manager shall determine whether an event is one sponsored by the town. 
    Expressive event means an event held principally to engage in activities involving freedom of speech, assembly and/or the right to petition, protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution or Article I, Sections 12 and 14 of the North Carolina Constitution, but not including commercial speech or advertising. 
    Permittee means the person, corporation unincorporated association, or other legal entity in whose name a reservation or permit is issued and who has agreed to act as the sponsor of the event and to be responsible for compliance with the provisions of this article. 
    Recreational facilities means the parks and other outdoor and indoor properties and facilities that are owned, controlled or operated by the town, within or without the corporate limits of the town, in or on which people engage in recreational activities. A list of such facilities is set forth in section 12-77. 
    Town manager means the Tarboro Town Manager or the person designated by the manager to perform any of the duties or responsibilities assigned to the town manager by this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 17-30(a)-(c); Ord. No. 12-03, § 3, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-77. - Recreational facilities identified. 
    The town's recreational facilities include the following: 
(1)  The Town Common, which comprises that portion of land extending from Albemarle Avenue to Panola Street lying between Wilson Street and Park Avenue, including the Bridgers School property and the portion of land adjacent to the north bank of the Tar River owned by the town and extending along the river from Panola Street in a westerly direction. 
(2)  E.L. Roberson Senior Recreation Center, 305 West Baker Street. 
(3)  Braswell Center and Park, 1501 Western Blvd. 
(4)  M.A. Ray Center/Clark Park and Pool, 1405 Martin Luther King. 
(5)  Community Swimming Pool, 401 Porter Street. 
(6)  Tennis Courts, four at the Indian Lakes Sports Complex, two at Braswell Park, and two at the eastern end of the Town Commons. 
(7)  Indian Lake Sports Complex, 3300 Western Boulevard. 
(8)  Indian Lake Park, 3202 Western Boulevard. 
(9)  Riverfront Park, Entrance East Panola Street. 
(10)  Neighborhood Parks: Livesay, Hussey and Burlington Parks. 
(11)  Courthouse Square Park. 
(12)  Other facilities generally used by the town for recreational facilities. 
(Code 1967, § 17-30(d); Ord. No. 12-03, § 4, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-78. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  The town manager may establish the hours when town recreational facilities are open and available for use by the public, provided that the Town Common and Indian Lake Park shall be open for use at least from sunrise to sunset. Such opening and closing hours shall be prominently posted. 
(b)  No person may enter or remain upon any recreational facility at any time other than within the operating hours posted under subsection (a) of this section, or when such facility is being operated under the supervision of the department or when the facility is being used pursuant to a permit issued under this article. 
(Code 1967, § 17-32; Ord. No. 12-03, § 5, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79. - Permissive reservation of recreational facilities. 
(a)  Recreational facilities may generally be used by the public for recreational activities on a first-come-first-served basis, subject to the provisions of this article and other applicable ordinances of the town and under the general supervision, direction and control of the department. Some types of events require that a permit be issued in advance (see section 12-79.1). However, some facilities may be reserved under the provisions of this article for the exclusive, temporary use of a group or organization, even though no permit or reservation is required. The town manager shall determine and publish a list of those recreational facilities or portions thereof that may be reserved under this article. 
(b)  The town manager may establish limitations on the number of occasions per designated time period when any one organization or group may reserve a particular facility. 
(Code 1967, § 17-46; Ord. No. 07-09, § 1, 8-13-07; Ord. No. 12-03, § 6, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.1. - Permits required for certain events. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, the town's recreational facilities may not be used for the following types of events unless a permit for such an event has been issued by the director. 
(1)  Events attended by one hundred (100) or more persons at any one time. 
(2)  Outdoor events involving the use of any of the following if the same are not permanently located on the site of the event: (i) ten or more chairs, (ii) five or more tables, (iii) a portable stage or dance floor, (iv) portable restrooms; (v) tents, canopies or other shelters, (vi) inflatable devices used by children to ride or jump in or on, or (vii) other machinery, equipment, structures, fixtures, or devices that are sufficiently large as to constitute an obstruction to the free movement of persons using the recreational facility or that may cause damage to the facility or injury to persons using the facility. 
(3)  Outdoor events that involve the use of sound amplification equipment other than individually held bullhorns. 
(4)  Events attended by ten or more persons that occur within meeting rooms or other confined spaces within recreational or community buildings under circumstances where the occupancy of such rooms or spaces by one group effectively precludes the use of such rooms or spaces by other individuals or groups. The town manager shall determine and publish a list of those rooms or spaces that are subject to this subsection. 
(5)  Events that involve the sale to the general public of food wholly or partially prepared or cooked by the vendor. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Events sponsored by the town; or 
(2)  Expressive events such as demonstrations, protests, or rallies that are occasioned by or that occur in response to news or affairs coming into public knowledge less than forty-eight (48) hours prior to such events. However, sponsors of such events are requested to provide to the parks and recreation department and to the police department as much advance notice as possible of the proposed location, date, and time of such events. 
(c)  A permit issued under this section shall also constitute a reservation of the facilities described therein. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 7, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.2. - Applications for facilities reservations or permits. 
    An application for a facilities reservation under section 12-79 or a permit required under section 12-79.1 shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the person, corporation or other body sponsoring the event; 
(2)  The day and hours when the event is scheduled to occur; 
(3)  The facilities desired to be reserved; 
(4)  An estimate of the anticipated attendance; 
(5)  The nature, character and scope of the proposed event for which the facilities are requested to be reserved; 
(6)  A sketch plan or layout of the event area, including locations of all tables, chairs, tents, stages, portable restrooms, and other temporary fixtures or equipment; 
(7)  A parking management plan for any event where the attendance is expected to exceed seventy-five (75) persons at any one time. 
(8)  Any other information which the town manager shall find reasonably necessary to make a fair determination as to whether a reservation should be made or a permit issued. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 8, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.3. - Time for submitting and responding to applications. 
(a)  An application for a facilities reservation authorized under section 12-79 must be submitted to the town manager at least ten (10) working days prior to the date of the event for which the reservation is requested. If a timely application is received, the manager shall make every reasonable effort to approve or deny the application within five (5) working days thereafter. If an untimely application is received, the manager may summarily deny it or take other action upon it as time and resources allow. 
(b)  Subject to subsection (c), an application for a permit required under section 12-79.1 must be submitted to the town manager at least thirty (30) working days prior to the date of the event for which the permit is requested. If a timely application is received, the manager shall make every reasonable effort to approve or deny the application within ten (10) working days thereafter. If an untimely application is received, the manager may summarily deny it or take other action upon it as time and resources allow. 
(c)  If a permit is required under section 12-79.1 for an expressive event, the application must be submitted to the town manager at least three (3) working days prior to the date of the event for which the permit is requested. If a timely application is received, the manager shall make every reasonable effort to approve or deny the application within two (2) working days thereafter. If an untimely application is received, the manager may summarily deny it or take other action upon it as time and resources allow. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 9, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.4. - Standards for approving facilities reservations and permits. 
(a)  The town manager shall approve the application for a reservation or a permit unless he or she finds that: 
(1)  The application (including any required attachments and submissions) is not fully completed and executed; or 
(2)  The applicant has not tendered any fees or deposits required under section 79.5; or 
(3)  The application contains a material falsehood or misrepresentation; or 
(4)  The applicant or person on whose behalf the application is submitted has on prior occasions damaged town facilities and has not paid in full for such damage; or 
(5)  The facilities requested have previously been reserved for another use during the date and time requested in the application; or 
(6)  The event proposed by the applicant would conflict with previously planned programs organized and conducted by the department; or 
(7)  The facilities requested are inadequate to accommodate the proposed event and the number of people expected to attend; or 
(8)  The use or activity intended by the applicant would present an unreasonable danger to the health or safety of the applicant, other users of the facility, town employees, or the general public; or 
(9)  The event proposed or described by the applicant would be inconsistent with any federal or state statute, town ordinance, or written town policy, including without limitation laws that prohibit discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, creed, national origin, age, gender, or disability; or 
(10)  The applicant has on prior occasions made material misrepresentations regarding the nature or scope of an event previously permitted or has violated the terms of a prior permit; or 
(11)  The proposed event will not be limited to the hours of operation of the requested facility as established pursuant to section 12-78, unless the department can accommodate a request for the event to occur outside those hours upon payment by the event sponsor of the costs incurred by the town in making such an accommodation. 
(b)  If the town manager determines that no reason exists under subsection (a) to deny the application, the reservation or permit shall be approved. If the manager determines that the application should be denied for one or more of the reasons set forth in subsection (a), the manager shall inform the applicant wherein the application is deficient, and the reasons therefor. If the deficiency is remedied or the application is revised to meet all the standards of subsection (a), the manager shall approve the requested reservation; otherwise, the application shall be denied. 
(c)  In deciding whether to approve an application, no consideration may be given to the message of the event, the content of speech, the identity or associational relationships of the applicant, or to any assumptions or predictions as to the amount of hostility which may be aroused in the public by the content of speech or message conveyed by the event. 
(d)  A reservation or permit may be issued subject to reasonable conditions and requirements concerning the time, place or manner of holding the event as are necessary to coordinate multiple uses of the facility that is the site of the event, assure preservation of public property and public places, prevent dangerous, unlawful or impermissible uses, or activities, protect the safety of persons and property, control vehicular and pedestrian traffic in and around the facility, and otherwise ensure that the event is consistent with the provisions of this article and other town ordinances; provided that such conditions and requirements shall not be imposed in a manner that will unreasonably restrict expressive or other activity protected by the North Carolina or United States constitutions. 
(e)  Reservations or permits approved under this article may not be assigned. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 10, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.5. - Facilities reservation and permit fees. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (d), an application for a reservation under section 12-79 or a permit under section 12-79.1 shall be accompanied by payment of an application fee in an amount specified in or determined in accordance with the fee schedule adopted by the town council. An application will not be considered complete and will not be processed unless and until the required application fee is paid. The application fee is designed to cover only the costs incurred by the town in processing the application. 
(b)  Subject to subsections (c) and (d), an application for a reservation under section 12-79 or a permit under section 12-79.1 shall also be accompanied by payment of (i) a user fee, if such a fee has been established for the facility in question in the fee schedule adopted by the council, and (ii) a services and damages deposit, designed to ensure that the town is reimbursed should costs be incurred as a result of services provided to the event or should damages to the facility be sustained as a result of the event. For some facilities, this deposit will be a fixed amount set forth in the fee schedule. When no such fixed amount is established, the town manager shall, after consulting with appropriate town departments, determine the estimated cost that may be incurred by the town to provide services before, during, and after the event. To that amount shall be added a reasonable facilities damage deposit, determined by the manager upon consideration of the nature and size of the requested event and the type of facility where the event will be held. Following the event, if the actual cost of services provided and/or damages incurred is less than the services and damages deposit, the excess amount shall be refunded to the applicant. If the cost of services and damages is greater than the deposit, then the applicant shall promptly reimburse the town upon receipt of a statement from the town itemizing the costs incurred and/or the damages sustained. 
(c)  Subject to subsection (d), an applicant for a reservation under section 12-79 or a permit under section 12-79.1 to hold an expressive event shall not be required to pay a facilities user fee. Nor shall such an applicant be required to pay a services and damages deposit unless the amount of such deposit for the facility in question has been previously established in the fee schedule. However, following the event, the town shall determine the actual costs incurred by the town as a result of damages to the facility resulting directly from the event and directly attributable to the permittee, as well the actual costs incurred by the town in providing services to the event, except that the permittee shall not be required to pay for the cost of public safety personnel who were present to protect event attendees from hostile members of the public or counter-demonstrators or for general law enforcement in the vicinity of the event. The permittee shall promptly reimburse the town upon receipt of a statement from the town itemizing the costs incurred and/or the damages sustained. 
(d)  An applicant for a reservation under section 12-79 or a permit under section 12-79.1 to hold an expressive event shall not be required to pay an application fee or a services fee if the applicant submits with the application an affidavit, on a form provided by the department, stating that neither the applicant as an individual nor any organization, group, or entity represented by the applicant has the financial resources to pay such fees. However, such affidavit shall not relieve the permittee of the responsibility to pay for any damages to the facility resulting directly from the event and directly attributable to the permittee. 
(e)  If an event is cancelled, the applicant or sponsor shall promptly notify the director. No refund shall be made of the application fee. The town shall refund the user fee and services and damages deposit after deducting any costs incurred by the town prior to receiving notification of such cancellation. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 11, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.6. - Insurance. 
(a)  Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, no reservation may be made under section 12-79, and no permit may be issued under section 12-79.1 unless and until the applicant has provided to the town a certificate of insurance stating that the applicant has in effect a comprehensive liability insurance policy covering the event in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00), which policy must contain an endorsement naming the Town of Tarboro, specifically and separately, as an additional insured. The insurance company must be licensed to do business in the State of North Carolina. The policy or the endorsement must obligate the insurance company to notify the town in writing not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the date such policy is terminated or modified if such termination or modification is to occur prior to the indicated expiration date on the face of the certificate. If the policy is cancelled or modified in such a way as to lessen the town's coverage prior to the event, the permit shall be automatically revoked. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply to expressive events. 
(c)  The town manager may publish a list of recreational facilities whose nature is such that events held in such facilities are unlikely to pose a significant risk of liability for the town or damage to such facilities, and subsection (a) shall not apply to events held in the facilities on that list. Similarly, subsection (a) shall not apply to particular events or categories of events which the manager concludes create no significant exposure to liability for the town or likelihood of damage to town recreational facilities. The manager shall publish a list of any categories of events (e.g. weddings, family reunions, etc.) with respect to which such a determination is made. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 12, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.7. - Indemnification. 
    Each application for a facility reservation under section 12-79 or a permit under section 12-79.1 shall expressly provide that the applicant agrees, at its own cost, risk and expense, (i) to defend any and all claims and all legal actions that may be commenced or filed against the town, its officers, agents, employees, or volunteers arising out of the alleged willful or negligent acts or omissions of the applicant, its officers, agents, or employees in connection with the proposed event; (ii) to pay any settlement entered into and satisfy any judgment that may be rendered against the town as the result of the alleged willful or negligent acts or omissions of the applicant, its officers, agents, or employees in connection with the proposed event; and (iii) otherwise to protect, indemnify and hold the town, its officers, employees, agents, and volunteers free and harmless from and against any and all claims, damages, expenses, loss or liability of any kind or nature whatsoever resulting from the alleged willful or negligent acts or omissions of the applicant, its officers, agents, or employees in connection with the proposed event. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 13, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.8. - Sanitation services. 
(a)  The public works department shall determine whether an event for which a reservation or permit is requested will require additional trash receptacles, including dumpsters, beyond those normally present within or serving the facility that is the subject of the reservation or permit. The cost of providing such additional equipment and services will be charged to the applicant pursuant to section 12-79.5. 
(b)  It is the applicant's responsibility to deposit any trash into appropriate trash receptacles following the event in order to avoid being charged under section 12-79.5 for the cost incurred by the town of picking up such trash. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 14, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.9. - Miscellaneous requirements applicable to events. 
(a)  Restroom facilities. For all events of four (4) hours duration or more, the town manager may approve an application for a facility reservation or permit subject to a condition (under subsection 12-79.4(d)) requiring that portable toilets be provided if the manager concludes that no restrooms exist on site or that existing restrooms are unlikely to be able to handle the demand given the expected attendance at the event. In compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act, the applicant must provide sufficient handicap accessible portable toilets. It is the applicant's responsibility to make all arrangements (drop-off, pumping during the event, and pick-up) and pay any rental fees. The town will stock supplies for permanent restroom facilities prior to start of event. 
(b)  Medical. For all events (other than expressive events) of four (4) hours duration or more, the town manager may condition the reservation or permit on the applicant making necessary arrangements at its expense to have county EMS medical personnel available on site if the manager concludes that having such medical personnel on site is warranted given the nature of and expected attendance at the event. 
(c)  Utilities. Applicants for reservations or permits for events that will require more than an incidental amount of electricity, or any temporary wiring systems other than a maximum of twenty-five (25) feet of extension cords plugged into existing outlets, or the use of lighting other than from existing fixtures, shall submit with their applications complete information describing their proposed use of electricity and electrical fixtures. Events that utilize more than incidental amounts of electricity will be charged for such services pursuant to section 12-79.5 based on electric meter readings taken prior to and following such events. 
(d)  Sound systems. The town does not provide sound system equipment. Applicants for reservations or permits for events where sound amplification equipment will be used shall submit with their application information as to the nature and extent of the use of such sound amplification equipment. Pursuant to section 11-18.2 of this Code of Ordinances, outdoor concerts and other amplified sound must conclude by 10:00 p.m. 
(e)  Parking. All persons attending an event shall adhere to all parking regulations established by the town. Permittees are prohibited from charging anyone for parking in public spaces. For events expected to be attended by more than five hundred (500) persons at any one time, permittees may be required to arrange for satellite parking and shuttle service to and from such off-site parking. 
(f)  Food sales. When food sales are permitted under this article, the permittee shall be responsible for obtaining any necessary permits from the Edgecombe County Health Department. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 15, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-79.10. - Appeals. 
(a)  An applicant whose application for a facilities reservation or permit has been denied or issued subject to one or more conditions to which the applicant objects may appeal such denial or objectionable condition to the council by filing a written notice of the appeal with the town clerk not later than ten (10) days after receiving written notice from the town of the denial or objectionable condition. 
(b)  The council shall hear the appeal as expeditiously as possible, but not later than the first regular meeting of the council that occurs at least five (5) days after the town receives the notice of appeal. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the appeal involves an expressive event, and the applicant so requests, the council shall hear and decide the appeal at a regular or special meeting held within three (3) days after receipt of the notice of appeal. 
(c)  In deciding the appeal, the council may exercise all the powers of the town manager as set forth in this article. 
(d)  The council's decision shall be reduced to writing and a copy thereof shall be provided to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 16, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-80. - Conflict of use. 
(a)  No person or group of persons shall use any town recreation area or facility for a recreation activity or other use or activity which will interfere with or detract from any recreation activity under the general supervision, direction and control of the department of recreation. 
(b)  No person may obstruct, impede, or otherwise interfere with any activity or any person participating in any activity occurring at an event for which a facilities reservation has been made or a permit issued so long as such activity is in compliance with such reservation or permit and the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 17-47; Ord. No. 12-03, § 17, 5-14-12) 
(Code 1967, § 17-47) 
Sec. 12-81. - Compliance with requirements. 
(a)  Any person who is present at the site of an event that is taking place (i) without a permit required by the provisions of this article, or (ii) contrary to the terms or conditions of such a permit, may be directed by a law enforcement officer or authorized representative of the department to vacate the recreational facility or portion thereof where such event is taking place. It shall be a violation of this article for any such person to refuse to follow such a directive. 
(b)  Any person who engages in conduct within any recreational facility that is in violation of any of the provisions of this article or any other ordinance, policy, rule, or regulation properly adopted by the council or the town manager applicable to such facilities may be directed by a law enforcement officer or authorized representative of the department to vacate the recreational facility or portion thereof where such violation is occurring or has occurred. It shall be a violation of this ordinance for any such person to refuse to follow such a directive. 
(c)  The town reserves the right at any time to revoke the right to use the town's recreation facilities to individuals or groups not conforming to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 17-50; Ord. No. 12-03, § 18, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-82. - Participation fees. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Industrial participants means persons who do not reside within the corporate limits of the town but are full time permanent employees performing a work week of at least thirty-five (35) hours per week for an industry located within the corporate limits of the town. Industrial participants may participate in activities organized by the recreation department and sponsored by the industry where they are employed. 
    Nonresident eligible participants means persons who do not live within the corporate limits of the town but live outside the corporate limits of the town. Nonresident eligible participants may participate in activities organized by the recreation department when there is space available in the program they wish to participate in. 
    Resident participants means persons who reside within the corporate limits of the town or who own a minimum of six thousand (6,000) square feet of property within the corporate limits of the town. 
(b)  Fees. All resident participants will be allowed to participate in the recreation program of the town subject to payment of the normal charges and fees of the given activity. Nonresident eligible participants and industrial participants, in order to qualify for participation in the recreation program of the town, shall comply with the fee schedule as determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. Nonresident eligible participants will pay twice the normal fee or twenty-five dollars ($25.00), whichever is greater, for participation charges which are set by the recreation department and not listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(Code 1967, §§ 17-60, 17-61; Ord. No. 91-11, § 1, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 99-15, § 1, 8-9-99; Ord. No. 04-14, § 1, 12-6-04) 
Sec. 12-83. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-03, § 19, adopted May 14, 2012, repealed § 12-83, which pertained to permits required for parades, processions or meetings and derived from § 17-48 of the 1967 Code. 
Sec. 12-84. - Swimming pools. 
(a)  The director shall prepare rules and regulations for the proper management and operation of the town-owned swimming pools which shall be approved by the town council and by reference become a part of this section. These rules and regulations shall be posted at each pool. 
(b)  The opening and closing dates of the pools shall be established by the director. 
(c)  The director shall have supervision of all activities and personnel in the swimming pools and pool areas. 
(d)  The director is authorized to and shall establish schedules, rules and regulations for the use of the pools by the town swimming teams and other swimming teams for the purpose of competitive swimming meets and practices therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 17-51) 
Sec. 12-85. - Concessions. 
    The town reserves the right to operate concession stands for all functions. 
(Code 1967, § 17-49; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 3-10-03) 
Sec. 12-86. - Vehicles in recreation areas. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any unlicensed person to drive or propel any vehicle in, over or through any recreation area, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or propel any motor vehicle or other vehicle in, over or through any recreation area except along and upon designated recreation area drives, parking lots and recreation area boulevards. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or permit to be parked any vehicle anywhere in any recreation areas except upon designated parking areas authorized by the director. 
(Code 1967, § 17-33) 
Sec. 12-87. - Advertising, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or erect any structure, sign, bulletin board, post, pole or advertising device of any kind whatever in any recreation area or facility or to attach any notice, bill, poster, sign, wire, rod or cord to any tree, shrub, fence, railing post or structure within any recreation area or facility except as authorized by the director. 
(Code 1967, § 17-34) 
Sec. 12-88. - Commercial activity. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b), no person may engage in commercial activity within or on town recreational facilities. For purposes of this section, commercial activity means any activity conducted by any person (other than the Town of Tarboro) for the purpose of collecting admission charges or fees of any kind, as well as any sale, attempted sale, or advertisement of sale of any goods, merchandise, equipment or services. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sales of goods, merchandise and services by authorized persons at town sponsored events. 
(2)  Sales of goods, merchandise, and services by persons acting as agents of the town. 
(3)  The following activities when conducted by nonprofit organizations: 
a.  Solicitation of donations. 
b.  Sales of goods, merchandise, and services at an event for which a reservation has been made pursuant to section 12-79 or a permit issued pursuant to section 12-79.1. 
c.  Other fund raising activities conducted at those indoor recreational facilities that may be reserved pursuant to section 12-79. 
(Code 1967, § 17-35; Ord. No. 12-03, § 20, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-89. - Firearms and other weapons. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except duly authorized department of recreation employees or law enforcement officers in the course of their official duties, to discharge, shoot, fire or explode or cause to be discharged, shot, fired or exploded any firearm, including but not limited to any type of arms, device or top designed to forcibly hurl a projectile or missile, at any time or under any circumstances within any recreation area or facility or to carry any firearms in any recreation area or facility. 
(b)  Archery equipment, air rifles, slingshots or other similar devices may be shot or discharged only on those areas, if any, within the recreation areas or facilities which may be specifically set aside and designated for such purposes and so posted and only then under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the director. 
(Code 1967, § 17-36) 
Sec. 12-90. - Destruction or damage to property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, damage, destroy, mutilate or deface any structure, monument, statue, planter, fountain, wall, fence, railing, vehicle, bench, tree, plant or any other property in any recreation area or facility. It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, cut, bruise, mutilate or cause to be transplanted, cut, bruised, debarked or mutilated any plant material of any description within any town recreation area or facility without written permission of the director. 
(Code 1967, § 17-37) 
Sec. 12-91. - Animals running at large; horseback riding. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner thereof to allow or permit any horses, dogs or other animals to run at large in any park, and it shall be unlawful to ride horses in any park except upon designated and marked bridle trails and under such rules and regulations as shall be prescribed by the director. 
(Code 1967, § 17-38) 
Sec. 12-92. - Molesting animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to trap, catch, wound or kill or cause to be injured, treat cruelly or tease or attempt to trap, catch, wound, kill, injure or tease any bird or animal or molest or rob any nest of any bird or any lair, den or burrow of any animal in or upon any park or recreation area owned by the town and administered by the department of recreation. 
(Code 1967, § 17-39) 
Sec. 12-93. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-03, § 21, adopted May 14, 2012, repealed § 12-93, which pertained to selling, peddling, etc. and derived from § 17-40 of the 1967 Code. 
Sec. 12-94. - Alcoholic beverages, intoxicating liquors and narcotic drugs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, consume or display publicly any alcoholic beverages, intoxicating liquors or narcotic drugs as defined by the General Statutes on or in any town recreation area or facility, and it shall be unlawful for any person under the influence of intoxicating beverages or liquors or narcotic drugs to enter or remain on or in any town recreation area or facility. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a), the sale, consumption, and possession of alcoholic beverages are permitted at the Blount Bridgers House and property so long as all required permits are obtained from the North Carolina Alcohol Beverage Commission. 
(Code 1967, § 17-41; Ord. No. 12-03, § 22, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-95. - Games, sports, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to play or practice football, golf, baseball or other games or activities of like character in any area in any town recreation area or facility except in areas specifically designed and designated for such game or activity. At no time and under no circumstances shall such games or activities be played in such proximity to playground equipment or park structures as to threaten bodily harm to persons using the park or damage to park structures. 
(Code 1967, § 17-42) 
Sec. 12-96. - Excavations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make an excavation in any recreation area or facility for any purpose without permission from the director. 
(Code 1967, § 17-43) 
Sec. 12-97. - Fires. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make or kindle a fire in any recreation area or facility except in a regularly constructed fireplace or grill. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave any fire unattended or to fail to completely extinguish a fire and all the embers thereof before leaving such fire. 
(Code 1967, § 17-44) 
Sec. 12-98. - Dumping. 
    Except in containers provided for that purpose, no person shall deposit, dump, throw, cast, lay or place or cause to be deposited, dumped, thrown, cast, laid or placed any ashes, trash, rubbish, soil, earth, paper, garbage, refuse, debris, plant clippings or limbs or leaves in or upon any town recreation area or facility or in any watercourse, lake, pond or slough within any recreation area. 
(Code 1967, § 17-45) 
Sec. 12-99. - Camping prohibited except at Indian Lake Park and Blount-Bridgers House and Grounds. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b) of this section: 
(1)  No tents designed to provide shelter for sleeping shall be erected within any town recreational facility. 
(2)  Camping or sleeping between sunset and sunrise within any town recreational facility is prohibited. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) shall not apply to persons engaged in camping within Indian Lake Park and Blount-Bridgers House and Grounds pursuant to and in accordance with a permit by the department. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 23, 5-14-12) 
Sec. 12-100. - Alterations to recreational facilities. 
    Alterations to recreational facilities including the attachment or installation of decorations and displays are prohibited except as authorized pursuant to a facilities reservation of permit approved under this article. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 24, 5-14-12) 
Chapter 13 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Personnel, G.S. § 160A-162 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Full-time employees means those who are in classified positions for which an average workweek of at least forty (40) hours and continuous employment of at least twelve (12) consecutive months are required by the town. Temporary layoff and authorized leave without pay do not interrupt continuous employment for purposes of this section and are omitted in calculations of the average workweek. 
    Part-time employees means those who are in classified positions for which an average workweek of at least twenty (20) hours and less than forty (40) hours and continuous employment of at least twelve (12) consecutive months are required by the town. Temporary layoff and authorized leave without pay do not interrupt continuous employment for purposes of this section and are omitted in calculation of the average workweek. 
    Permanent employees means all full-time and part-time employees who have successfully completed their probation periods. All town positions are subject to budget review and approval each year, and employees must meet established standards of conduct and job performance. Reference to permanent employees or permanent positions should not be construed as a right or contract to perpetual funding or employment. 
    Probationary employees means those serving their probationary period in accordance with the provisions of article V of this chapter. 
    Temporary employees means those who work in positions for which either the average workweek required by the town over the course of a year is less than twenty (20) hours or continuous employment required by the town is less than twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-6, 19-7, 19-8, 19-9), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-2. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is hereby the purpose of this chapter and the rules and regulations set forth in this chapter to establish a fair and uniform system of personnel administration for all employees of the town under the supervision of the town manager. Nothing in this chapter creates an employment contract or term between the town and employees. 
(b)  This chapter shall cover all employees except: 
(1)  Elected officials; 
(2)  Officials appointed by the town council; 
(3)  Employees not covered by the classification plan of this chapter; and 
(4)  Employees of advisory or special boards or commissions. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-1), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-3. - Approval of personnel policies and plans. 
    The town council shall be responsible for approving the personnel policies, the position classification plan and the pay plan and for making and confirming appointments when so specified by law. The council and town manager may change the policies and benefits from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-2), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-4. - Administration. 
(a)  The town manager will be responsible for the following: 
(1)  Administering the personnel program according to the rules, policies and procedures established in this chapter; 
(2)  Making all appointments to positions under the manager's jurisdiction within the provisions set forth in the Charter and the policies and procedures established in this chapter; 
(3)  Preparing and presenting to the town council for their approval recommendations for additions or revisions to the procedures governing the overall administration of the personnel program; and 
(4)  Ensuring compliance with federal and state laws and regulations and ensuring fair and equitable treatment of employees. 
(b)  The personnel officer, who may be designated by the town manager, will be responsible to the manager for the administrative and technical direction of the personnel program. The personnel officer shall: 
(1)  Administer, under the direction of the manager, the personnel program as set forth in this chapter; 
(2)  Perform all lawful and necessary duties essential to the effective administration of the personnel system, including compliance with federal and state laws and regulations; 
(3)  Recommend to the manager rules and revisions thereto for the consideration of the town council; 
(4)  Recommend to the manager a position classification and pay plan for approval by the council and install and maintain such a plan; 
(5)  Establish and maintain required and necessary personnel records, and maintain the security of these records; 
(6)  Develop and administer such recruiting and examining programs as may be necessary to obtain an adequate supply of competent applicants to meet the needs of the town; 
(7)  Develop and coordinate training and educational programs for town employees; 
(8)  Administer benefits programs and interpret personnel policies for town employees; 
(9)  Investigate periodically the operation and effect of the personnel provisions of this chapter and of personnel policies, and recommend changes to the manager; and 
(10)  Perform such other duties as may be assigned by the town manager not inconsistent with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-3), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-5. - Application of policies, plans, rules and regulations. 
    The personnel policies and plans and all rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto shall be binding on all town employees, and any employee failing to carry out the full implementation of these policies may be subject to disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-4), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-6. - Establishment of departmental rules and regulations. 
    Due to the particular personnel and operational requirements of the various departments of the town, each department is authorized to establish supplemental rules and regulations applicable only to the personnel of that department. All such rules and regulations shall be subject to the approval of the town manager and shall not in any way conflict with the provisions of this chapter, but shall be deemed supplemental hereto. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-5), 6-13-88) 
Secs. 13-7-13-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POSITION CLASSIFICATION PLAN 

Sec. 13-16. - Purpose. 
    The position classification plan provides a complete inventory of all authorized and permanent positions in the town service and an accurate description and specification for each class of employment. The plan standardizes job titles, each of which is indicative of a definite range of duties and responsibilities. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-20), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-17. - Composition. 
    The classification plan shall consist of: 
(1)  A grouping of positions in classes which are approximately equal in difficulty and responsibility, which call for the same general qualifications and which can be equitably compensated within the same range of pay under similar working conditions; 
(2)  Class titles descriptive of the work of the class; 
(3)  Written specifications for each class of positions; and 
(4)  An allocation list showing the class title of each position in the classified service. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-21), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-18. - Use of plan. 
    The classification plan is to be used: 
(1)  As a guide in recruiting and examining applicants for employment; 
(2)  In determining lines of promotion and in developing employee training programs; 
(3)  In determining salary to be paid for various types of work; 
(4)  In determining personnel service items in departmental budgets; and 
(5)  In providing uniform job terminology. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-22), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-19. - Administration. 
    The town manager shall allocate each position covered by the classification plan to its appropriate class and shall be responsible for the administration of the position classification plan. The manager shall periodically review the entire position classification plan and recommend appropriate changes to the town council. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-23), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-20. - Adoption of plan. 
    The position classification plan shall be adopted by resolution by the town council and shall be on file with the town clerk. Copies will be made available to all town employees for review upon request. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-24), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-21. - Request for reclassification. 
    Any employee who considers his classification to be improper may submit a request for reclassification in writing to his immediate supervisor, who shall immediately transmit the request to the department head or manager. Upon receipt of such request, the manager shall study the request, determine the merit of such reclassification and advise the employee, in writing, of the finding as well as the right to appeal the finding under the grievance procedure. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-25), 6-13-88) 
Secs. 13-22-13-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PAY PLAN 

Sec. 13-36. - Defined. 
    The pay plan includes the basic salary schedule and the "assignment of classes to grades and ranges" adopted and amended by the town council. The salary schedule consists of steps for minimum, maximum and intervening rates of pay for all classes of positions and designation of the standard hours in the workweek for each position. Salary increases within the pay range shall be based on performance. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-30), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-37. - Effective date. 
    The pay plan and all amendments shall be effective on the date determined by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-31), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-38. - Maintenance of plan. 
    The town manager shall be responsible for the administration and maintenance of the pay plan. The pay plan is intended to maintain equitable compensation for all classes in the classification plan with regard to range of pay of other classes, general rates of pay for similar employment in private establishments in the area, cost of living data, financial condition of the town and other factors. To this end, the manager will, from time to time, make comparative studies of all factors affecting the level of salary ranges and will recommend to the town council such changes in salary ranges as appear to be pertinent. Such assignments will be made by increasing or decreasing the assigned salary grade for the class and adjusting the rate of pay for employees in the class when the action is approved by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-32), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-39. - Transition to a new plan. 
    The following provisions shall govern the transition to a new pay plan: 
(1)  No employees shall receive a salary reduction as a result of the transition to a new pay plan. 
(2)  An employee being paid at a rate lower than the minimum rate established for such employee's class shall be raised to a salary at or above the new minimum for the class. 
(3)  An employee being paid at a rate below the maximum rate established for the employee's respective class shall continue to be paid at a rate within the pay range and shall be paid at a rate listed in the salary schedule; all employees not at a listed rate shall have their salaries raised to a listed rate. 
(4)  An employee being paid at a rate above the maximum rate established for such employee's class shall remain at such rate as long as the maximum rate is below the employee's present salary. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-33), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-40. - Use of salary ranges. 
    Salary ranges are intended to furnish administrative flexibility in recognizing individual differences among positions allocated to the same class, in providing employee incentive and in rewarding employees for meritorious service. The following provisions shall govern the granting of within-the-range increases: 
(1)  The minimum rate established for the class is the normal hiring rate for new employees, except in those cases where unusual circumstances appear to warrant appointment at a higher rate. Appointment above the minimum step may be made when the town manager determines that it is necessary in the best interest of the town. Approval will be based on the qualifications of the applicant being in excess of the requirements of the position or that there is a shortage of qualified applicants available at the minimum step or that qualified applicants decline employment at the minimum step. 
(2)  Advancement within the salary range to a higher level of pay shall be at the recommendation of the department head based on the quality of the individual's work performance. The anniversary date shall be the date of employment plus one (1) year. On the employee's anniversary date and annually thereafter, the department head shall evaluate each employee in his department and determine if a merit increase is warranted. Employee eligibility for a merit increase shall be based upon approval by the town manager and may be subject to budget or policy limitations. Procedures for determining increase eligibility shall be published in policies developed by the town manager. Evaluation reports shall be forwarded promptly to the manager and will become part of the employee's formal personnel record. 
(3)  Across-the-board or pay plan increases may be given at such times and in such amounts as the town council may authorize. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-34), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-41. - Payment at a listed rate. 
    All employees covered by the pay plan shall be paid at a listed rate within the salary range established for their respective job classifications, except employees in a trainee status or employees whose present salaries are above the established maximum rate following transition to a new pay plan. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-35), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-42. - Trainees.
