(a)  Applicants being considered for employment or town employees who do not meet all of the requirements for the position for which they are being considered may be hired, promoted, demoted or transferred by the town manager to a trainee position. 
(b)  In such cases, a plan for training, including a time schedule, must be prepared and approved by the town manager. Trainee salaries may be no more than two (2) steps below the minimum salary established for the position for which the person is being trained. A new employee designated as "trainee" shall be regarded as a probationary employee. 
(c)  If the training is not successfully completed as planned, the trainee shall be terminated in accordance with the provisions of article VI of this chapter or, if the trainee transferred from another town position, may be returned to the employee's previous or a comparable town position. If the training is successfully completed, the employee shall be paid at least at the minimum hiring rate for the position for which the traineeship was developed. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-36), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-43. - Promoted employee. 
    When an employee is promoted, the employee's salary shall normally be advanced to the minimum level for the new position or to a salary which provides at least a one-step increase over the salary before promotion; provided, however, that the new salary may not exceed the maximum rate of the new salary range. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-37), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-44. - Demoted employee. 
(a)  When an employee is demoted to a position for which qualified, the salary shall be set at the rate in the lower pay range which provides the smallest decrease in pay if action is not for cause. If the current salary is within the new range, the employee's salary may be retained at the previous rate. 
(b)  If the demotion is for cause, the salary shall be decreased at least one (1) step or to the new maximum. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-38), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-45. - Effective date of salary adjustments. 
    Salary adjustments which are approved shall become effective with the first day of the pay period immediately following the town manager's approval. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-40), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-46. - Court pay. 
    Police officers required to appear in court on regular days off shall receive compensation for the time spent as provided in the pay plan. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-41), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-47. - Payroll deductions. 
    Deductions shall be made from each employee's salary, as required by law. Additional deductions may be made upon employee request, as approved by the town manager. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-42), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-48. - Overtime compensation. 
    Employees covered by overtime policies will be compensated for overtime, following the provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act, in article V of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-43), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-49. - Call-back pay and on-call pay. 
(a)  An employee not exempt from the Fair Labor Standards Act who is called out to perform emergency work after normal working hours shall be guaranteed a minimum of two (2) hours' compensation at the overtime rate of pay as a reporting fee and as minimum pay for time worked up to two (2) hours. All time worked in excess of these hours shall be compensated for at the appropriate straight or time-and-a-half pay rate. 
(b)  Employees who are designated for on-call status during off-duty hours and are required to remain available to report for work when called shall be compensated for such services at the time-and-one-half pay rate for all hours worked. The minimum number of guaranteed hours for such services shall be five (5) hours per week, which shall also be compensated for at the time-and-one-half pay rate. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-44), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-50. - Delivery of checks by finance officer. 
    At least once each year the finance officer shall personally hand the employee's paycheck to each employee. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-45), 6-13-88) 
Secs. 13-51-13-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMPLOYMENT POLICY 

Sec. 13-71. - Statement of policy. 
    The policy of the town is to foster, maintain and promote equal employment opportunity. The town shall select employees on the basis of applicants' qualifications for the job and award them, with respect to compensation and opportunity for training and advancement, including upgrading and promotion, without regard to age, sex, race, color, religion, nonjob-related handicap or national origin. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-50), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-72. - Implementation of policy. 
    All personnel responsible for recruiting and employment will continue to review regularly the implementation of this personnel policy and relevant practices to ensure that equal employment opportunity based on reasonable job-related job requirements is being actively observed to the end that no employee or applicant for employment shall suffer discrimination because of age, sex, race, color, religion, nonjob-related handicap or national origin. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-51), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-73. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 00-13, § 1, adopted June 19, 2000 repealed section 13-73 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to recruitment sources. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 13-74. - Equal employment notices. 
    Employment advertisements shall contain assurances of equal employment opportunity and shall comply with federal and state statutes. Notices with regard to equal employment shall be posted in conspicuous places on town government premises. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-53), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-75. - Application reserve file. 
    The personnel office shall keep a reserve file of all applications received for a period of two (2) years or as required by federal or state law. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-54), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-76. - Qualifications and testing. 
(a)  The policy of the town is that hiring qualifications for both entry level and promotional level jobs be fair. Qualifications shall be reviewed periodically to ensure that requirements conform to the actual job performance requirements and to changing situations. 
(b)  Tests administered by the town or by the state employment security commission for the town shall be only those measuring the skills actually required for the job. All tests given to applicants shall be administered by or under the direction of the manager, by the employment security commission, the institute of government or, in psychological exams or similar special situations, by designated members of the faculty of academic institutions or by qualified professionals. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-55), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-77. - Promotion and employee development. 
(a)  Employees will be provided every reasonable means to succeed on their jobs and will be given opportunities to prepare themselves for full use of their talents and potential. On-the-job training will be provided to prepare employees to meet the full requirements of their new jobs and special programs developed to meet specialized training needs. 
(b)  Candidates for promotion shall be chosen on the basis of existing or forecasted job openings, on their qualifications and work records, without regard to sex, race, color, religion, age, national origin or nonjob-related handicap. Performance appraisals and work records for all personnel, including minority groups, will be carefully examined when openings for higher level positions occur. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-56), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-78. - Qualification standards. 
    Employees shall meet the minimum standards established by the position classification plan, unless hired as a trainee employee. Employees shall also meet such other reasonable minimum standards as to character, aptitude, ability to meet the public and physical condition as may be established by the town manager with the advice and recommendations of department heads. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-57), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-79. - Employment procedures. 
(a)  Whenever a job opening occurs, and when the procedures set forth in this article have been completed, the personnel director shall screen all applications for the position to a top group. The department head or supervisor may interview and/or check the references on any or all such selected applicants. 
(b)  In order to protect the town from possible conduct which might be detrimental to the town and its property, no person who is known to have been convicted of a misdemeanor or felony crime of theft, burglary, embezzlement, robbery, fraud, wrongful conversion of or misappropriation or misuse of property of others may be employed or offered employment with the town in the following positions: Town manager, assistant town manager, clerk, director of finance, director of electric utilities, director of public works, fire chief, police chief, director of parks and recreation, director of planning, personnel officer, accounting/data processing manager, purchasing agent, collector of revenue, revenue cashier, warehouse supervisor and law enforcement officer. 
(c)  In the event of a vacancy in any of these positions, the personnel officer shall conduct an investigation of each applicant. As a part of that investigation, he shall require each applicant for these positions to provide fingerprints and all other necessary personal identification so that the chief of police might cause a thorough search to be made of local and state criminal history records to determine if the applicant has a history of criminal conviction for any of the crimes enumerated in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  If the chief of police finds that an applicant for one (1) of the named positions has a criminal history of conviction for one (1) of the crimes named in this section, the chief shall not divulge to the personnel officer or anyone else that such a finding has been made or any particulars thereof, but shall, based upon the requirements of this article, indicate to the personnel officer in writing that the particular applicant is not recommended for employment. Upon receiving such recommendation, the personnel officer shall eliminate the particular applicant from future consideration relative to the positions named in this section. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-58), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-80. - Residency policy. 
(a)  All successful applicants for position openings with the town for police chief, fire chief, director of electric utilities, and director of public works shall be required to live in such proximity to the town that they may, without exceeding a safe speed, be present and available for duty within twenty (20) minutes after notification except that the town manager may temporarily waive this requirement for individuals who are recruited from outside the said radius, provided such waiver shall not exceed a period of more than sixty (60) days from the applicant's beginning date of employment. 
(b)  Any person who is employed or promoted into the position of police chief, fire chief, director of electric utilities, and director of public works must reside in such proximity to the town that they may, without exceeding a safe speed, be present and available for duty within twenty (20) minutes after notification, except that the town manager may temporarily waive this requirement for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days from the employee's beginning date of employment in such position. 
(c)  All persons employed by the town in positions requiring on-call duty or emergency-call duty must reside in such proximity to the town that they may, without exceeding a safe speed, be present and available for duty within thirty (30) minutes after notification. Such persons shall also be required to have a telephone located within their residences to receive notifications of the town's needs. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-59), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 08-17, § 1, 12-8-08; Ord. No. 14-03, § 2, 4-14-14) 
Secs. 13-81-13-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT 

Sec. 13-96. - Probationary period-Generally. 
(a)  All new employees, promoted employees or employees who have been transferred to another position shall serve a probationary period of one (1) year. The employee may be dismissed, with the permission of the town manager, at any time during the probationary period that it is felt he is not satisfactorily performing the assigned duties of the position. 
(b)  A probationary employee whose work is unsatisfactory should normally receive a written warning before being terminated by his department head. The warning shall state in writing in what areas the employee is deficient and shall designate a reasonable period of time in which the employee must display satisfactory performance. Unsatisfactory performance during the designated period shall be grounds for termination. Except in unusual cases, the written warning shall be preceded by one (1) or more oral warnings or counseling sessions in order that the employee may be assisted in fulfilling the responsibilities of his position. Such oral warnings are not, however, a prerequisite to the written warning in all cases. 
(c)  Upon completion of six (6) months of service, the probationary employee shall receive an interim evaluation of his work, which will be conducted by the department head, but with no recommendation for a pay increase, and submitted to the town manager indicating: 
(1)  That the department head has discussed the employee's progress (accomplishments, strengths, failures, and weaknesses) with the employee; 
(2)  Whether the employee is performing satisfactory work; and 
(3)  Whether the employee should be retained for the remainder of his probationary period or whether he should be released, transferred or demoted. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-70), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-97. - Same-Benefits. 
(a)  New employees on probation shall receive all benefits provided under this chapter, but shall not be permitted to take vacation leave during the first six (6) months of their employment unless denial of such leave would create an unusual hardship. In such event, the town manager may grant leave at his discretion. 
(b)  Promoted employees serving a probationary period shall be entitled to receive all benefits provided under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-71), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-98. - Same-Terminal pay. 
    Any employee who is dismissed during the probationary period shall be eligible for terminal pay for any accumulated vacation leave. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-72), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-99. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 00-13, § 2, adopted June 19, 2000 repealed section 13-99 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to employment of relatives. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 13-100. - Overtime compensation and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). 
(a)  Employees of the town can be requested and may be required to work overtime hours as necessitated by the needs of the town and determined by the department head, with the prior approval of the manager. 
(b)  To the extent that local government jurisdictions are so required, the town will comply with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). The manager, following FLSA regulations, shall determine which jobs are nonexempt and are, therefore, subject to the Act in areas such as hours of work, work periods, rates of overtime compensation and other provisions. Nonexempt employees will be paid at a straight-time rate for hours up to the FLSA-established limit for their position, usually forty (40) hours in a seven-day period; hours for fire and police personnel may be different. Hours worked beyond the FLSA-established limit will be paid at the appropriate overtime rate, usually time-and-a-half the employee's regular rate. 
(c)  Wherever practicable, departments will schedule time off on an hour-for-hour basis within the applicable work period for nonexempt employees instead of paying overtime. When time off within the work period cannot be granted, overtime worked will be paid in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act or taken as compensatory time at a time-and-a-half rate. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-74), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-101. - Compensatory time for employees exempt from FLSA. 
    Employees in positions determined to be exempt from the Fair Labor Standards Act (as executive, administrative or professional staff) will not receive pay for hours worked in excess of their normal work periods. These employees may be granted compensatory leave by their department heads where the convenience of the department allows. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-75), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-102. - Emergency overtime. 
    During emergency conditions incident to hurricane or other disaster and during cleanup periods following the same, employees exempt from FLSA who ordinarily are given compensatory time may instead be paid for such overtime at their regular rate, upon approval of the town manager. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-76), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-103. - Outside employment. 
(a)  The work of the town shall have precedence over other occupational interests of employees. Outside employment for salary, wages or commissions must be reported to the town manager in order that he might determine if such employment is in conflict with the interests of the town. Continuation of conflicting outside employment may be grounds for disciplinary action. 
(b)  In granting permission to an employee to engage in outside employment, the town requires that the employee understand and agree that the work of the town shall take precedence over all other occupational interests of the employee and that the employee, while otherwise employed, shall be available to call and shall answer a call to duty on town work when and if the town shall make such a call. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-77), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-104. - Dual employment. 
    A full-time or part-time employee may simultaneously hold a temporary position, where the temporary position is in a different department or clearly different program area from that of the full-time or part-time position; however, the work of the full-time or part-time position shall take precedence over the temporary position. Such work will not count toward the calculation of overtime for pay or time off. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-78), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-105. - Demotion. 
    Any employee whose work is unsatisfactory or who becomes unable to perform the requirements of such position is subject to demotion or dismissal in accordance with the procedures outlined in this article; provided, however, that an employee showing promise of becoming a satisfactory employee in another position shall not be dismissed. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-79), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-106. - Transfer. 
    Any employee of the town may be transferred to another position in the same or in another department of the town if approved by the town manager. The employee shall not be denied any of the employee benefits that would be provided if the transfer had not occurred. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-80), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-107. - Right of appeal. 
    Any employee demoted or transferred for cause may appeal the action in accordance with the grievance procedure. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-81), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-108. - Acceptance of gifts and favors. 
    No official or employee of the town shall: 
(1)  Accept any gift, favor or thing of value that may tend to influence such employee in the discharge of the employee's duties; or 
(2)  Grant in the discharge of duty an improper favor, service or thing of value. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-82), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-109. - Town employee political activity. 
(a)  Purpose. 
(1)  The purpose of this section is to ensure that town employees are not subjected to political or partisan coercion while performing their job duties, to ensure that employees are not restricted from political activities while off duty, and to ensure that public funds are not used for political or partisan activities. 
(2)  It is not the purpose of this section to infringe upon the rights of employees to engage in free speech and free association. Every town employee has a civic responsibility to support good government by every available means and in every appropriate manner. Employees shall not be restricted from affiliating with civic organizations of a partisan or political nature, nor shall employees, while off duty, be restricted from attending political meetings, or advocating and supporting the principles or policies of civic or political organizations, or supporting partisan or nonpartisan candidates of their choice in accordance with the Constitution and laws of the state and the Constitution and laws of the United States of America. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section: 
On duty means that time period when an employee is engaged in the duties of his or her employment. 
Town employee or employee means any person employed by the town or any department or program thereof that is supported, in whole or in part, by town funds. 
Workplace means any place where an employee engages in his or her job duties. 
(c)  No employee while on duty or in the workplace may: 
(1)  Use his or her official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of an election or nomination for political office; or 
(2)  Coerce, solicit or compel contributions for political or partisan purposes by another employee. 
(d)  No employee may be required, as a duty of his or her office or employment or as a condition of employment, promotion, or tenure of office or employment, to contribute funds for political or partisan purposes. 
(e)  No employee may use town funds, supplies, or equipment for partisan purposes or for political purposes, except where such political uses are otherwise permitted by law. 
(f)  No employee may be a candidate for elective office under the Charter of the town. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-83), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 93-14, § 1, 9-13-93) 
Sec. 13-110. - Telephones. 
    Police and fire department personnel and all department heads shall have telephones in their residences. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-84), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-111. - Sexual harassment. 
(a)  The town opposes sexual harassment by supervisors and coworkers in any form. Sexual harassment is defined as unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature when: 
(1)  Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of an individual's employment, 
(2)  Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for employment decisions affecting such individual, or 
(3)  Such conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive working environment. 
(b)  Any employee who believes he or she may have a complaint of sexual harassment may file the complaint directly with the personnel director. The personnel director will conduct an investigation into any allegation of sexual harassment and advise the employee and appropriate management officials of the outcome of the investigation. 
(Ord. No. 91-5, § 1, 3-11-91) 
Sec. 13-112. - Alcohol and drug abuse. 
(a)  The abuse of alcohol and illegal drugs by employees of the town, while on duty or off, not only imperils the safety and well-being of town employees and the public, but the town government's ability to fulfill its responsibilities to the public as well. 
(b)  The abuse of alcohol or legal drugs or the use of illegal drugs by town employees which could in any way jeopardize the safety or welfare of the public or town employees is strictly prohibited. The town will take a very aggressive and vigorous approach to the management and enforcement of this policy within the following parameters: 
(1)  All employee applicants who are offered employment will be medically screened for use of controlled substances and their employment shall be precluded upon a positive finding as hereinafter set forth. 
(2)  All employees who are required by the department of transportation to hold commercial drivers' licenses in order to fulfill the requirements of their positions with the town shall be subject to all department of transportation regulations which apply and the town will adhere strictly to the enforcement and application of those regulations. Violation of those regulations will be grounds for termination. 
(3)  Drug and alcohol screening shall also be required for all employees in any situation in which an employee is found to be in possession of alcohol or controlled substances while on town property during working hours or when any employee comes under reasonable suspicion of being under the influence of alcohol or controlled substances. 
(4)  Alcohol and drug screenings which result in concentrations in excess of the following limits will cause the positively tested employee to be subject to immediate termination: 
Alcohol concentration 0.02 Amphetamines 1,000 ng/ml Cocaine metabolites 300 ng/ml Phencyclidine (PCP) 25 ng/ml Opiate metabolites 2,000 ng/ml Marijuana metabolites 50 ng/ml  
(c)  All town screening procedures for employees required by the department of transportation to hold commercial driver's licenses in order to fulfill the requirements of their positions with the town shall be conducted in accordance with U.S. Department of Transportation regulations, CFR Title 49, Parts 382 and 40. 
(Ord. No. 95-12, § 1, 7-10-95; Ord. No. 95-17, § 1, 9-11-95; Ord. No. 97-15, §§ 1, 2, 9-8-97; Ord. No. 99-8, §§ 1, 2, 6-14-99) 
Sec. 13-113. - Annual motor vehicle record check. 
    All permanent employees (full-time and part-time) will receive an annual motor vehicle record check on the employee's anniversary date to verify that all town employees who are required to have a valid North Carolina driver's license are driving town vehicles legally. If the record check reveals that an employee's license is inactive, the employee will be terminated. 
(Ord. No. 08-03, § 1, 1-14-08) 
Secs. 13-114-13-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 

Sec. 13-131. - Eligibility. 
    All full-time and part-time employees of the town and others as specifically provided in this chapter shall be eligible for employee benefits provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-90), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-132. - Group health and hospitalization insurance. 
(a)  The town will provide full-time and part-time employees with group hospitalization insurance including family coverage. The town will bear the full cost of full-time employee coverage and a proportionate amount of the cost for part-time employees. Family coverage costs will be paid by the employee through payroll deduction. 
(b)  The health insurance coverage shall also be available to those retirees of the town who have a minimum of twenty (20) years of service under the North Carolina Local Government Employees Retirement System and who are under the age of sixty-five (65), with the town bearing a portion of the cost which shall not exceed the amount paid for full-time employees. 
(c)  Medicare supplement insurance shall be provided to those town retirees over the age of sixty-five (65), who have a minimum of twenty (20) years of service under the North Carolina Local Government Employees Retirement System, with the town bearing a portion of the cost which shall not exceed the amount paid for full-time employees. 
(d)  Subsections (b) and (c) above, shall not apply to any employee hired after August 1, 2011.* 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-91), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 90-18, § 1(19-91), 6-4-90; Ord. No. 91-10, § 1, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 96-9, § 1, 6-10-96; Ord. No. 96-19, § 1, 10-14-96; Ord. No. 11-01, § 1, 3-14-11; Ord. No. 11-08, § 1, 8-8-11) 
*Section 2 of Ordinance No. 11-01, adopted March 14, 2011, states this subsection shall become effective August 2, 2011. 
Sec. 13-133. - Continuation of coverage. 
    Any employee who, by reason of extended illness, has exhausted his leave and is in unpaid status will have his membership in the town's group insurance carried at the town's expense for one (1) month for each year of service with the town, up to a maximum of six (6) months, except that part-time employees shall pay a proportionate share of the cost as during employment. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-92), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-134. - Group life insurance. 
    The town will provide group life insurance to all full-time employees free of charge. Employees may elect to insure other members of their family under this plan at their expense. The same coverage will be available to part-time employees on a pro rata cost basis in accordance with the factor chart used for annual leave in article VII of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-93), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-135. - State retirement system. 
    Each employee who is expected to work for the town more than one thousand (1,000) hours annually shall join the North Carolina Local Governmental Employees' Retirement System as a condition of employment. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-94), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-136. - Worker's compensation. 
(a)  All full-time, part-time and temporary employees of the town are covered by state worker's compensation and are required to report all injuries arising out of and in the course of employment to their immediate supervisor at the time of the injury in order that appropriate action may be taken at once. 
(b)  Responsibility for claiming compensation under the Worker's Compensation Act is on the injured employee, and such claim must be filed by the employee with the state industrial commission within two (2) years from date of injury. The supervisor or personnel office will assist the employee in filing a claim. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-95), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-137. - Worker's compensation leave. 
    An employee absent from duty because of sickness or disability covered by the worker's compensation laws shall be eligible to receive a town-paid worker's compensation salary supplement for the first week of each such disability. 
(1)  The employee shall receive an amount up to his full salary for the first week of disability, as certified by the attending physician, without charge to vacation or sick leave. 
(2)  At regular intervals, the employee's physician shall advise the town of the employee's physical status and ability to return to work. 
When the Town of Tarboro's Workers' Compensation Insurance Carrier, upon physician's recommendation, releases the employee back to work with modified or light duty stipulations, the town will place the employee in a position to accommodate those requirements. The supervisor of that position and the employee will go over the modified or light duty requirements together so that both parties will follow the physician's specified limitations for the employee. 
(3)  Following an absence of one (1) year, employment may be terminated, unless there is clear indication that the employee will be able to be reinstated in the near future. 
(4)  The employee will have the option, if he so chooses, to use accrued sick or vacation leave in lieu of receiving worker's compensation disability benefits. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-96), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 1-14-08) 
Sec. 13-138. - Tax-deferred savings program. 
    The town may offer a program of deferred compensation qualifying as such under the Internal Revenue Code as an optional benefit to town employees. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-97), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-139. - Longevity pay. 
(a)  A program of longevity pay may be provided to recognize the length of service of town employees. The annual payment will be made in December to those full-time and part-time employees who are on the last payroll in November and who have completed the required number of years of service as of November 1 of the year the payment is made. 
Length of Service Percent 
of Payment More than five (5) and less than ten (10) years 2 More than ten (10) and less than fifteen (15) years 3 Fifteen (15) years and over 4  
(b)  Payment to part-time employees shall be on a proportional basis according to the number of hours normally scheduled to be worked by the employee. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-98), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-140. - Payment for completion of degrees. 
    Upon prior approval of the department head and the town manager, an employee who successfully completes the requirements for one (1) of the following degrees, in a field of education directly relating to the employee's job, during his or her employment with the town, as evidenced by a transcript with a "C" average or better and a diploma, will be rewarded with a one-time payment as follows:

(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-99), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 88-40, § 1, 7-11-88) 
Secs. 13-141-13-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - HOLIDAYS AND LEAVES OF ABSENCE 

Sec. 13-161. - Policy. 
    The policy of the town is to provide annual leave, sick leave and holiday leave to all full-time and part-time employees and to provide proportionately equivalent amounts to employees having average workweeks of different lengths. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-106), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-162. - Annual leave-Rate. 
(a)  Each full-time employee of the town, except fire personnel on shift schedules and part-time employees, shall accumulate annual leave at the rate of between ten (10) and twenty (20) days per year, depending upon years of town service, as follows: 
(1)  Hiring through three (3) years: Ten (10) eight-hour days; 
(2)  Three (3) through ten (10) years: Twelve (12) eight-hour days per year; 
(3)  Ten (10) through twenty (20) years: Fifteen (15) eight-hour days per year; 
(4)  Twenty (20) through twenty-five (25) years: Eighteen (18) eight-hour days per year; 
(5)  Twenty-five (25) plus years: Twenty (20) eight-hour days per year. 
(b)  Firefighters on a twenty-four-hour shift schedule shall accumulate annual leave as follows: 
(1)  Hiring through three (3) years: Five (5) twenty-four-hour days; 
(2)  Three (3) through ten (10) years: Six (6) twenty-four-hour days; 
(3)  Ten (10) through twenty (20) years: Seven and five-tenths (7.5) twenty-four-hour days; 
(4)  Twenty (20) through twenty-five (25) years: Nine (9) twenty-four-hour days; 
(5)  Twenty-five (25) plus years: Ten (10) twenty-four-hour days. 
(c)  Part-time employees shall earn vacation leave on a proportionate basis according to the number of hours normally scheduled to be worked in a workweek divided by forty (40) hours. The following part-time employee benefit factor chart provides the multiplier: 
Hours Scheduled 
Per Week Factor of Multiplier 20 0.500 21 0.525 22 0.550 23 0.575 24 0.600 25 0.625 26 0.650 27 0.675 28 0.700 29 0.725 30 0.750 31 0.775 32 0.800 33 0.825 34 0.850 35 0.875 36 0.900 37 0.925 38 0.950 39 0.975  
Leave may be taken in amounts of fifteen-minute increments for the time missed. 
(d)  An employee shall be permitted to take five (5) days of vacation, three (3) twenty-four-hour days of vacation in the case of firefighters, after successfully completing six (6) months of service. 
(e)  After successfully completing six (6) months of service, part-time employees shall be permitted to take a proportionate amount of vacation according to the number of hours the employee works in a workweek. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-107), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 88-46, § 1, 10-10-88; Ord. No. 99-7, § 1, 6-14-99) 
Sec. 13-163. - Same-Accumulation. 
    Leave shall begin to accrue during the first calendar month or fraction thereof that an employee works without being prorated for the number of days worked during the first partial month. For an employee who ends service with the town, leave shall cease to accrue with the last full calendar month worked without being prorated for the number of days worked during the last partial month worked. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-108), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 89-25, § 1, 11-13-89) 
Sec. 13-164. - Same-Schedule for taking. 
    Employees shall be granted the use of earned annual leave at those times designated by the manager or department head which will least obstruct normal operations of the town. Probationary employees will be allowed the use of such leave in accordance with article V of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-109), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-165. - Same-Maximum accumulation. 
    For employees hired on or before July 1, 2000 -No more than four hundred eighty (480) hours of vacation leave may be carried over from calendar year to calendar year, except that firefighter personnel on shift schedules may carry over six hundred eighty (680) hours from calendar year to calendar year. Any hours remaining in excess of four hundred eighty (480), or six hundred eighty (680) hours in the case of firefighter personnel, shall be credited to sick leave. 
    For employees hired after July 1, 2000 -No more than two hundred forty (240) hours of vacation leave may be carried over from calendar year to calendar year except that firefighter personnel on shift schedules may carry over three hundred forty (340) hours from calendar year to calendar year. Any hours remaining in excess of two hundred forty (240), or three hundred forty (340) hours in the case of firefighter personnel, shall be credited to sick leave. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-110), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 91-13, § 1, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 93-12, § 1, 6-7-93; Ord. No. 00-25, § 1, 8-14-00) 
Editor's note- The provisions of § 13-165 shall be effective July 1, 2000. 
Sec. 13-166. - Same-Payment of accumulated leave upon termination. 
    A permanent employee shall be paid for annual leave accumulated to the date of separation, not to exceed thirty (30) days, provided notice is given to the immediate supervisor at least two (2) weeks in advance of the effective date of resignation. The manager and department heads shall be required to give thirty (30) days' notice prior to the effective date of resignation. Any employee failing to give the notice required by this section shall forfeit payment for accumulated leave. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-111), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-167. - Same-Payment of accumulated leave upon death. 
    If a permanent employee dies while in the service of the town, all unused annual leave and accumulated holiday leave in the deceased employee's credit will be issued with the final paycheck. An employee may name an agent to receive personal property items and the final paycheck in the event of the employee's death. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-112), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-168. - Same-Conversion to cash for educational purposes. 
    An employee of the town who desires to take an educational course which will improve the employee's knowledge and capabilities for his work with the town and who is utilizing out-of-hours time and at his own expense for the training may use some annual leave for this purpose. With the approval of the town manager, the employee may draw cash in lieu of accumulated vacation leave in an amount not to exceed the equivalent of twelve (12) days' vacation leave. In all cases the vacation leave must have already been accumulated and the payment check shall be made jointly to the employee and the educational institution involved. This shall only apply where the course taken requires payment of money by the employee for payment to the institution involved and will not be allowed where the course is free. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-113), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-169. - Holidays designated. 
(a)  The following are designated as holidays with pay for all full-time and part-time employees of the town. Paid holiday leave shall not be provided to temporary employees. When a single holiday falls on a Saturday, the preceding Friday shall be observed; or if on a Sunday, the following Monday shall be observed as a holiday: 
New Year's Day 
Martin Luther King, Jr. Day 
Good Friday 
Memorial Day 
July 4 
Labor Day 
Veteran's Day 
Thanksgiving (Thursday and Friday) 
Christmas 
(b)  When Christmas falls on the day designated below, the corresponding days shall be observed as holidays: 
Christmas 
   Day 
Falling On Work Days Off Sunday Friday and Monday Monday Monday and Tuesday Tuesday Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday Wednesday Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday Thursday Wednesday, Thursday and Friday Friday Thursday and Friday Saturday Friday and Monday  
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-113), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 94-14, § 1, 12-12-94) 
Sec. 13-170. - Effect of holidays, weekends. 
    Designated town holidays, Saturdays and/or Sundays which may fall or occur during an annual, sick or other leave period of an employee of the town shall not be considered as annual, sick or other leave. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-115), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-171. - Compensation or time off for working holidays. 
    An employee of the town required to work on any designated holiday shall receive compensation at the regular rate and shall be entitled to an equal number of hours off selected with the approval of the supervisor or, at the supervisor's election, shall be entitled to compensation for such day at double the normal rate in lieu of time off. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-116), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-172. - Religious holidays. 
    An employee of the town desiring to observe a religious holiday other than those designated shall be permitted to do so. Any such employee shall advise his immediate supervisor of this desire at least one (1) week in advance of the date and the employee's work schedule shall be adjusted accordingly to permit such observance. The employee shall not be paid for such day off, but may elect to use accrued vacation leave. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-117), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-173. - Sick leave policy. 
(a)  Sick leave with pay shall not be a right which an employee may demand, but a privilege granted to such employee for the benefit of the employee when certain conditions are met. 
(b)  Sick leave with pay shall be granted to an employee when sick or for illness in the employee's immediate family which requires the care of the employee. Sick leave may be used if an employee must be absent from work due to any of the following conditions: Sickness, bodily injury, quarantine, required physical or dental examinations or treatment and exposure to a contagious disease when continuing work might jeopardize the health of others. 
(c)  For a major or terminal illness in the employee's immediate family necessitating the presence at home for longer than three (3) days, the town manager may in his discretion authorize additional leave charged to the employee's accumulated sick leave. 
(d)  Notification of the desire to take sick leave should be submitted to the employee's supervisor one (1) hour prior to reporting time. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-118), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-174. - Reinstatement and rehiring. 
(a)  An employee of the town who is on educational, maternity, sick or other authorized leave shall be reinstated to the former position or one comparable in seniority, status and salary if such employee returns to town service at the expiration of such leave or authorized extension thereof. An employee who fails to return within the required time shall be treated as an applicant for employment with the town. 
(b)  An employee called to extended active duty with the United States military forces who does not volunteer for service beyond the period for which called shall be reinstated provided: 
(1)  He applied for reinstatement within ninety (90) days of his release from military service; and 
(2)  He still is able to perform the duties of his former position or a similar position; or 
(3)  If he is unable to perform the duties of his former position or a similar position due to disability sustained as a result of military service but is able to perform the duties of another position in the service of the town, he shall be employed in such other position as will provide the nearest approximation of the seniority, status and pay which he otherwise would have been provided. 
(c)  An employee who resigns while in good standing may be rehired with the approval of the town manager and shall be regarded as a new employee, subject to all of the provisions of rules and regulations of this chapter. 
(d)  An employee in good standing who is terminated due to a reduction in force shall be given the first opportunity to be rehired in the same or a similar position. These employees will have their sick leave credits reinstated. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-119), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-175. - Sick leave rate and accumulation. 
(a)  Each full-time and part-time employee shall accumulate sick leave at the rate of twelve (12) days per year. Fire personnel on a shift schedule shall earn six (6) twenty-four-hour days or one hundred forty-four (144) hours off annually. No sick leave shall be taken in excess of that earned. 
(b)  Sick leave shall be cumulative with no maximum accumulation. 
(c)  Leave shall accrue pro rata effective on the pay issue date. Employees who begin work or leave service during the pay period shall accrue leave prorated to the days worked. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-120), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-176. - Physical standards. 
    Employees may be required to maintain specified levels of fitness appropriate to the physical requirements of their jobs. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-121), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-177. - Medical examination and physician's certification. 
(a)  Prospective or current employees may be required to submit to a medical examination or inquiry if the manager deems desirable. 
(b)  The manager or department head may require a physician's certificate stating the nature of an employee's illness or injury and the employee's physical capacity to perform the duties of the job. Certificates may be required for each occasion on which an employee uses sick leave. 
(c)  The manager or department head shall be responsible for the application of these provisions to the end that: 
(1)  Employees shall not be on duty when they might endanger their health or the health of other employees; and 
(2)  Sick leave privileges are used only for authorized purposes. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-122), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-178. - Sick leave abuse. 
    Claiming or taking sick leave under false pretense to obtain a day off with pay shall subject the employee to disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-123), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-179. - Effects of termination upon sick leave. 
    All sick leave accumulated by an employee shall end and terminate without compensation when the employee retires, resigns or is terminated by the town, except as provided in this chapter for employees terminated due to reduction in force. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-124), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-180. - Maternity leave-Generally. 
    Maternity leave may be granted to an employee for a period of up to twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-125), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-181. - Same-Request. 
    A maternity leave request, including the tentative duration of the leave requested, must be submitted to the manager in advance of the leave. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-126), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-182. - Compliance with the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. 
    An employee of the town who has worked for the town for at least a total of twelve (12) months and at least twelve hundred fifty (1,250) hours during that period shall be allowed to take up to twelve (12) calendar weeks of leave for any of the following reasons: The birth of a child or the placement of a foster or adoptive child; to care for a spouse, child or parent who has a serious health condition; or to take personal medical leave when unable to work because of a serious health condition. 
(1)  No more than one (1) twelve-week leave may be taken in a twelve-month period, except by permission of the town manager. The inception of that twelve-month period shall begin with the first day of such leave. 
(2)  "Serious medical condition" is defined as an illness, injury, physical impairment or mental condition involving inpatient care in a hospital, residential medical care facility, or continuing treatment by a health care provider requiring an absence of more than three (3) days from work, school or other regular daily activities and does not include minor illnesses of short duration. 
(3)  In cases where the need for leave is foreseeable, such as expected birth or planned medical treatment, the employee is required to give the town thirty (30) days' notice or as much notice as is practicable and to make every effort to schedule planned medical treatment in such a manner that the town's operations will not be unduly disrupted. 
(4)  Under some circumstances, leave may be taken intermittently or in blocks of time, or by reducing the employee's normal weekly or daily schedule, when it is medically necessary to care for a seriously ill family member (spouse, child or parent) or because the employee is seriously ill and unable to work. Use of intermittent leave for birth or placement of a child for foster care or adoption shall be subject to approval by the town manager. 
(5)  The use of accrued sick or vacation leave for purposes of compensation during the leave shall normally be at the option of the employee, who shall notify the town of such election prior to the inception of the leave. The town does, however, reserve the option of requiring the use of accrued vacation or sick leave if it so chooses. 
(6)  An employee who requests leave under the provisions of this section because of his or her medical condition or the medical condition of a family member shall provide verification of medical necessity by the attending physician prior to the inception of the leave and at any other time during the leave, as requested by the town. Such verification shall include the date the condition began; the probable duration of the condition; appropriate medical facts as known by the physician with respect to the condition; and any additional data the town may require if the leave is to be of an intermittent nature. The town may, at its option and expense, require a second medical opinion and, if the second opinion conflicts with that of the attending physician, a third may be required. The third opinion shall be binding both on the employee and the town. 
(7)  All medical, dental and life insurance benefits normally provided by the town for the employees' benefit shall be continued at the town's expense during the course of the leave. Any expenses for optional life, medical or dental insurance which are normally borne by the employee shall be paid by the employee on a scheduled monthly basis. 
(8)  Upon returning from leave, as required by this section, the employee will be restored to his or her job or placed in an equivalent job with equivalent pay, benefits and all other terms and conditions of employment. An employee who is identified as a "key" employee, i.e., one who is salaried and among the highest paid ten (10) percent of all employees, may be denied restoration to employment after return from leave. Such denial can occur only if necessary to prevent substantial and grievous economic harm to the operations of the town. 
(9)  The provisions of this section are in no way to be construed in a manner which will deprive the employee of any other privileges or benefits which may be provided for elsewhere. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-127), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 93-13, § 1, 8-9-93) 
Sec. 13-183. - Maintaining benefits during maternity leave. 
    During the period of leave without pay, the employee shall retain all accumulated unused sick leave, annual leave and retirement status earned. The employee taking paid leave will continue to earn sick and annual leave during that period. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-128), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-184. - Leave without pay. 
    With approval of the manager, an employee may be granted a leave of absence without pay for a period not to exceed one (1) year for reasons of personal or family illness, completion of education or special work which will permit the town to profit from the experience gained or the work performed. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-129), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-185. - Military leave. 
    An employee who is a member of an Armed Forces Reserve organization or the National Guard shall be granted two (2) calendar weeks per year of leave with pay for military training. While on military leave, benefits will accrue as though present for duty. This leave is not charged as annual leave; however, any salary payment which the employee receives from the military shall be deducted from the sum paid by the town. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-130), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-186. - Civil leave. 
    An employee called for jury duty or as a court witness for the federal or state government or a subdivision thereof, by subpoena, shall be entitled to leave with pay for such duty in addition to keeping fees received for such duty, provided documentation is made for each day. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-131), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-187. - Educational leave. 
    Educational leave at full or part pay may be granted to an employee with the approval of the town manager, upon recommendation of the department head, to permit a town employee to take courses of study which will better equip the employee to perform his duties for the town. The employee may be required to enter into a formal contract with the town in which the employee agrees to return to the service of the town upon completion of the training and remain an employee of the town for a period equal to twice the educational leave which the employee received or reimburse the town for all compensation received while on educational leave. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-132), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-188. - Leave without pay; effect on merit increase eligibility. 
    An employee's merit increase eligibility will be delayed if the employee is on leave without pay for more than half of the period for which work is being evaluated. Procedures for establishing eligibility for merit increases shall be published in policies developed by the manager. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-133), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-189. - Petty leave. 
(a)  After one (1) year of employment, employees of the town may be allowed fourteen (14) hours per year petty leave over and above sick leave or vacation with pay. Petty leave may be granted for personal matters which cannot be transacted outside of office hours, medical appointments and absences due to adverse weather conditions. 
(b)  No more than two (2) hours nor less than fifteen (15) minutes of petty leave may be taken at any time. Any time taken above this will be charged to vacation or sick leave or leave without pay, as may be appropriate. Petty leave shall be in addition to any other leave which an employee may earn and accumulate, but shall not be cumulative from year to year. 
(c)  Part-time employees may also be allowed a proportional number of hours of petty leave over and above sick leave or vacation with pay, according to the number of hours normally scheduled to be worked by that employee in a workweek divided by forty (40) hours as provided in section 13-162(c). 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-134), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-190. - Bereavement leave. 
(a)  An employee may be granted up to three (3) days of bereavement leave in the event of death in the immediate family upon approval of the department head. Additional days may be granted at the discretion and upon approval of the town manager. Such leave shall be chargeable to accrued sick leave. 
(b)  Immediate family, for purposes of this section, is defined as wife, husband, sister, brother, child, grandchild, father, mother, grandfather, grandmother and any half, step, adoptive or in-law relationships. 
(Ord. No. 88-47, § 1(19-135), 10-10-88) 
Secs. 13-191-13-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - TRAVEL 

Sec. 13-211. - Travel, entertainment and living expenses. 
    Expenses incurred by town personnel in the course of conducting town business for authorized travel, entertainment and living expenses may be advanced, reimbursed and reviewed in accordance with town policies as they may be amended from time to time by the town council. For purposes of this section, the term "town personnel" includes elected and appointed town officers and employees. 
(Ord. No. 99-16, § 1, 8-9-99) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 99-16, adopted Aug. 9, 1999, repealed §§ 13-211 and 13-213 in their entirety and reenacted § 13-211 as here in set out. Formerly, §§ 13-211 and 13-213 pertained to the traveling policy and reimbursement of expenses and derived from § 1(19-34), (19-145) of Ord. No. 88-34, adopted June 13, 1988 and § 1 of Ord. No. 91-12, adopted June 10, 1991. 
Sec. 13-212. - Town vehicles. 
(a)  Vehicles owned by the town will be provided certain personnel for town business only. Vehicles shall not be used for personal purposes. If a town vehicle is involved in an accident either on public or private property, the department head and the manager shall be notified immediately. 
(b)  Personal vehicles shall be used only when authorized by the town manager and for town business. Travel expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with the town travel policy. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-146), 6-13-88) 
Secs. 13-213-13-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - SEPARATION 

Sec. 13-236. - Types of separation. 
    All separations of employees from positions in the service of the town shall be designated as one (1) of the following types and shall be accomplished in the manner indicated in this article: Resignation, layoff, disability, voluntary retirement, termination or death. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-151), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-237. - Resignation. 
(a)  An employee may resign by submitting in writing the reasons for resignation and the effective date to the employee's immediate supervisor as far in advance as possible. But in all instances the minimum notice requirements as set forth in this chapter shall apply. 
(b)  Three (3) consecutive days of absence without reporting in may be considered to be a resignation. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-152), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-238. - Layoff. 
    An employee may be laid off when a reduction in force becomes necessary. In determining which employee or employees will be laid off, consideration shall be given to the quality of each employee's past performance and the needs of the town, in addition to seniority. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-153), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-239. - Disability. 
    An employee who cannot perform his duties because of physical or mental impairment may be separated for that disability. Action may be initiated by the employee or the town, but in all cases must be substantiated by medical evidence which is acceptable to the town manager. The town may require an examination at its expense by a physician of its choice. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-154), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-240. - Retirement. 
    An employee who meets the conditions set forth under the provisions of the North Carolina Local Government Employees' Retirement System may elect to retire and receive all benefits earned under the retirement plan. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-155), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-241. - Termination. 
    An employee may be involuntarily terminated in accordance with the provisions and procedures of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-156), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-242. - Death. 
    Separation shall be effective as of the date of death. All compensation due shall be paid in accordance with the provisions of article VII of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-157), 6-13-88) 
Secs. 13-243-13-265. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - UNSATISFACTORY JOB PERFORMANCE AND DETRIMENTAL PERSONAL CONDUCT 

Sec. 13-266. - Unsatisfactory job performance defined. 
(a)  Unsatisfactory job performance includes any aspects of the employee's job which are not performed as required to meet the standards set by the department head and the manager. A permanent employee may be suspended, demoted or terminated for unsatisfactory job performance by the manager or by a department head if after following the procedures outlined in section 13-267 the employee's job performance is still deemed to be unsatisfactory. 
(b)  All cases of demotion or termination must be approved by the manager prior to giving final notice to the employee. 
(c)  Unsatisfactory job performance may be handled through the performance evaluation process and/or through the disciplinary process. 
(d)  Examples of unsatisfactory job performance include but are not limited to: 
(1)  Inability to adequately perform critical tasks; 
(2)  Physical or mental incapacity to perform duties, as certified by a physician; 
(3)  Inability to meet work standards over a period of time; 
(4)  Failure to complete work within time frames established in work plans or work standards; 
(5)  Demonstrated inefficiency, negligence or incompetence in the performance of duties; 
(6)  Careless, negligent or improper use of town property or equipment; 
(7)  Discourteous treatment of the public or other employees; 
(8)  Insubordination; 
(9)  Absence without approved leave; 
(10)  Habitual improper use of leave privileges; 
(11)  Habitual pattern of failure to report for duty at the assigned time and place; 
(12)  Reporting to work under the influence of alcohol or drugs or partaking of such while on duty. Prescribed medication may be taken within the limits set by a physician as long as medically necessary. 
(13)  Violations of the General Statutes of the State of North Carolina relating to the operation of motor vehicles, while in the course of town employment, specifically including but not limited to the use of shoulder and seat belt restraints. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-165), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 91-16, § 1, 10-14-91) 
Sec. 13-267. - Communication and warning procedures preceding termination for unsatisfactory job performance. 
(a)  Where an employee's job performance has been unsatisfactory over a period of time or because of incidents or inappropriate actions warranting disciplinary action, one (1) or more counseling discussions between the employee and the supervisor to discuss specific performance problems should be held. If performance continues to be unsatisfactory, disciplinary action may occur after appropriate notification including the following: 
(1)  A written warning from the supervisor which explains the nature of the unsatisfactory job performance; 
(2)  A final written warning from the supervisor serving notice upon the employee that corrected performance must take place immediately in order to avoid demotion or termination; 
(3)  Recommendation to the manager for disciplinary action such as suspension, demotion or discharge. Employees must be given the chance to explain or defend their actions before termination is recommended. 
(b)  In each case the supervisor shall record the dates of discussions with the employee, the performance deficiencies discussed, the corrective actions recommended and the time limits set. 
(c)  When serious incidents of unsatisfactory job performance occur, suspension, termination or other disciplinary action may occur without prior warning. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-166), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-268. - Detrimental personal conduct defined. 
    Detrimental personal conduct includes behavior of such a serious detrimental nature that the functioning of the town may be impaired, the safety of persons or property may be threatened or the laws of the government may be violated. Examples include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Fraud; 
(2)  Conviction of a felony or the entry of a plea of nolo contendere thereto; 
(3)  Falsification of records for personal profit or to grant special privileges; 
(4)  Willful misuse of town funds; 
(5)  Willful and wanton damage or destruction of property; 
(6)  Willful and wanton acts that endanger the lives and property of others; 
(7)  Possession of unauthorized firearms or other lethal weapons on the job; 
(8)  Brutality in the performance of duties; 
(9)  Engaging in incompatible employment or servicing a conflicting interest; 
(10)  Acceptance of gifts in exchange for favors or influence; 
(11)  Engaging in political activity prohibited by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-167), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-269. - Disciplinary action for detrimental personal conduct. 
(a)  An employee may be suspended or dismissed by his department head or by the town manager without warning for causes relating to personal conduct detrimental to town service and may be discharged for such conduct with the approval of the town manager: 
(1)  In order to avoid undue disruption of work; 
(2)  To protect the safety of persons or property; or 
(3)  For other serious reasons. 
In less serious or disruptive situations, steps similar to those listed under section 13-267 may be in order. 
(b)  When an employee is suspended or dismissed immediately, he shall be told to leave town property at once and either to report to his supervisor at a specific time or to remain away until further notice. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-168), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-270. - Nondisciplinary suspension. 
(a)  During the investigation, hearing or trial of an employee on any criminal charge or during an investigation related to alleged detrimental personal conduct or during the course of any civil action involving an employee when suspension would, in the opinion of the manager, be in the best interest of the town, the manager may suspend the employee for the duration of the proceedings as a nondisciplinary action. In such cases, the manager may: 
(1)  Relieve the employee temporarily of all duties and responsibilities and allow the employee no compensation for the period of the suspension; or 
(2)  Assign the employee new duties and responsibilities and allow the employee to receive such compensation as is in keeping with the new duties and responsibilities. 
(b)  If the employee is reinstated following the suspension, such employee shall not lose any benefits to which otherwise the employee would have been entitled had the suspension not occurred. If the employee is to terminate following suspension, the employee shall not be eligible for any pay from the date of suspension; provided, however, all other benefits with the exception of accrued annual leave and sick leave shall be maintained during the period of suspension. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-169), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-271. - Notification of disciplinary action for detrimental conduct. 
    When an employee is suspended, demoted or terminated for detrimental personal conduct, the manager shall immediately provide the employee with written notice of the action taken, the effective date, the reasons for the action and the recourse available to the employee under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-170), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-272. - Employee appeal. 
    Any employee who is disciplined may appeal the disciplinary action in accordance with the grievance procedure, save that an employee who is suspended, demoted or transferred for cause as a disciplinary action or terminated shall have fifteen (15) days from written notice of the disciplinary action to appeal. A decision to rescind a demotion or termination must be approved by the town manager before becoming effective. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-171), 6-13-88) 
Secs. 13-273-13-295. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE 

Sec. 13-296. - Policy. 
    It is the policy of the town to provide a just and prompt procedure for the presentation, consideration and disposition of employee grievances as set forth in this article. The purpose of this article is to outline the procedure and to assure all employees that a response to their complaints and grievances will be prompt and fair. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-180), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-297. - Grievance defined. 
    "Grievance" means any matter of employee concern or dissatisfaction within the control of the town. Examples of problems for which grievances may be filed include the following: 
(1)  Safety or health matters; 
(2)  Unsatisfactory physical facilities, surroundings, materials or equipment; 
(3)  Alleged unfair or discriminatory disciplinary or supervisory practices; 
(4)  Alleged unjust treatment by fellow workers; 
(5)  Unreasonable work quotas; 
(6)  Sexual harassment as defined in section 13-111 of this Code; 
(7)  Any other grievance related to conditions of employment. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-181), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 91-5, § 2, 3-11-91) 
Sec. 13-298. - Purposes. 
    The purposes of the grievance procedure include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Providing employees with a procedure by which their complaints can be considered promptly, fairly and without reprisal; 
(2)  Encouraging employees to express themselves about the conditions of work which affect them as employees; 
(3)  Promoting better understanding of policies, practices and procedures which affect employees; 
(4)  Increasing the confidence that employees have that personnel decisions are in accord with established, fair and uniform policies and procedures; and 
(5)  Increasing the sense of responsibility which supervisors exercise in dealing with their employees. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-182), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-299. - Procedure. 
(a)  Generally. The following steps shall be followed in all employee grievances except that if the employee alleges sexual harassment, the employee may file the complaint or grievance directly with the personnel director, as set forth in section 13-111 of this Code. All grievances must be in writing and all documents used in the procedure must be dated and signed by the respondent and the recipient. Time limits at every step may be extended by mutual consent. Prior to the first formal step of the grievance procedure, it is required that employee and supervisor meet to discuss the problem and seek to resolve it informally. This meeting should be scheduled by the employee considering filing a grievance with his supervisor within five (5) working days of the incident or action giving rise to the problem. Ongoing conditions are not subject to this deadline. At any stage, the employee may request the assistance of the personnel office in accurately writing the grievance. At each stage, the employee shall sign a copy of the decision or determination to acknowledge receipt and the date of the response. 
(b)  Step 1. If the informal meeting does not resolve the problem, the employee may file a written grievance within five (5) working days of the meeting. Ordinarily, the supervisor will respond, in writing, within five (5) days of receipt of the written grievance. In some cases, the supervisor may feel that a second meeting would be constructive. If so, the supervisor will schedule a meeting with the employee within five (5) working days of receiving the written grievance, will thoroughly investigate the matter and will render a written decision on the grievance within five (5) days of the meeting. The supervisor and division head, if appropriate, should and are encouraged to consult with any town employee or officer they may deem necessary to reach a correct, impartial, fair and equitable determination or decision concerning the grievance. 
(c)  Step 2. If the employee is not satisfied with the Step 1 decision and if the department head was not involved in Step 1, the employee may file an appeal with the department head within five (5) days following receipt of the Step 1 decision. The department head shall, within five (5) days, set a date for a meeting which shall be held within a reasonable period of time. The meeting is for the purpose of discussing the grievance fully. The department head will render a written decision on the grievance within five (5) days of the meeting. 
(d)  Step 3. If the employee is not satisfied with the Step 2 decision, the employee may file an appeal with the manager within five (5) days following receipt of the Step 2 decision. The manager will schedule a meeting with the employee to discuss the grievance fully, and render a decision on the grievance within ten (10) days of the meeting. The decision of the manager will be final. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-183), 6-13-88; Ord. No. 91-5, § 3, 3-11-91) 
Sec. 13-300. - Representation. 
    In the presentation of any grievance under this chapter, any employee may be represented by any person of the employee's choice, with the exception of an attorney, including another employee of the town; provided that no employee shall be represented in a grievance under this chapter by a supervisor in the same department as the employee bringing the grievance. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-184), 6-13-88) 
Sec. 13-301. - Conflict with policies, provisions, etc. 
    No decision or determination of any grievance shall in any way conflict with the town policies, resolutions, ordinances or statutes applicable thereto. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 1(19-185), 6-13-88) 
Chapter 14 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Police, Art. 10. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; nuisances, Ch. 10; offenses, Ch. 11; personnel, Ch. 13; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 16; traffic, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Delegation and exercise of the general police power, G.S. § 160A-174 et seq.; authority to appoint a chief of police and employ police officers, G.S. § 160A-281. 

Sec. 14-1. - Chief of police. 
(a)  Head of department. The chief of police is designated the head of the town's police department, as the term is used in G.S. section 160A-288, and is delegated the authority to make or grant requests pursuant to this statute. 
(b)  Entering into agreements. In accordance with the provisions of G.S. section 160A-288, the police chief is authorized to enter into agreements for exchanging law enforcement officers, equipment or supplies. 
(c)  Administration of department. The chief of police, subject to the direction of the town manager, shall have charge of the police force. He shall assign such duties to the police officers as he thinks best for the good order of the town, and he shall be responsible to the town manager in seeing to it that the police officers faithfully perform their duties. 
(d)  Duties generally. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to: 
(1)  Supervise the police department; 
(2)  When directed by the town manager, organize, train and supervise an auxiliary or reserve police department made up of volunteer members; 
(3)  Preserve the peace by suppressing all disturbances and by apprehending all offenders; 
(4)  Assign such duties to the police officers as he deems best for the welfare of the town; 
(5)  Carry out such further duties as may be assigned to him by the town manager. 
(Code 1967, §§ 20-1-20-2) 
Sec. 14-2. - Appointment of additional police in emergencies; mutual assistance agreements. 
(a)  Whenever an emergency arises requiring the same, the town manager shall have the authority to employ or appoint as many qualified police officers as may be necessary for the extent of such emergency. 
(b)  The chief is authorized to enter into law enforcement mutual assistance agreements with other law enforcement agencies in accordance with the provisions of G.S. section 160A-288. 
(Code 1967, § 20-3) 
State Law reference- Policemen appointed, G.S. § 160A-281; cooperation between law enforcement agencies, G.S. § 160A-288. 
Sec. 14-3. - Residence of police officers. 
    It is desirable that police officers employed by the town be residents of the town, but the town manager is authorized in his discretion to employ or continue to employ police officers who reside outside of the corporate limits of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 20-3.1) 
Sec. 14-4. - Hospitals to report to police upon receipt of certain patients. 
    It shall be the duty of every person operating or maintaining a hospital within the town or any person in charge of a hospital to report to the police department within one (1) hour after receiving at such hospital any patient suffering from injuries sustained in an accident or by assault or from self-inflicted wounds, giving in such report the name of the patient; his approximate age, sex and residence; the extent of injuries, as near as ascertainable; the person bringing such patient to the hospital; the name of the attending physician and any information which may be obtained as to the facts surrounding the injury to the patient. 
(Code 1967, § 20-6) 
Sec. 14-5. - Reports of deaths resulting from accidental or violent means. 
(a)  Hospitals. It shall be the duty of the superintendent of every hospital in the town or the person actively in charge thereof to report to the police department and the coroner, within thirty (30) minutes thereafter, the death of any person within such hospital resulting from accidental or violent means. 
(b)  Physicians. It shall be the duty of every practicing physician attending a case within the town, where death occurs as a result of accidental or violent means, to report the fact of such death to the police department and the coroner within thirty (30) minutes after information of such death is received by such physician. 
(Code 1967, § 20-7(a), (b)) 
State Law reference- Determination of death by physician, G.S. § 90-323; notification of death, G.S. § 130A-112; post-mortem investigation and disposition, G.S. § 130A-377 et seq. 
Sec. 14-6. - Intimidating police officer having person under arrest. 
    No person shall menace or seek to intimidate any police officer having any person lawfully under arrest. 
(Code 1967, § 20-8) 
Sec. 14-7. - Interfering with police. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, hamper, molest, resist or hinder a police officer in the lawful discharge of his duty. 
(Code 1967, § 20-10) 
Sec. 14-8. - Cursing or abusing officers. 
    No person shall curse or apply any vile or obscene epithet to any officer of the town or member of the police force while such officer is in the discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1967, § 20-11) 
Chapter 15 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Town may clean trash or debris from sidewalk, § 13.3; property to be kept free of offensive matter, § 14.1; removal of offensive matter, § 14.2. 
Cross reference- Clean community commission, § 2-191 et seq.; disposal of dead animals, § 3-6; deposit of trash in cemetery, § 5-22; noxious matter declared nuisance, § 10-2; abandoned and junk motor vehicles, § 10-26 et seq.; weeds and noxious growth, § 10-81 et seq.; posting bills in recreation area, § 12-87; spilling loads prohibited, § 16-8; deposit of glass on streets, § 16-10. 
State Law reference- Littering, G.S. § 14-399; dumping litter, G.S. § 14-399.1; littering or discharge of sewage in waters and lakes, G.S. § 75A-10; solid waste management, G.S. § 130A-290 et seq.; department of transportation authorized to permit garbage collection containers on state highway rights-of-way, G.S. § 136-18.3; authorization to regulate disposal of solid wastes, G.S. § 160A-192; authorization to prohibit disposal of trash on city streets, G.S. § 160A-303.1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
