    Commercial premises means a commercial establishment having an individual designated address. 
    Commercial receptacle means a painted heavy-gauge steel receptacle with a capacity of not more than eight (8) cubic yards nor less than four (4) cubic yards and approved by the department of public works. 
    Garbage means animal and vegetable waste resulting directly from the handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of food by humans, including a minimum amount of liquid necessarily incident thereto but excluding trash. 
    Garbage roll-out container means an eighty- to ninety-gallon capacity container of plastic or like material on wheels and approved by the department of public works. 
    Industrial premises means an industrial establishment having an individual designated address or an industrial establishment located more than two hundred (200) feet from another industrial establishment on the same property under the same ownership. 
    Residential premises means a residential dwelling unit having an individual designated address, excluding multiple-residential housing units and mobile home parks with five (5) or more units. 
    Trash means waste materials resulting directly from normal day-to-day cleaning and operation of a residence, a commercial activity, an office or other urban activity, excluding, however, garbage and industrial, construction or land-clearing wastes. Trash may include yard trimmings, limbs, grass or weeds, papers, small boxes, rags, leaves, cold ashes, tin cans, glass and other rubbish in small quantities normally coming from occupied premises. 
    Waste means any useless, unused, unwanted or discarded material resulting from normal urban activities, including but not limited to cold ashes, garbage and trash. The word "waste" includes the following types of waste: 
(1)  Construction waste means waste that is the direct by-product of construction or building, including such materials as excavated earth, stones, bricks, plaster, limbs, shingles, tile, concrete and waste parts occasioned by the installation or replacement of plumbing, heating systems, electrical work and roofing. 
(2)  Hazardous waste means waste that may, spontaneously or through handling or compaction or because of exposure to temperatures experienced in the climate of this area or because of a change in composition, explode or reach the kindling point. "Hazardous waste" also means waste that emits or may emit dangerous quantities of gases or radiation or waste that is highly corrosive or otherwise dangerous. 
(3)  Industrial waste means waste from factories, processing plants or other industrial enterprises that is a by-product of the manufacture, processing or major repair of a product. 
(4)  Land-clearing waste means waste that is the direct by-product of clearing land or of major landscaping projects, including such materials as stumps, trees, limbs, excavated earth, shrubs, ashes or debris. 
(Code 1967, § 12-21) 
Sec. 15-2. - Administration. 
    The collection, removal and disposition of all waste from premises in the town and the rules and regulations governing the same shall be performed under the supervision of and enforced by the director of public works, except as otherwise provided by the ordinances of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 12-20) 
Sec. 15-3. - Littering. 
(a)  Prohibited generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drop, cast or deposit upon any street, alley, sidewalk or any yard or premises, public or private, any filth of any kind or cans, paper, trash, paper containers, rubbish, bottles, glass or any other form of litter or waste matter. 
(b)  Placing or throwing trash on public grounds. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to throw or place or cause to be thrown or placed any garbage, trash or other wastes on the public streets or in the public parks of the town unless the articles are placed in the container or other depository provided for that purpose or otherwise prepared for collection in accordance with other provisions of this chapter. The throwing or placing of the articles forbidden by this subsection shall for each act constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Duty of business owners, occupants. The owner or occupant of any store or other place of business situated within the town shall exercise reasonable diligence at all times to keep his premises clean of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers and other used or waste materials thrown or left on the premises by customers and to take reasonable measures to prevent same drifting or blowing to adjoining premises. 
(1)  Receptacles. Receptacles of sufficient size and number shall be placed by the owners thereof on the premises accessible to the customers of such business where the articles of waste referred to in this subsection may be disposed of. 
(2)  Signs. Each and every business establishment shall place upon its premises in a conspicuous place in close proximity to the receptacle a sign which shall, in essence, convey to the customers a request that they use such receptacles for the disposal of waste material. 
(d)  Duty of customer. It shall be unlawful for any customer going upon the premises of another to in any manner dispose of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers and other used or waste materials except in receptacles provided for such purposes. 
(Code 1967, §§ 12-7-12-9, 12-26(a)) 
Sec. 15-4. - Mud, rocks, etc., from construction sites deposited on public right-of-way. 
    Contractors or the owners of vehicles shall take special care at construction sites to prevent tracking of mud, rock or other soil from private property onto the public right-of-way. The contractor at any construction site shall be required to pay the cost of removing any mud, rock or other soil from the public right-of-way if the mud, rock or other soil is tracked from the construction site to the public right-of-way. The contractor may, at his option, remove the material from the public right-of-way to the satisfaction of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 12-26(f)) 
Secs. 15-5-15-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 15-26. - Solid waste management fee. 
    The director of public works shall provide for the collection and disposal of garbage and trash in accordance with the requirements and standards set forth in this article. A solid waste management fee shall be charged to all residents of the town and all businesses and commercial establishments of the town permitted to use roll-out containers, pursuant to section 15-31 of this article, whose garbage and trash is disposed of by the town's solid waste handler. The fee (or fees) shall be in an amount to be determined from time to time by the town council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(a); Ord. No. 93-11, § 1, 6-7-93; Ord. No. 94-11, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 15-27. - Precollection requirements. 
(a)  Trash. Trash shall be placed in an approved container or, if dry and nonperishable, shall be bagged, bundled, packaged, boxed or otherwise bound, tied or secured into one-man loads, and then placed adjacent to and behind the curb or in front of the ditch adjoining the street for collection. A one-man load shall not exceed four (4) feet in length or general circumference or one hundred (100) pounds in weight. Tree limbs may be excluded from the bundling or packaging requirement if cut into four-foot lengths and stacked with the butt end toward the back of the curb in front of the ditch. 
(b)  Leaves. Leaves shall be bundled, packaged or boxed into one-man loads and placed adjacent to and behind the curb or in front of the ditch, except during the portion of each year when special leaf collection equipment is in operation. During that portion of each year, leaves may be piled loosely adjacent to and behind the curb or in front of the ditch for collection by special equipment. However, such loose piles of leaves will not be collected unless they are free of trash such as broken glass, cuttings, cans or other debris that might damage collecting equipment. 
(c)  Maintenance of containers. Every garbage or trash container required by this article shall be maintained in as sanitary condition as possible in view of the use to which it is put and shall be thoroughly cleansed as needed by washing, sterilizing or otherwise by the owner thereof. 
(d)  Liquid garbage. Garbage and refuse should be drained of liquid substances and sacked or wrapped in paper before the parcel is placed in a container. 
(e)  Prohibited items. In addition to the items specified elsewhere in this article, the following items may not be placed within the roll-out containers or other waste receptacles: 
(1)  Aluminum cans; 
(2)  Recyclable corrugated cardboard; 
(3)  Recyclable rigid plastic containers that are required to be labeled as provided by G.S. 130-309.10(e) that have a neck smaller than the body of the container, and that accept a screw top, snap cap, or other closure; 
(4)  Used oil; 
(5)  Motor vehicle oil filters; 
(6)  Antifreeze (ethylene glycol); 
(7)  White goods; 
(8)  Lead-acid batteries; 
(9)  Whole scrap tires, as provided in G.S. 130A-309.58(b); 
(10)  Wooden pallets; 
(11)  Oyster shells. 
(Code 1967, § 12-23; Ord. No. 09-12, § 1, 9-14-09) 
Sec. 15-28. - Private haulers. 
    No person shall engage in the business of collecting, hauling or transporting on any public ways of the town any garbage, trash or other wastes without first obtaining a permit from the director of public works to engage in such business. The holder of such permit shall conform to the applicable provisions of this article, state law and regulation of the director of public works, and, upon failure to conform, such permit shall be subject to revocation by the director of public works. 
(Code 1967, § 12-26(e)) 
Sec. 15-29. - Containers-Residential. 
(a)  Required. It shall be the duty of every person owning, managing, leasing, occupying or operating any premises to have at least one (1) but no more than two (2) garbage roll-out containers of a design approved by the town or its sanitation contractor for the deposit therein of all garbage and/or trash. Containers may be purchased from the town's residential sanitation contractor. Such containers shall be placed on the grassed area behind the curb or in front of the ditch on the day of collection. Garbage bags may be used for the deposit of excess garbage and trash which will not fit in the required roll-out containers, provided such bags shall be placed on or beside the required garbage roll-out container behind the curb or in front of the ditch on the day of collection. 
(b)  Location. All garbage and trash roll-out containers shall be kept on the private residential premises of the owner, lessee, tenant or occupant and shall be kept at some place behind the front line of the residence except when the container is placed on the grassed area for collection. The containers may be placed at the curb the night before, but no later than 7:00 a.m. on scheduled collection days. The containers shall be retrieved from the curb on the day of collection. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(b), (g); Ord. No. 88-45, § 1, 9-12-88) 
Sec. 15-30. - Same-Commercial container location. 
    In instances where commercial receptacles are used, the owner or user thereof shall place such commercial receptacle in a suitable location, readily accessible to the collection vehicle. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(h)) 
Sec. 15-31. - Same-Central business district and shopping centers. 
    Commercial establishments in the central business district and shopping centers shall use commercial receptacles with a capacity of not more than eight (8) cubic yards nor less than four (4) cubic yards. If the director of public works determines that it is physically impractical to locate a commercial receptacle on the premises, he may permit garbage roll-out containers. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(i)) 
Sec. 15-32. - Same-Planned unit developments. 
    The public works director shall determine whether a roll-out or commercial container will be used prior to the approval of the planned unit development's final subdivision plat. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(e)) 
Sec. 15-33. - Same-Damaging. 
    It shall be unlawful to willfully cut, slash or upset containers or bags containing garbage or trash or to strew the contents of such bags or containers. 
(Code 1967, § 12-26(c)) 
Sec. 15-34. - Standards for collection. 
    Every occupant of premises in the town shall follow the standards set forth below for the preparation of garbage and trash for collection. 
(1)  Residential collection. Garbage and trash shall be collected two (2) times per week. Residents who qualify for backyard collection due to age or disability will receive only one (1) collection per week. Collection routes and schedules will be approved by the director of public works. 
(2)  Business or commercial collection. Businesses, industries, multifamily housing developments, schools, hospitals and other institutions which have accumulations of sufficiently large size, weight and volume to require commercial-type receptacles may contract for these services with the town's contractor or private haulers with permits issued pursuant to section 15-28 of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 12-24) 
Sec. 15-35. - Backyard collection for elderly or disabled persons. 
    Households in which no one is able to roll the roll-out container to the curb due to age or disability may qualify for backyard garbage collection. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(c)) 
Sec. 15-36. - Use of farm path or road. 
    When three (3) or more dwellings are located on a farm path or road, the town will collect garbage and/or trash from the front of the dwellings if the property owner enters into an agreement with the town granting the town permission to use the farm path or road for sanitation collection purposes and further agrees that the town will in no way be responsible or obligated for the maintenance of the farm path or road. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(d)) 
Sec. 15-37. - Disposition of heavy accumulations. 
    Building materials such as brick, broken concrete, lumber, plaster, ashes, dirt, rocks, sand or gravel, automobile frames and parts, dead trees and other bulky, heavy material shall be disposed of by the owner or person controlling same, according to applicable regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(j)) 
Sec. 15-38. - Responsibility for disposal of accumulations. 
    Garbage and trash allowed to accumulate beyond such time of collection or any garbage or trash ordered removed by the health department shall be the responsibility of the resident, establishment or industry to haul and dispose of same as directed by the health department or director of public works. 
(Code 1967, § 12-26(b)) 
Sec. 15-39. - Multiple housing units. 
    Multiple residential housing units and mobile home parks with five (5) units or more are required to use commercial receptacles. The town or its designated contractor will collect garbage and/or trash from the front of each mobile home if the property owners enter into an agreement with the town to provide approved roll-out containers for each individual residence and grant the town permission to use the streets within the mobile home park for sanitation collection purposes and further agree that the town shall in no way be responsible or obligated for the maintenance of the streets. If the director of public works determines that it is physically impractical to locate a commercial receptacle on the premises or determines that the garbage in a multifamily unit with five (5) units or more can be collected more economically by garbage roll-out containers, he may permit the multiple housing units with five (5) units or more to use garbage roll-out containers. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22(f)) 
Sec. 15-40. - Special services. 
(a)  Bulky trash items. During the special cleanup campaign in the spring of each year, bulky trash items such as worn-out furniture, stoves and other bulky items exceeding a one-man load will be collected if placed adjacent to and behind the curb or in front of the ditch line. 
(b)  Truck rental. Residents desiring the use of a dump truck for disposing of items permitted under the town's ordinances may rent a truck for the weekend or a holiday. The truck will be delivered, subject to availability, to the renter before 4:00 p.m. prior to the date desired and will be picked up by town personnel at 7:00 a.m. on the first workday after the weekend or holiday. Renters will not be permitted to drive the truck. The fee schedule for such extended service shall be published and reviewed annually by the director of public works. 
(c)  Dead animals. Dead animals such as cats and dogs, except those from animal clinics, will be collected on a call basis during regular working hours. The animal shall be placed on the grassed area behind the curb or in front of the ditch for collection. 
(d)  Furniture and appliances. In residential areas, furniture, appliances and other large items will be collected on regular trash collection days. These items shall be placed on the grassed area behind the curb or in front of the ditch. These items from nonresidential premises shall be disposed of by the owner. 
(e)  Additional collections. In addition to the maximum level of service permitted to all persons, the town may provide regularly scheduled additional collection service contingent upon the town's ability to perform such services. If the town agrees to provide such additional service, the recipient shall contractually agree to pay an additional fee based upon the established schedule of monthly rates for additional collections. 
(f)  Recycling. The town strongly encourages recycling efforts. Recycling containers (one per dwelling) are provided by the town at no charge and remain the property of the town. Additional or replacement containers will be provided by the town upon payment of a fee established by the town. Recycling containers shall be stored and placed for collection in accordance with the same requirements applicable to roll-out containers (see subsection 15-29). Only those materials that are acceptable for recycling shall be placed within the recycling containers. Recyclable items: Plastic drink bottles and milk jugs; clear, brown and green glass food or beverage containers; aluminum cans; newspapers bundled, not tied, on top of the container (wet newspapers are acceptable); used motor oil, placed in a clear plastic jug with a secure fitting lid and placed beside the recycling bin; and, recyclable corrugated cardboard. The public works department shall provide adequate public notice from time to time of the types of solid wastes that may be placed within these recycling containers for collection by the town. 
(Code 1967, § 12-25; Ord. No. 09-12, § 2, 9-14-09) 
Sec. 15-41. - Nonresident use of collection services. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not a resident of the town to deposit or cause to be deposited for collection by the town any garbage or trash in any container within the town if such garbage or trash is brought into the town for the purpose of such disposition. 
(Code 1967, § 12-26(d)) 
Chapter 16 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Street improvements, Art. 11; establishment of proposed street lines, Art. 12; sidewalks, Art. 13. 
Cross reference- Planning board of Tarboro, § 2-106 et seq.; stock prohibited on sidewalk, § 3-15; regulation of vegetation along street, § 10-81; shows on town common prohibited, § 11-4; ball games in streets, § 11-8; parades and processions, § 11-20; picketing, § 11-21 et seq.; construction debris deposited on public rights-of-way, § 15-4; use of streets to sell merchandise, § 17-312; traffic, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Responsibility for streets inside municipalities, G.S. § 136-66.1; authority to establish and control streets and sidewalks, G.S. § 160A-296. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Damage to streets or sidewalks; recovery of costs of repair. 
    No person shall injure, deface or mar in any manner whatsoever any of the streets or sidewalks of the town. The town shall have the right and privilege to repair any such injury, defacement or mar and assess the cost thereof against the offender. 
(Code 1967, § 23-1) 
Sec. 16-2. - Grades. 
    The town shall have the authority to establish and change the grades of the streets and sidewalks within the town as may be necessary. 
(Code 1967, § 23-2) 
Sec. 16-3. - Grade level of railroad tracks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to lay down tracks in or on any street or avenue in the town without having first obtained from the town engineer the proper grade of such street or avenue over which the line of such railroad is to run if such street or avenue has been brought to grade. Such railroad shall be put on exact grade so as not to impede or interfere with travel. If such street or avenue has not been brought to grade, then such railroad must be laid so as to conform to the then surface of the street so as not to interfere with travel over and along such street. If any company shall lay down tracks on streets not brought to grade, the right of the town to grade such street in the future shall not be prejudiced, and the owners, proprietors and lessees of such railroad tracks shall be required to raise or lower such tracks so as to conform to the grade of the streets, without cost to the town, whenever the town council may direct the same to be done. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be so construed as to prejudice the existing rights of the town to compel all persons or companies now owning or controlling railroad tracks in the town to raise or lower the tracks so as to conform to grade of streets when such streets are brought to grade. 
(Code 1967, § 22-10) 
Sec. 16-4. - Obstruction-Generally. 
(a)  No persons shall obstruct any of the streets or sidewalks in the town in such manner as to hinder or delay the travel thereon on foot or otherwise. For purposes of this section, the term "obstruct" means to place a physical barrier or object within such street or sidewalk. In such case it shall be the duty of the police to cause such obstruction removed and to keep such streets and sidewalks clear for the travel of the public. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed so as to prohibit the town to barricade, rope off or otherwise obstruct any street or sidewalk in the town when the same may become necessary for the protection, health or welfare of the citizens of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 23-3; Ord. No. 09-08, § 2, 7-13-09) 
Sec. 16-5. - Same-By merchants. 
    No person shall obstruct any of the streets or sidewalks in the town by placing thereon any boxes, merchandise or other things. This section shall not be construed to prevent merchants from making reasonable use of sidewalks when receiving or shipping goods, nor shall it prevent the use of three (3) feet of sidewalk space next to their stores for the display of goods, provided that no such display shall be made unless the entire sidewalk area is paved from the building or property line to the curbline and unless ample space is left on sidewalk for pedestrians. 
(Code 1967, § 23-4) 
State Law reference- City's duty to keep public streets free from unnecessary obstructions, G.S. § 160A-296(a)(2). 
Sec. 16-6. - Protection of streets or sidewalks under construction. 
    No person shall ride, lead or drive or cause to be ridden, led or driven any horse or other animal or drive or cause to be driven any automobile or other vehicle upon any street or sidewalk when the same is barricaded and under the process of construction, nor shall any person in any other manner cause any damage to such street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1967, § 23-5) 
Sec. 16-7. - Vehicles on sidewalks. 
    No person shall ride, pull, push or drive any vehicle whatsoever, except baby carriages, on any of the sidewalks within the fire limits. 
(Code 1967, § 23-6) 
State Law reference- Driving motor vehicle on sidewalk prohibited, G.S. § 20-160. 
Sec. 16-8. - Spilling loads prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spill or cause to be spilled from any vehicle any crushed rock, earth, concrete, sand, asphalt or other material on streets of the town. It shall be the duty of the person hauling such material to provide tight vehicles and not to load to such an extent that they will spill. 
(Code 1967, § 23-7) 
Sec. 16-9. - Certain wheels, tires, etc., restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or cause to be driven any traction engine or other vehicle with lugs or corrugations in the wheels thereof over the permanently paved streets of the town, unless suitable provisions are made by planking or otherwise to the satisfaction of the town engineer so that such corrugations or lugs will not damage the pavement. 
(Code 1967, § 23-8) 
Sec. 16-10. - Deposit of glass or other sharp objects on streets. 
    No person shall throw, place or deposit any glass or other sharp cutting substance or any injurious obstruction in or upon any of the public streets of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 23-9) 
State Law reference- Placing glass or injurious obstruction upon highway prohibited, G.S. § 136-91. 
Sec. 16-11. - Awnings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any awning or other similar object which has a clearance of less than seven (7) feet above the level of any sidewalk or which extends over the traveled portion of the street in front of the building to which it may be attached; provided, however, that stationary awning arms shall be at least eight (8) feet above the level of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1967, § 23-10) 
Sec. 16-12. - Damage to curbs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to break and remove the street curbing in any of the town's improved streets, except when a permit for the same has been issued by the town. 
(Code 1967, § 23-11) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate digging in the streets, G.S. § 160A-296(6); curb cut regulations, G.S. § 160A-307. 
Sec. 16-13. - Street numbers for buildings. 
(a)  All structures fronting on any street or alley in the town shall be numbered in some conspicuous place, by the owner thereof, according to the map made by the town engineer for such purpose and on file in his office, all odd numbers being on one (1) side of the street and all even numbers on the other. 
(b)  Any person desiring to have a number put on his structure shall first apply to the town engineer for the proper number, and any person failing or refusing to put the proper number on his structure or putting the wrong number thereon or failing or refusing to comply with any other requirement of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished pursuant to section 1-12. 
(Code 1967, § 23-12) 
Sec. 16-14. - Barbed wire. 
    No person shall erect, maintain or allow on any premises along any street or alley of the town any barbed wire or barbed wire fence where or in such manner as to constitute a danger to passers-by. 
(Code 1967, § 23-13) 
Sec. 16-15. - Electric fences. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, install or construct, operate or maintain or allow the installation or operation of a fence or similar structure or device which is electrically charged within the corporate limits without obtaining a permit from the building inspector and enclosing such electric fence, structure or device with a fence at least four (4) feet in height and of sufficient density to restrain anyone from coming in contact with such electric fence, structure or device and posting a warning sign. 
(Code 1967, § 23-15) 
Sec. 16-16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-01, § 1, adopted January 14, 2008, repealed § 16-16, which pertained to gates and doors not to open on street or sidewalk and derived from § 23-14 of the 1967 Code. 
Secs. 16-17-16-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 16-36. - Authority of council. 
    The provisions of this article shall not make it mandatory upon the town council to approve any petitions for local improvements, nor shall the town council be obligated in any manner to cause any local improvements to be made pursuant to any petitions that may be approved, and all improvements made or authorized by the town council shall be subject to the availability of funds. 
(Code 1967, § 23-25) 
Sec. 16-37. - Methods and procedures. 
    The procedures and methods of making public improvements as provided for in this article shall be governed by and be in accordance with the provisions of the General Statutes and the Charter, as amended, as the same shall apply to the town. 
(Code 1967, § 23-26) 
Sec. 16-38. - Assessments-Generally. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, all local improvements within the town of the nature set forth in this article shall be made by assessment against the abutting property owners in accordance with the provisions of the General Statutes and the Charter, as amended, as the same shall apply to the town, and the cost of such improvements shall be apportioned as provided in this article. However, in any project for any of the improvements or combination thereof within the town of the nature set forth in this article in which the total cost to be paid by the town for the project will not be more than the total cost to be paid by the town on an assessment basis as set forth in the General Statutes, the Charter, as amended, and this article and in the project for any such improvements in which all or a portion of the costs thereof are paid from community development block grant funds provided by the federal government, the town council may, in its discretion, elect to perform the project without assessing abutting property owners for any portion of the cost thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 23-27) 
Sec. 16-39. - Same-Streets. 
    Assessments for street surfacing or resurfacing improvements, except for street intersections, shall be by assessment of one-third of the total cost against the abutting property owners on each side of the street being improved; the remaining one-third and the cost of improving street intersections shall be paid by the town. The total cost subject to assessment shall include engineering costs, excavation, subbase, base course paving and any other costs which may be involved and shall also include all costs involved in street drainage, piping, catch basins, manholes and associated structures wherever located, except on private property. To the sum of all costs assessed against each property owner, eight (8) percent of that cost will be added to cover legal and assessment costs. 
(Code 1967, § 23-28) 
Sec. 16-40. - Same-Curbs and gutters. 
    Assessments for curb and gutter improvements shall be made by assessing against the abutting property owner one-half of the total cost per lineal foot of curb and gutter for each foot of the property owner's frontage, with the town to pay one-half of the cost. The cost of curb and gutter shall include engineering, grading and any other costs involved in the curb and gutter portion of the street improvement involved. 
(Code 1967, § 23-29) 
Sec. 16-41. - Same-Effect of prior assessments. 
    No assessment shall be made against an abutting property owner for street improvements for which an assessment has previously been made. 
(Code 1967, § 23-31) 
Sec. 16-42. - Certain improvements at cost of town. 
    Street surfacing or resurfacing improvements, including curbs and gutters, at street intersections, exclusive of sidewalks at such intersections, will be paid by the town. The town will share in the cost of oversized street improvements as provided by section 16-47. 
(Code 1967, § 23-32) 
Sec. 16-43. - Maintenance work not to be assessed. 
(a)  Resurfacing of streets which have previously been improved (i) where the costs of such improvements were paid by assessment as provided by state law, the town Charter and this article, or (ii) the total cost of such improvements paid by the town was not more than the town would have paid on an assessment basis, or (iii) such improvements as constructed comply with the right-of-way and design and construction standards provided for in section 16-44(b) and (c) shall be considered maintenance and shall be done and performed at the expense of the town without assessment against the abutting property owners. 
(b)  All other surfaced streets classified as local access residential streets shall be maintained in such street's existing condition by patch maintenance until such street has been improved on an assessment basis as provided in this article or has been improved with curb and gutter without assessment at a total cost to the town of not more than the town would have paid on an assessment basis as provided in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 23-33; Ord. No. 90-12, § 1, 4-9-90) 
Sec. 16-44. - Requisities for street improvements. 
(a)  No unsurfaced street shall be surfaced in accordance with section 16-39 until the unsurfaced street has been properly curbed and guttered in accordance with section 16-40 and in a manner satisfactory to the town manager, nor the unsurfaced street surfaced and the surfaced street resurfaced until water and sewer mains and laterals have been installed in accordance with the applicable provisions of this Code, state law, and town ordinances and policies, except as provided by subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Streets which have a right-of-way of at least sixty (60) feet may be surfaced without curbs and gutters (strip paved) if over sixty-seven (67) percent of the abutting property owners owning over sixty-seven (67) percent of the abutting frontage on the street or portion of the street to be strip paved file a valid petition requesting that the street be strip paved on an assessment basis as provided in this article; provided, however, that if the town manager, in his sole discretion, determines that it is engineeringly feasible to make the improvement with a right-of-way less than sixty (60) feet, he may waive the sixty-foot right-of-way requirement. 
(c)  Any construction undertaken pursuant to subsection (b) of this section will strictly adhere to the minimum design and construction standards for new streets with strip paving and side ditches, as may be adopted by the town council, and all construction and engineering costs for such strip paving, including all drainage costs, shall be assessed to the abutting property owners as provided in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 23-34; Ord. No. 90-12, § 1, 4-9-90; Ord. No. 93-20, § 1, 12-13-93) 
Sec. 16-45. - Sidewalk improvements. 
(a)  The procedures and methods of making sidewalk improvements within the town shall be governed by and be in accordance with the provisions of the General Statutes, the Charter, as amended, and this article. 
(b)  If the town council shall, in its discretion, determine that heavy pedestrian traffic exists and likely will continue to exist for an indefinite period along any street within the town and that such pedestrian traffic is generated by facilities operated and maintained by public funds such as a public school and that the convenience, safety and welfare of the public generally would be served and promoted by the construction and maintenance of sidewalks on either or both sides of such street, the town council may cause sidewalks to be constructed on either or both sides of such street without expense to the property owners abutting on such sidewalks. 
(Code 1967, § 23-35) 
Sec. 16-46. - Corner lot exemption. 
    If a corner lot is used as a single lot, where surfacing and other associated street improvements have already been made on an assessment basis on the intersecting street on which the lot abuts, no assessment shall be made against the lot for improvement on the nonimproved side for any part of the frontage of such lot, except that portion in excess of one hundred fifty (150) feet or seventy-five (75) percent of the improved frontage, whichever is greater. This section shall only apply to residential lots. 
(Code 1967, § 23-37; Ord. No. 94-15, § 1, 12-12-94) 
Sec. 16-47. - Improvements on oversized streets. 
    When a street is to be improved on an assessment basis and it is necessary for the street to be wider than a local access street (thirty-one (31) feet back of curb to back of curb), the abutting property owners shall only be assessed for those improvement costs which would have been assessed if the street had been a local access street, with the remainder of the additional cost being borne by the town. When a street is to be improved on an assessment basis and it is necessary or desirable to use street drainage pipes with a diameter in excess of fifteen (15) inches, the abutting property owners shall only be assessed for the cost of fifteen-inch drainage pipe, with the additional cost of a pipe in excess of fifteen (15) inches in diameter being borne by the town. 
(Code 1967, § 23-38) 
Sec. 16-48. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 99-21, adopted Dec. 13, 1999, repealed § 16-48 in its entirety. Formerly, § 16-48 pertained to street improvements within new subdivisions and derived from § 1 of Ord. No. 98-4, adopted Feb. 19, 1998. 
Secs. 16-49-16-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 16-66. - Applicability. 
    Except as otherwise expressly provided, the provisions of this article shall apply and shall govern the construction of all driveways, whether for commercial purposes or establishments or noncommercial purposes or establishments, within the town. 
(Code 1967, § 23-45) 
Sec. 16-67. - Prerequisites to construction. 
    Before any driveway shall be constructed, built or repaired within the town, the person desiring to do the same shall: 
(1)  Obtain the approval of the town engineer of the proposed work to be done; 
(2)  Obtain an appropriate permit from the building inspector; 
(3)  Pay a permit fee in an amount to be determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(Code 1967, § 23-46) 
Sec. 16-68. - Number and width of drives. 
    No individual driveway entrance constructed within the town shall be of a greater width than fifty (50) feet, measured parallel to the street or roadway, or wider than one-third of the lot frontage, whichever is smaller. If the lot frontage does not permit the use of two (2) driveways of one-third lot frontage as limited in this section, then one (1) combined entrance and exit of a maximum width of fifty (50) feet may be provided. Notwithstanding the above and regardless of the number of driveways, the combined width of all driveways shall not exceed two-thirds of the width of the lot on any street. 
(Code 1967, § 23-47) 
Sec. 16-69. - Area between or adjacent to driveways. 
    The frontage on the street or road right-of-way other than the driveway itself shall be either curb and gutter or in the form of a ditch or drain. Modification thereof may be permitted, provided proper drainage is constructed and curbs or posts or other safeguards are installed to prevent misuse. A written permit for any modification must be obtained from the town engineer before any work is started. 
(Code 1967, § 23-48) 
Sec. 16-70. - Return radii. 
    Suitable return radii for driveways shall be provided as determined by the town engineer. 
(Code 1967, § 23-49) 
Sec. 16-71. - Corner sight areas. 
    At intersections where sight-distance or clear-vision areas have been obtained, no driveway shall be permitted to cross such areas. The driveway at the right-of-way line should begin at a point no closer than the intersection of the sight-distance line and the right-of-way line. 
(Code 1967, § 23-50) 
Sec. 16-72. - Drainage. 
    The drainage in street or roadside ditches shall not be altered or impeded. The person constructing any driveway within the town shall provide suitable drainage structures at entrances and exits at his own expense. 
(Code 1967, § 23-51) 
Sec. 16-73. - Intersections. 
    No driveway or entrance shall be permitted to enter directly into an intersection, but shall be so placed as to turn traffic into a major or minor street before passing through the intersection. 
(Code 1967, § 23-52) 
Sec. 16-74. - Property line offset-Commercial. 
    All commercial driveways shall be so located that the flared portion thereof adjacent to the travelled way will not encroach on adjacent property. A minimum distance of five (5) feet shall be reserved between the driveway and the property line. 
(Code 1967, § 23-53) 
Sec. 16-75. - Same-Noncommercial. 
    All noncommercial driveways shall be so located that the flared portion thereof adjacent to a traveled way shall not encroach on adjacent property. A minimum distance of eighteen (18) inches shall be reserved between the driveway and the property line. 
(Code 1967, § 23-54) 
Sec. 16-76. - Commercial driveway entrances and exits. 
    For all commercial driveways, curbs, channelizing islands or posts shall be so constructed or placed as to define entrances and exits to the degree needed to prevent entire frontages from being used as driveways and thereby eliminating parking immediately adjacent to the travelled way and in front of business places. Between each driveway, if there is more than one (1), there shall be a channelizing island between the property line and the street curb for a minimum length parallel with the street of eight (8) feet along the property line and such greater length along the curb as may be necessary to conform with the requirements of section 16-77. 
(Code 1967, § 23-55) 
Sec. 16-77. - Angle of commercial driveways. 
    The angle of commercial driveways shall not be less than forty-five (45) degrees with the edge of the street or roadway, except that on dual streets or roadways where there is a median strip, the entrance angle may be decreased to not less than thirty (30) degrees. Exit drives onto dual streets or roadways shall have an angle of not less than sixty (60) degrees with the edge of the street or roadway. 
(Code 1967, § 23-56) 
Sec. 16-78. - Servicing of vehicles. 
    No vehicle shall be loaded or serviced on any portion of the street, roadway or sidewalk right-of-way. If servicing of vehicles is to be performed from both sides of a pump island, then pump islands shall be placed a minimum of twelve (12) feet away from such right-of-way line. 
(Code 1967, § 23-57) 
Sec. 16-79. - Slope of commercial driveways. 
    The grade of entrance and exit of commercial driveways shall slope away from the street or road surface at a rate of not less than one-fourth inch per foot and not more than one (1) inch per foot for the distance between the sidewalk and the street or roadway, unless the grade of the sidewalk requires a variance therefrom. 
(Code 1967, § 23-58) 
Secs. 16-80-16-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONTROL OF VEGETATION AT INTERSECTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Vegetation, § 10-81 et seq. 

Sec. 16-101. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article, "street gutter flow line" means the street gutter flow line of the curb adjacent to and bordering upon each such restricted area. If there is no such curb, the height restrictions set forth in this article shall be based upon the actual level of the paved or used portion of the public street adjacent to and bordering upon each such restricted area. 
(Code 1967, § 23-69) 
Sec. 16-102. - Enforcement. 
    In addition to any penalty which may be imposed for the violation of this article, the town shall have the power, subject to constitutional limitations, to enter upon and remove from the triangular corner areas described in this article any of the growths prohibited by this article. The town shall not be liable to the owners of such property for such entry and removal. 
(Code 1967, § 23-70) 
Sec. 16-103. - Restricted areas. 
(a)  The areas in the town restricted by the provisions of this article are as follows: 
(1)  All of that portion of land lying within a triangular shaped area on each street corner within the town described by metes and bounds as follows: 
Beginning at the precise corner of intersection point of the curbs of each of the two (2) streets forming each corner and extending twenty (20) feet along each such curbline from the curb intersection point, the third side being determined by the drawing of a straight line from the ends of such twenty-foot extensions, whether the land is privately owned or unpaved or untraveled street right-of-way property. 
(2)  Where no curbs are in existence at such street intersections, the twenty-foot lines shall coincide with the central flow line of the ditches paralleling such uncurbed streets as shall be determined by the town engineer. 
(b)  However, the provisions of this article shall apply only to those areas of the town designated and classified by the town's zoning ordinance requiring construction on lots in zoned sections to be set back from the property line of each such lot. 
(Code 1967, § 23-71) 
Sec. 16-104. - Maximum height of shrubs, etc. 
    No person shall plant, grow or maintain in any restricted area described in this article any plant, hedge, shrub or other growth, except trees, at a height greater than three (3) feet from the street gutter flow line. 
(Code 1967, § 23-72) 
Sec. 16-105. - Minimum clearance of trees. 
    Any trees planted, grown and maintained in any restricted area described in this article shall not have branches or foliage extending from the trunk thereof at a height lower than ten (10) feet from the street gutter flow line. 
(Code 1967, § 23-73) 
Chapter 17 - TAXATION, REVENUE AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Town tax collector, § 7.3; finance and taxation, Art. 8. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate and license occupations, businesses, trades, professions and forms of amusement or entertainment, G.S. § 160A-194. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Economic development investment policy. 
    The Town of Tarboro encourages and supports, within the limitations of the North Carolina General Statutes and financial constraints of the town, the development of the industrial base of the town. Though assistance is normally provided through the provision of infrastructure, such assistance may also be provided through land development, site preparation, building preparation and other means authorized in GS 158-7.1. Consideration in providing infrastructure funding or other direct assistance will be provided only upon the following terms and assurances: 
(1)  Prior to the town's agreement to participate in any industrial development project, it must be established that: 
a.  Within ten (10) years from the date the town and the applicant enter into the agreement specified in paragraph (10), the applicant's investment will increase the town's property tax base by at least five million dollars ($5,000,000.00); and 
b.  Any expenditure incurred by the town for infrastructure improvements that primarily benefit the applicant or for direct contributions to the applicant will, within ten years of the date of such expenditure, be recouped by the town by ad valorem tax revenue increases resulting from increases in the assessed valuation of the applicant's real and personal property caused by the applicant's investment. The calculation determining the assurance will be based on the then current year tax levy computed at one hundred (100) percent. 
(2)  Estimates of valuation of property enhancement must be based on an architect's estimate, contracted construction/development costs, and/or development contracts in hand if third parties are involved. Other forms of proving the level of financial commitment may be considered on an individual basis. 
(3)  All direct assistance to the applicant by the town will be paid in annual installments over a ten-year period and will be prorated based on the amount of each year's taxable property valuation. The annual installment amount shall be limited to fifty (50) percent of the amount of the annual tax revenue. The installment will not be paid until the current year's tax bill has been paid. 
(4)  Actual tax valuations as set by the Edgecombe County Tax Assessor will be used to determine if and when the five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) investment has been reached. Because the taxable valuation of personal property is depreciated over its useful life, the valuation of any personal property used to satisfy the five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) minimum investment requirement must be sufficient in amount to offset the effect of depreciation. At the end of the ten-year period, the combined additional real property value and depreciated personal property value must total at least five million dollars ($5,000,000.00). 
(5)  Projects will be evaluated on no more than ten-year projections. Increased tax revenues beyond the initial ten (10) years will enhance the project's desirability but will not qualify the project for town funding. 
(6)  The facilities of applicants must be located within the corporate limits of the Town of Tarboro or the owner must agree to petition for annexation. 
(7)  Conveyance of land by the town must be valued at an amount equal to the fair market value of the property conveyed. 
(8)  Projects must not be deemed harmful to the environment, require excessive use of water and sewer, create harmful emissions, or be potentially harmful to the surrounding neighborhood as determined by the Town Council of the Town of Tarboro. 
(9)  Applicants shall, on their corporate letterhead, detail the parameters of the request including what the general nature of the manufacturing or industrial process will be, where the site (or sites) is (are) located, how much the real estate and tangible personal property value shall initially represent, and when the facility operation shall begin. Projected daily use of municipal water, anticipated quality and quantity of wastewater, level of electric Kwh usage and electric Kw demand will be provided. The applicant will also indicate that new jobs to be offered will meet average wage levels as set forth in the state enabling laws. The applicant letter, from a corporate official, will be addressed to the Town Manager of the Town of Tarboro. 
(10)  Investment by the town under this policy shall take place only pursuant to a written agreement between the town and the applicant that sets forth the mutual obligations of the parties, establishes a time frame for performance, and spells out the consequences of a failure of performance. 
(Ord. No. 97-16, § 1, 10-13-97; Ord. No. 98-2, § 1, 1-29-98; Ord. No. 11-07, § 1, 6-13-11) 
Secs. 17-2-17-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General power to impose taxes, G.S. § 160A-206. 

Sec. 17-26. - Annual determination. 
    The ad valorem tax rate shall be determined by the town council each year. 
(Code 1967, § 24-1) 
Sec. 17-27. - Payment of taxes; discounts and penalties. 
    All ad valorem taxes levied by the town council shall be due and payable on September 1 of the year in which they are assessed or levied. No discount will be allowed for payment of taxes before the due date. Penalties and interest shall be added at such times and in such amounts as may be prescribed by the General Statutes pertaining to the late payment of taxes. 
(Code 1967, § 24-2(a)) 
Sec. 17-28. - Sale of property for unpaid taxes. 
    The town tax collector is hereby designated or commissioned to sell all property, real or personal, to satisfy any tax certificate or lien, penalty or forfeiture, as is provided under state laws. 
(Code 1967, § 24-3) 
Secs. 17-29-17-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADVERTISING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Unlawful posting of advertisements, G.S. § 14-145. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-46. - General restrictions. 
    No person shall advertise any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind for sale by crying out the same on the streets or sidewalks of the town. No person shall advertise any goods, wares or merchandise or any event of any kind by crying out the same or by using any megaphone, bell, horn or other noise-making device on any street or sidewalk, nor shall radios or loudspeakers be operated in such a manner as to project sound outside the confines of the building in which they may be located. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1) 
Sec. 17-47. - Use of amplifying equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind by the use of any amplifying equipment used by or mounted on any vehicle, boat or aircraft without first having obtained a permit therefor from the town manager. 
(Code 1967, § 3-2) 
Sec. 17-48. - Marking of streets or sidewalks prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise or attempt to advertise by marking or painting on any of the streets or sidewalks within the town. 
(Code 1967, § 3-3) 
Sec. 17-49. - Misrepresentation of goods. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person running and conducting a public sale within the town of any goods, wares or merchandise to falsely advertise or misrepresent the same as being imported or to falsely represent the same as to brand, trademark, quality, weight and texture. 
(Code 1967, § 3-4) 
Sec. 17-50. - Misleading advertising or display of goods. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person running or conducting any mercantile business in the town to display in his windows or place of business any goods, wares or merchandise which are not in fact priced in good faith and carried in stock for sale in accordance with such display or advertisement so made, and it shall be unlawful for any person to display any misleading advertisements or displays as to the goods, wares or merchandise actually carried in stock for sale. 
(Code 1967, § 3-5) 
Sec. 17-51. - Placing on motor vehicles. 
    No person shall distribute advertising or printed matter of any kind by placing the same in or on a motor vehicle that is parked on any street or in other public places. 
(Code 1967, § 3-6) 
Sec. 17-52. - Posting on property of others. 
    No person shall post any bills, signs, posters or advertisements on any buildings, fences, poles or other property belonging to another without the consent of the owner thereof. Such consent shall be secured in writing, and such written consent shall be exhibited by the person having the same to any police officer on demand. 
(Code 1967, § 3-7) 
Sec. 17-53. - Posting on poles prohibited. 
    No person shall post any bills, posters, signs or advertisements on any telegraph, telephone, electric light or other pole along any of the streets of the town, provided, that this section shall not be construed to include street signs placed on such poles by the town for designating names of streets. Each sign, poster, bill or advertisement posted in violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1967, § 3-8) 
Sec. 17-54. - Mutilation of advertisements. 
    It shall be unlawful to tear, deface, mutilate, take down or in any manner destroy any advertisement or any legal, public or private notice lawfully posted for public view within the corporate limits, except that the owner of the property upon which such advertisement or notice has been posted without his permission may remove the same. 
(Code 1967, § 3-9) 
State Law reference- Injuring notices and advertisements, G.S. § 14-384. 
Secs. 17-55-17-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HANDBILL DISTRIBUTION 

Sec. 17-71. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this division, "distribute" means and includes the scattering, throwing, handing out or any other means of dispensing circulars, handbills or other printed matter. 
(Code 1967, § 3-10) 
Sec. 17-72. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or cause to be distributed any circulars, handbills or other written or printed matter for advertising purposes upon the streets or sidewalks of the town without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 3-12) 
Sec. 17-73. - Scattering prohibited. 
    No person shall promiscuously distribute handbills or advertisements of any kind by placing or throwing the same on any street or lot or otherwise. Such handbills or advertisements shall be enclosed in an envelope or clipped and placed under or in the mailbox of each house where such advertising matter is left. 
(Code 1967, § 3-11) 
Sec. 17-74. - Persons acting for others. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or cause to be distributed any circulars, handbills or other written or printed matter for advertising purposes on behalf of any other person unless such other person shall have first obtained a license therefor. It shall be the duty of any person making such distribution to inform himself as to whether or not the proper license has been obtained by such other person. 
(Code 1967, § 3-13) 
Sec. 17-75. - Exceptions to certain sections. 
    Sections 17-73 and 17-74 shall in no way affect the usual and customary sales and delivery of newspapers and periodicals and shall not prevent the distribution of advertising matter in business buildings or private residences. 
(Code 1967, § 3-14) 
Secs. 17-76-17-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SIGNS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Ch. 4. 

Sec. 17-91. - Permit-Applicability. 
    The provisions of sections 17-92 through 17-94 shall not apply to signs, banners, billboards or similar structures or objects placed within the rights-of-way before April 9, 1962, provided that such signs, banners, billboards, etc., not in compliance with such sections shall not be enlarged, relocated or changed unless in compliance with such sections. Such signs shall be maintained in a safe and presentable condition or shall be condemned and removed upon demand of the building inspector. 
(Code 1967, § 3-18) 
Sec. 17-92. - Same-Location as grounds for denial. 
    The building inspector shall not issue a permit for the erection, construction or placement of any outdoor commercial display sign, banner, billboard or other similar structure or object which is to be located, supported or erected upon the ground within the public street or highway rights-of-way within the corporate limits. 
(Code 1967, § 3-20) 
Sec. 17-93. - Same-Compliance with building code. 
    The building inspector is hereby authorized to issue a permit for wall signs, roof signs and other projecting signs or similar structures or objects which are to be supported by or attached to the faces of buildings or upon roofs when the same comply with all requirements of article XXIII of the state building code applicable thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 3-21) 
Sec. 17-94. - Same-Bond required for display signs. 
    The owner or person in control of a display sign shall file with the building inspector a public liability insurance policy or surety bond thereon, approved by the town attorney, in a company duly licensed to transact business in the state for the principal sum of not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) liability to any one (1) person or fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) liability on account of any one (1) accident, such policy or bond to be written in accordance with standard form now in general use and a duplicate thereof deposited with the building inspector, which policy or bond shall further carry an endorsement protecting the town as its interest may appear as a result of any accident or injury for which it might become in any manner liable. 
(Code 1967, § 3-22) 
Sec. 17-95. - Placement in town common. 
    No signs, billboards, banners or similar objects shall be placed in the town common except in specific compliance with the provisions of this Code, ordinances, rules, regulations or policies of the town council concerning the town common. 
(Code 1967, § 3-23) 
Sec. 17-96. - Signs or banners across streets or sidewalks. 
    No person shall erect or place any sign or banner of wood, cloth, metal or other material across any street or sidewalk in the town without permission by the town manager; provided however, that the town council shall have power to revoke any permit to erect or maintain any such sign. 
(Code 1967, § 3-15) 
Sec. 17-97. - Minimum height over sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hang or suspend any sign over or above any sidewalk or street of the town, such sign having a clearance of less than seven (7) feet from the ground over the sidewalk. 
(Code 1967, § 3-16) 
Sec. 17-98. - Erection of signs, etc., for charitable, civic, religious, etc., purposes. 
    Signs, banners, billboards and similar structures and objects directly relating to charitable, historical, religious or other civic services and nonprofit activities may be installed in the public rights-of-way upon a permit issued by the building inspector with approval of the town manager. 
(Code 1967, § 3-17) 
Secs. 17-99-17-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AUCTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Auctions and auctioneers, G.S. § 85B-1 et seq. 

Sec. 17-121. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether principal or agent, who has not engaged in a permanent business within the corporate limits of the town for a continuous period of at least twelve (12) months next preceding to sell, dispose of or offer for sale or to cause or permit to be sold, disposed of or offered for sale in the town, at public auction, goods, wares or merchandise without first having obtained a license or permit therefor; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the sale of farm products or judicial sales or sales by executors and administrators, receivers or assignees in insolvent and bankrupt estates. 
(Code 1967, § 7-1) 
Sec. 17-122. - Inventory required. 
    Every applicant for a license or permit to conduct a public auction sale shall file with the town manager a complete inventory, verified under oath, of all goods, wares and merchandise to be offered at such public auction. 
(Code 1967, § 7-2) 
Sec. 17-123. - Bond. 
    Every applicant for a license or permit to conduct a public auction sale shall be required to file with the town manager a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), with good and sufficient surety, for the purpose of guaranteeing compliance with the terms of this article and applicable provisions of state law and the faithful performance of any contract made with the customers and purchasers at the auction sale, such bond to remain in full force and effect for the term of sixty (60) days after the close of the auction sale. 
(Code 1967, § 7-3) 
Sec. 17-124. - Adding stock to continue sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person buying any bankrupt stock to add to such stock for the purpose of continuing an auction sale thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 7-4) 
Sec. 17-125. - Duration of sale. 
    Sales at public auction of the stock of any person shall not be held on other than successive days, Sundays and legal holidays excepted, and shall continue not more than thirty (30) days in all within the period of one (1) fiscal year. 
(Code 1967, § 7-5) 
Sec. 17-126. - Closing hours. 
    No person shall sell, dispose of or offer to sell or dispose of at public auction any of the goods, wares or merchandise set forth in this article between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(Code 1967, § 7-6) 
Sec. 17-127. - Bidding. 
    No person at any public auction of goods, wares and merchandise shall act as a sham bidder or what is commonly known as "capper," "booster" or "shiller" or offer to make any false bid or falsely pretend to buy any article offered at the auction for the purpose of deceiving the persons attending the sale, nor shall any person conducting such sale receive knowingly or permit to be made any false or "boosting" bids by any "booster," "buy bidder," "shiller" or other person bidding for the purpose of boosting the price of articles sold or offered for sale at the auction sale. 
(Code 1967, § 7-7) 
Secs. 17-128-17-155. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VII. - JUNK DEALERS AND JUNKYARDS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Failure of junk dealers to keep record of purchases a misdemeanor, G.S. § 66-10; dealing in certain metals regulated, G.S. § 66-11; transportation of copper, G.S. § 66-11.1; Junkyard Control Act, G.S. § 136-141 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-266. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Junk means any worn out, discarded or old iron, other metal, automobile parts, chain, copper, parts or machinery, automobile tires, appliances or old wrecked or unusable automobiles and trucks and other articles commonly known as junk. 
    Junkyard means any land or area used, in whole or in part, for commercial storage and/or sale of wastepaper, rags, scrap metal or other junk and including storage of motor vehicles and dismantling of such vehicles or machinery. 
(Code 1967, § 14-1) 
Sec. 17-267. - Records-Required. 
    Any person operating or maintaining a junkyard shall keep records on each article of junk which will show the following: 
(1)  A description of the junk; 
(2)  The person or corporation from whom obtained; 
(3)  The serial or motor number, if any. 
(Code 1967, § 14-5) 
Sec. 17-268. - Same-Maintenance. 
    The records required to be kept by junk dealers shall not be destroyed until three (3) years of age and shall be available for inspection by the building inspector or chief of police at reasonable times. 
(Code 1967, § 14-6) 
Sec. 17-269. - Enclosure required. 
    All junkyards shall be enclosed by a wire or metal fence of a minimum height of six (6) feet, protected by gates which may be locked and shall be locked when an attendant is not present. The plans for construction of the fence and gates shall be first submitted to the building inspector and approved by him. 
(Code 1967, § 14-7) 
Sec. 17-270. - Accessory buildings. 
    Nothing but automobile dismantling shall be carried on in any automobile or truck junkyard, and if repairs are made at or in any junkyard to automobiles or trucks, such repairs shall be made in a building meeting all the applicable provisions of this Code and state law. 
(Code 1967, § 14-8) 
Sec. 17-271. - Burning prohibited. 
    No junk or any vehicle, including automobiles and trucks, shall be burned in or on any premises occupied as a junkyard. 
(Code 1967, § 14-9) 
Cross reference- Air pollution, § 10-51 et seq. 
Sec. 17-272. - Combustible materials. 
(a)  Gas and oil and all other combustible materials shall be stored in a building of fireproof construction which shall be constructed in full compliance with all applicable provisions of this Code and state law. 
(b)  Upon being stored or placed in the junkyard, all gas and oil shall be drained from vehicles and stored. 
(Code 1967, § 14-10) 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention, Ch. 7. 
Secs. 17-273-17-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 17-291. - Required. 
    Any person who shall engage in the business of buying, selling, handling, storing or hauling junk shall first obtain a permit therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 14-2) 
Sec. 17-292. - Application. 
    Application for a permit to engage in the junk business shall be made to the building inspector and shall state the place where the business is to be conducted and that the terms of this article shall be met. 
(Code 1967, § 14-3) 
Sec. 17-293. - Issuance. 
    The building inspector shall issue a permit to engage in the junk business to the applicant therefor if it shall appear that the location of the junkyard shall not constitute a fire hazard or other hazardous condition to any adjacent property or shall not be in violation of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 14-4) 
Secs. 17-294-17-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of solicitation campaigns, flea markets and itinerant merchants, G.S. § 160A-178. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-311. - Going on private residence without invitation. 
    The refusal or failure immediately to leave private residences in the city by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of merchandise, books, periodicals, magazines, pictures, prints and/or photographs or makers of photograph negatives, after having been requested or required so to do by the owner or occupant of such private residence, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, books, periodicals, magazines, pictures, prints, merchandise and/or disposing of and/or peddling or hawking the same is declared to be a nuisance and punishable as a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 18-8) 
State Law reference- Trespass on land after being forbidden, G.S. § 14-134. 
Sec. 17-312. - Use of streets. 
    No permittee under this article shall have the right to sell or exhibit for sale on any street, sidewalk, alley or public place within the town any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind or character or to use any part of the streets, sidewalks, alleys or public places within the town as a place in which to carry on his trade, profession or business. 
(Code 1967, § 18-9) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 17-313. - Standing or parking restriction. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to take a stand or stop or stand his vehicle within the town for the purpose of selling his articles for a period of time in excess of thirty (30) minutes within the same block in the residential sections of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 18-10) 
Cross reference- Stopping, standing and parking § 19-136 et seq. 
Secs. 17-314-17-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 17-331. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for peddlers, solicitors, canvassers, itinerant or transient vendors or merchants who may move from place to place or from house to house in the town to sell or offer for sale any bankrupt, fire or water damaged stock of merchandise or goods, wares or any other commodity or solicit, sell or take orders for goods, wares, merchandise, subscriptions to magazines, newspapers, to expose plates or films or make negatives, to make pictures or photographs for future delivery or any delivery or any article for future delivery without first applying for and obtaining a permit to do so from the chief of police. 
(Code 1967, § 18-1) 
Sec. 17-332. - Application; fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of peddling within the town shall first file a written application for a permit to do so to the chief of police which shall show: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The name and address of the person whom such applicant represents; 
(3)  The names of the immediate last preceding three (3) towns in which he worked, if any; 
(4)  The kind of goods, wares and merchandise offered or to be offered for sale; 
(5)  Whether such applicant, upon any such order so obtained, will demand, accept or receive payment or deposit money in advance of final delivery; and 
(6)  The period of time such applicant so wishes to solicit, sell or take orders in the town. 
(b)  The application shall also show satisfactory proof of his authority to represent the company or individual such applicant so states that he represents and shall be in writing. 
(c)  The written application shall be accepted by the chief of police, accompanied by a fee as shall be determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office, and no permit shall be issued until such fee has been paid by the applicant. 
(d)  The application shall also be accompanied by two (2) photographs of the applicant taken within one (1) month prior to the date of application, the applicant's fingerprints and the license fee required by law. 
(e)  No permit shall be issued until such application has been filed with the chief of police for a period of seventy-two (72) hours, then only after the chief of police has determined that the applicant meets all the requirements. 
(Code 1967, § 18-2) 
Sec. 17-333. - Exemptions. 
    The permit required by this article shall not be required of the following: 
(1)  Local resident business representatives; 
(2)  Ordinary commercial travelers who sell or exhibit for sale goods, wares or merchandise to persons engaged in the business of buying, selling and dealing in the same within the town; 
(3)  Persons offering for sale agricultural products, meats, poultry or other articles of food grown or produced by such persons; 
(4)  Sales of goods, wares and merchandise by a local resident person, the major portion of the proceeds of which are to be used and applied to some locally recognized and approved charitable, educational, religious or philanthropic purposes to be expended within the corporate limits of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 18-3) 
Sec. 17-334. - Permit card. 
    Along with every permit issued under the provisions of this article, the permittee shall be issued a card which shall be wallet size and contain the name of permittee, permit number, date of expiration of the permit and the signature of the chief of police. Such card shall be stamped with the town seal on the face thereof. It shall be unlawful for the permittee to engage in his business without having such card in his possession, and it shall further be unlawful for such permittee to fail or refuse to show or display such card upon the request of any person demanding the same. 
(Code 1967, § 18-5; Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 2-8-93) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 93-5, § 1, adopted Feb. 8, 1993, rescinded § 17-334 and subsequently, renumbered §§ 17-335-17-337 as §§ 17-334-17-336. Former § 17-334 pertained to issuance and bond of permits and derived from § 18-4 of the 1967 Code. 
Sec. 17-335. - Duration. 
    All permits issued under the provisions of this article shall be, except as specifically provided otherwise, issued for such period of time as may be determined at the discretion of the chief of police, provided that any such permit shall not be issued for a longer period of time than twelve (12) months. 
(Code 1967, § 18-6; Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 2-8-93) 
Sec. 17-336. - Transferability. 
    Each permit issued under the provisions of this article shall not be transferable or assignable and shall give to no person other than the permittee authority to transact any business in the town. 
(Code 1967, § 18-7; Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 2-8-93) 
Secs. 17-337-17-355. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PAWNBROKERS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, G.S. § 91-1 et seq. 

Sec. 17-356. - Reports and records. 
    All pawnbrokers doing business in the town shall furnish each day to the police department a full and complete list of every article taken in pawn by them or bought by them, giving a full description of the same including the maker, marks, number, brand, monogram and letters of every kind on such article so pawned or bought, and shall keep a daily record showing from whom all such articles are received and to whom sold. 
(Code 1967, § 16-19) 
Sec. 17-357. - Arrangement of stock. 
    Every pawnbroker in the town shall have his goods arranged in stock so as to enable any police officer to readily inspect the same. 
(Code 1967, § 16-20) 
Sec. 17-358. - Forfeiture of license. 
    Every pawnbroker persistently neglecting, failing or refusing to comply with the provisions of this article shall forfeit his license to do business in the town, in addition to any penalty imposed upon conviction for any such violation. 
(Code 1967, § 16-21) 
Secs. 17-359-17-375. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PRIVILEGE LICENSE TAX[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to levy privilege license taxes on businesses and trades, G.S. § 160A-211. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-376. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agent means the person having the agency for the manufacturer, producer or distributor. 
    Business means any business, trade or profession. 
    Contract sales means all work done by electrical, plumbing, heating and general contractors for a specified cost and shall be considered as being done under the contractor's license. That part of the "cost plus" contract other than labor shall be considered to be sales, that is, the cost of the material plus the percentage shall be considered sales and shall be taxable under section 17-387 of this article. 
    Engaged in business means as either owner or operator. 
    Gross sales means the sum total of all cash sales and sales on credit. If the business is on a cash basis, cash sales shall be the total sum of all goods sold for cash, plus all payments received on account. If the business is on an accrual basis, the gross sales shall be the total of all sales for cash, plus all sales on credit, plus accounts previously charged off and collected subsequently, less all accounts charged off. 
    License tax year means the period beginning with July 1 and ending June 30 next following, except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code or state law. 
    Quarter means any three (3) consecutive months. 
(Code 1967, § 15-1) 
Sec. 17-377. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to business licenses and shall not apply to franchise taxes unless so specifically provided. 
(Code 1967, § 15-2) 
Sec. 17-378. - Levied. 
    In addition to the tax on property imposed by the town and under the power and authority conferred by state law, there shall be levied and collected annually or more often, as may be provided, a privilege license tax on trades, professions, agencies, business operations, callings, occupations, avocations, exhibitions, circuses and all other subjects within the town authorized to be licensed as set out in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 15-6) 
Sec. 17-379. - Continuing authority of council. 
    Nothing contained within this article shall be construed to prevent the town council from imposing from time to time such other license taxes as are not specifically defined in this article or required or from increasing or decreasing the amount of any special license tax or from prohibiting or regulating the business or acts licensed. 
(Code 1967, § 15-4) 
Sec. 17-380. - Exemptions-Generally. 
    Except as otherwise provided by this Code, the schedule of license taxes set out in this article or by state law, there shall be no exception of any person for any reason from the payment of the license taxes levied by this article. 
(Code 1967, § 15-27) 
Sec. 17-381. - Same-Charitable organizations.
