The parking of vehicles shall be limited to fifteen (15) minutes between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:30 p.m., unless other hours may be specifically designated, in the designated parking spaces marked and set off on designated streets and portions of streets within the town. 
(26)  Handicapped only parking spaces. Certain locations are hereby designated as handicapped only parking spaces. 
(27)  Reserved parking spaces. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle other than an official vehicle of or for the indicated department, official or purpose in any designated reserved parking spaces. 
(28)  Parking of commercial passenger buses. The parking of any vehicle other than a commercial passenger bus within the zones designated shall be unlawful. 
(29)  Loading, unloading zones. The parking of vehicles for the loading or unloading of goods, wares, merchandise or other freight on the portion of Main Street between Church and Granville Streets is prohibited except within the zones designated. 
(30)  Passenger loading and unloading. A passenger loading and unloading zone is hereby established and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time, other than the expeditious loading and unloading of passengers, in places marked as a passenger loading and unloading zone during the hours when the regulations applicable to such zones or stops are effective, and then for a period not to exceed three (3) minutes. Passenger loading and unloading zones are established at designated locations during the periods of time indicated. 
(31)  Municipal parking lot reserved spaces. Parking spaces shall be reserved for the exclusive use of certain officials or purposes within the municipal parking lot located on the west side of Main Street and north of the town hall. 
(32)  Parking lots operated by parking authority; parking limited to two hours. The parking of vehicles shall be limited to two (2) hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. every day except Sundays and legal holidays in the designated public parking lots operated by the parking authority; provided, however, that this limitation shall not apply to those spaces appropriately marked as reserved parking spaces in such lots. 
(33)  Turn right on red light. Any vehicle, after coming to a complete stop for a red light facing the vehicle, may make a right turn after yielding to pedestrians and other vehicles. 
(34)  No-passing zones. No vehicle shall pass any other vehicle traveling in the same direction on any street or portion of street which is designated as a no-passing zone. 
(35)  Controlled residential parking areas. An area designated as a controlled residential parking area and subject to article VA of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, §§ 26-212-26-238; Ord. No. 88-41, 8-8-88; Ord. No. 90-3, §§ 1, 2, 2-12-90; Ord. No. 90-4, §§ 1, 2, 2-12-90; Ord. No. 90-15, § 1, 5-14-90; Ord. No. 91-7, § 1, 4-8-91; Ord. No. 91-25, § 2, 11-4-91) 
Chapter 20 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Water and sewer improvements, Art. 15. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; building regulations, Ch. 4; health and sanitation, Ch. 8; housing, Ch. 9; solid waste management, Ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Public enterprises, G.S. § 160A-311 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Scope. 
    All pertinent provisions of this chapter are hereby made a part of the terms and conditions whereby the town shall furnish sewer, electric or water service to any person or whereby the town shall make any sewer, electric or water connections or perform any work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of sewer, electric or water service. 
(Code 1967, § 27-2) 
Sec. 20-2. - Liability of town for damage. 
    The town shall not be liable for any damage to the property of any customer of any utility service furnished by the town due to backflow of the sewerage system; failure of the electric, sewer or water supply; interruption of service or any other cause outside the direct control of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 27-3) 
Sec. 20-3. - Application for service. 
    Written application shall be made to the town, upon forms furnished therefor, for water, sewer, electricity or any other utility service that may be furnished by the town. Such application shall state the name and address of the applicant, the type of utility service desired, the purposes for which the application is made and such other information as the town may request. 
(Code 1967, § 27-4) 
Sec. 20-4. - Connections to service. 
    Connections for any utility service furnished by the town shall be made only by the town under the supervision of the superintendent of the particular department. 
(Code 1967, § 27-5) 
Sec. 20-5. - Separate connections. 
    Except as provided by section 20-128 with regard to group housing developments, every building, structure or consumer in the town shall have a separate utility service connection. 
(Code 1967, § 27-6) 
Sec. 20-6. - Service to comply with technical regulations. 
    Any utility service furnished under the provisions of this chapter at any of the rates set forth shall be in accordance with and compliance with all applicable technical provisions of this Code, state law and town ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 27-7) 
Sec. 20-7. - Termination of service for noncompliance. 
    The town shall have the right to disconnect or refuse to connect or reconnect any utility service which does not meet the applicable provisions of this Code, state law or town ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 27-8) 
Sec. 20-8. - Ownership of equipment, meters, etc. 
    All meters, meter boxes, pipes and other equipment furnished and used by the town in installing any utility connection shall be and remain the property of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 27-9) 
Sec. 20-9. - Resale of service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resell any utility service obtained from the town to others except by units of local government or recognized and licensed utility companies, and then only by special arrangement. 
(Code 1967, § 27-1) 
Sec. 20-10. - Town's right to temporarily interrupt service. 
    The town reserves the right to cut off any utility service without notice in case of emergencies. When an interruption in service is necessary for maintenance and improvement to the utility system, affected customers will be notified as circumstances permit. 
(Code 1967, § 27-10) 
Sec. 20-11. - Obtaining right-of-way for facilities. 
    When any utility service is requested which requires the placing of the town's facilities on or across private property other than that of the applicant, the person requesting such service shall obtain or cause to be obtained at no cost to the town all rights-of-way necessary for the town's facilities. 
(Code 1967, § 27-11) 
Sec. 20-12. - Plumbing inspection prior to making water or sewer taps outside town. 
    In order to protect the town water supply, the town will not make any water or sewer taps outside the town limits until the plumbing of the premises involved has been inspected and approved by the town plumbing inspector, which inspection will be made only after deposit of the stipulated fee for such inspection by the affected property owner. The plumbing shall be in accordance with the plumbing code of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 27-12) 
Secs. 20-13-20-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Electric service in urban areas, G.S. § 160A-331 et seq. 

Sec. 20-36. - General inspection. 
    The town will inspect only facilities connected to the town electric lines. 
(Code 1967, § 27-22) 
Sec. 20-37. - Inspection of wiring prior to connection. 
    When an electric connection is requested for a new structure or a structure has been repaired, revised, moved or extended, the electrical wiring must be inspected by the electric inspector and approved as to meeting the requirements of the town electric code before any connection or reconnection will be made. 
(Code 1967, § 27-23) 
Sec. 20-38. - Electrical inspection prior to connection outside of town limits. 
    In order to protect the town electric system, the town will not make any electric connection outside the town limits until the electric system of the premises involved has been inspected and approved by the town electrical inspector, which inspection will be made only after deposit of the stipulated fee for such inspection by the affected property owner. The electric system shall be in accordance with the town electric code. 
(Code 1967, § 27-24) 
Sec. 20-39. - Unlawful use of current. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to extend electric wires or electric service of the town in or outside of any structure by attaching thereto additional wires, burners or lights. 
(Code 1967, § 27-25) 
Sec. 20-40. - Location of connection. 
    Anyone requesting an electric service connection or relocation of an existing connection must provide, on the premises to be served, a point of attachment for the electric department's wires, meter, metering equipment and all apparatus necessary to provide and meter and maintain the type of service to be furnished. The location of the point of attachment and meter must be approved by the superintendent of the electric department before any electrical wiring or rewiring may be commenced. The point of attachment and location of the meter must be open and easily accessible to employees of the electric department for maintaining, servicing and meter reading. The point of attachment must also be approved by the superintendent of the electric department with regards to its strength for supporting the wires which are to be attached and its height to give proper clearance above the ground and/or other objects. The town will not be responsible for damage to the point of attachment unless such damage is caused by negligence of town employees. 
(Code 1967, § 27-26) 
Sec. 20-41. - Attachments to electric system property. 
    No person shall attach any wires, signs, boxes, ropes or any other thing to the poles, structures or other property of the electric system unless it is determined by the superintendent of the electric department to be permissible and prior approval is given in writing. 
(Code 1967, § 27-27) 
Sec. 20-42. - Accessibility of meters. 
    All electric meters must be located so as to be easily and readily accessible to employees of the electric department for installing, removing, servicing and reading. Where an electric meter is not located so as to be easily and readily accessible to employees of the electric department and the service is disconnected for any reason, the meter must be relocated so as to be easily and readily accessible before the electric service will be reconnected. If the premises being served is altered in any way which makes the meter not easily and readily accessible, the electric meter must be relocated so as to make it easily and readily accessible to employees of the electric department. 
(Code 1967, § 27-28) 
Sec. 20-43. - Right-of-way. 
    Electric connections will not be made that cross private property other than the particular residential, commercial or industrial lot being served, unless a right-of-way is given to the town and recorded. 
(Code 1967, § 27-29) 
Sec. 20-44. - Extensions. 
    When an electric connection is requested which will require an extension of the town's electric lines and the estimated cost of such extension is greater than five (5) times the estimated annual revenue from the connection, then a deposit in the amount of the estimated cost of the extension will be required. Fifty (50) percent of the monthly electric bill will be deducted from the deposit and the remaining fifty (50) percent paid by the customer monthly until the deposit is used up. Thereafter the customer will pay one hundred (100) percent of the bills in the usual manner. 
(Code 1967, § 27-30) 
Sec. 20-45. - Temporary service. 
    Upon request of the customer, temporary electric service shall be supplied under the following conditions: 
(1)  The customer shall pay to the town, prior to connection of the service, a temporary service charge which shall be the estimated net cost, including all applicable overhead costs, of installing and removing the service facilities furnished by the town both on and off the customer's premises, except as modified by subsection (2) of this section. 
(2)  Where temporary service is furnished at a permanent service location, the temporary service charge will be the net cost to the town, including overhead costs, which is in excess of the estimated cost of furnishing the permanent service. 
(3)  When the construction necessary to install the required service would not be greater than that required to install a single-phase, three-wire overhead or underground service from an existing secondary on a pole already set or from an existing pad-mounted transformer already in place, the customer may elect to pay, in lieu of the charges described in subsection (1) or (2) of this section, prior to connection a flat charge in an amount to be determined by the council from time to time and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. However, if the customer requests the town to prepare an estimate under either subsection (1) or (2) of this section, then the flat charge under this subsection will not be applicable. 
(Code 1967, § 27-31; Ord. No. 96-18, §§ 1, 2, 10-14-96) 
Secs. 20-46-20-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER AND SEWER CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 20-66. - Fees. 
    The fees which may be charged by the town for water and/or sewer connections shall be paid in advance. 
(Code 1967, § 27-41) 
Sec. 20-67. - Made at one time. 
    Water and sewer connections to the town's water mains and sewer lines, when both are desired or required, shall be made at the same time, and an application to connect therewith shall be made at the same time. 
(Code 1967, § 27-42) 
Sec. 20-68. - Construction by town. 
    Upon approval of any application for a sewer or water connection, the town only shall do the excavating, lay the pipe, install a meter where necessary, make the connection to the main, fill the excavation and replace the surface of the street. 
(Code 1967, § 27-43) 
Sec. 20-69. - Outside town. 
    No connection of any water or sewer line or system outside the town shall be made to any part of the town water or sewer system without special permission from the town manager on such terms as the town council shall prescribe. 
(Code 1967, § 27-44) 
Sec. 20-70. - Maintenance. 
(a)  The town shall be responsible for the maintenance and repair of the water line from the water main to the point of metering for the structure served and of the sewer line from the sewer main to the property line of the structure served. 
(b)  If the town is requested or required to cut off water service to a dwelling or building at the meter and the dwelling or building served by such meter does not have an approved private water shut-off valve near the entrance of the water service pipe into the dwelling or building, service shall not be restored to such dwelling or building until a private water shut-off valve is installed and maintained near the entrance of the water service pipe into the dwelling or building and approved by the town. 
(Code 1967, § 27-45) 
Sec. 20-71. - Additional connections. 
    Whenever any additional water or sewer connection is provided for any user of the town's water or sewer system at the user's request, such user shall bear and pay the additional connection fee. 
(Code 1967, § 27-46) 
Sec. 20-72. - Laterals. 
    At each water tap, the town will extend the water lateral to the back of the curbline where the meter will be located and will extend the sewer lateral to the property line. 
(Code 1967, § 27-47) 
Sec. 20-73. - Taps on lines abutting property. 
    No water or sewer tap will be made except to a water or sewer line situated in that part of the street or right-of-way immediately abutting the lot to be served, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 27-48) 
Sec. 20-74. - Temporary water taps. 
    When a temporary water tap is desired, the party desiring such a tap shall deposit with the town the fee for an in-town tap, regardless of the location of the tap, and the town will then install a meter at the nearest water main. After the tap has served its purpose and has been removed, the town will refund to the depositor any monies over and above the cost of labor and the cost of any material involved in the project that is not reusable. 
(Code 1967, § 27-49) 
Sec. 20-75. - Taps on privately owned lines. 
    The town shall not make taps on privately owned water lines. 
(Code 1967, § 27-50) 
Sec. 20-76. - Extensions to become property of the town. 
    All extensions made to the town's water or sewer system shall, upon completion thereof, become the sole property of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 27-51) 
Sec. 20-77. - Water shortage response plan. 
(a)  The provisions set forth in sections 20-77 through 20-83 of this chapter shall be referred to as the Town of Tarboro's Water Shortage Response Plan ("this plan"). 
(b)  The Town of Princeville, Edgecombe County, and any other unit of local government that purchases water from the Town of Tarboro's water system will, at a minimum, adopt and enforce the water use reduction measures contained in this plan as a condition of water sales. 
(c)  When the thresholds established in section 20-80 are reached, the town manager, or the public works director, as designated by the town manager, shall declare a water shortage and institute the provisions of this plan. Upon declaration of a water shortage by the manager, a press release will be forwarded to the following media outlets: The Daily Southerner,(252-823-3106) WCPS 760 AM Radio, (252-824-7878), WITN Channel 7 News (252-946-3131),WNCT Channel 9 News (252-355-8500)and WRAL Channel 5 News (919-821-8555). 
(Ord. No. 01-11, 6-11-01; Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 20-78. - Year-round water conservation policy. 
(a)  The Tarboro Town Council encourages all municipally supplied water users to use water efficiently at all times. The Town of Tarboro's Public Works Director will monitor regional water resource conditions through the North Carolina Drought Monitor. fhttp://www.ncwater.org/drought/). When the drought monitor indicates impending drought conditions the public works director will increase monitoring of water demand and the available supply of water. The findings will be reported to the town manager. In the event of a declaration of a water shortage by the town manager, the public works director will submit a weekly report on water supply conditions to the town manager. 
(b)  Public education and outreach efforts will consist of the following activities: Independent mailing to major users; bill stuffers to all customers; radio, TV (public service announcements), website, newspaper ads, and water audits. 
(Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 20-79. - Water use classification. 
    To aid implementation of this plan the following classes of water use are established: 
(1)  Class I: Essential potable water uses shall consist of the following: 
a.  Domestic: Water to sustain human and domestic pet life; minimum standards of hygiene and sanitation. 
b.  Patient care: Patient care and rehabilitation, including swimming pools used for patient care and rehabilitation. 
c.  Public use: Firefighting and approved flushing of sewers and hydrants to ensure public health and safety. 
(2)  Class II: Socially/economically important potable water uses shall consist of the following: 
a.  Domestic: Minimal use for kitchen, bathroom and laundry; minimal watering of vegetable gardens and trees to preserve them. 
b.  Public use: Filling and operation of public swimming pools, which serve more than twenty-five (25) residents. 
c.  Commercial: Commercial vehicle washes and laundromats; restaurants and hotels, irrigation of golf course greens, watering by commercial nurseries at a minimum level to maintain stock, minimum amount required to maintain essential cooling operations. 
d.  Agricultural: Minimum amount required to maintain crops, livestock, and associated activities. 
e.  Industrial: Minimum use necessary to operate production facilities and maintain jobs, minimum amount required to maintain essential cooling operations. 
f.  Institutional: Efficient use by schools, churches, and government facilities. 
(3)  Class III: Nonessential potable water uses shall consist of the following: 
a.  All: Ornamental uses (fountains, reflecting pools, artificial waterfalls, etc.); residential lawn irrigation; noncommercial washing of motor vehicles; wash down of impervious surfaces; filling and operation of recreational swimming pools serving less than twenty-five (25) residents. 
b.  Public use: Gardens, lawns, parks, golf courses (except greens), playing fields and recreational areas. 
c.  Commercial: Serving water in restaurants except by request. 
(Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 20-80. - Drought response triggers and phased water use reductions. 
(a)  When the water supply thresholds (triggers) described in this section are reached, the town manager shall initiate the phase reduction measures as outlined under the corresponding response heading. 
(b)  Phase I: Voluntary water use reduction. 
(1)  Triggers. Whenever the town manager finds that a potential shortage of water supply is indicated or when the flow of the Tar River as measured by the USGS river gauge located in Tarboro falls below seventy (70) cubic feet per second (cfs) for seven (7) consecutive days, the manager shall declare a state of voluntary conservation, and shall call upon all water customers to employ voluntary water conservation measures. 
(2)  Response. The town manager shall declare a water shortage advisory and shall: 
 Begin distribution of water use reduction education materials; 
 Begin public notification as previously outlined and distribute water conservation tips; 
 Request voluntary conservation for all users of the Town of Tarboro water system as outlined in distributed information; 
 Request all irrigation systems be limited to two (2) days per week between 6:00 p.m.-8:00 a.m.; 
 Request citizens to stop all noncommercial car washing; 
 Request all noncommercial pressure washing and wash down of impervious surfaces be reduced or eliminated; 
 Request class III nonessential uses be reduced or eliminated; 
 Request restaurants serve water only by request; 
 Require commercial and industrial water users to prepare and submit a twenty-five (25) percent water use reduction plan within thirty (30) days of water shortage advisory declaration; 
(c)  Phase II: Mandatory water use reduction measures. 
(1)  Triggers. Whenever the town manager finds that there is the potential for a water emergency situation to occur or exist or when the flow of the Tar River as measured by the USGS river gauge located in Tarboro falls below fifty (50) cubic feet per second (cfs) for seven (7) consecutive days, the manager shall declare a state of mandatory conservation. Under a state of mandatory conservation, the manager shall continue to encourage voluntary water conservation measures, and shall impose a scheduled water use program or an outright ban on all class 3 uses until the mandatory conservation period is declared to be over by the manager. 
(2)  Response. The manager shall declare a water shortage alert and shall notify water use customers by any or all methods previously outlined. The manager shall also propose to the council daily household consumption restrictions to be implemented under phase III conditions, and may propose other amendments to this plan that would impose additional water use restrictions or bans applicable to phase II conditions. All phase I voluntary conservation measures shall become mandatory, and the following additional requirements shall be applicable: 
 The twenty-five (25) percent water use reduction plans for industrial and commercial users shall be implemented and become mandatory requirements. 
 Landscape irrigation shall be limited to one (1) day per week using drip irrigation or hand held nozzle; 
 Residential outdoor watering shall be limited to spray nozzle or drip irrigation only; 
 No noncommercial car washing; 
 Vehicle sales dealerships may only wash vehicles upon the purchase or sale of such vehicles; 
 No noncommercial pressure washing or washing down of impervious surfaces; 
 Restaurants shall be allowed to serve water only upon request; 
 No filling of newly constructed or recently drained pools unless to prevent damage; 
 Public recreational areas shall be limited to watering on Monday between the hours of 6:00 p.m.-8:00 a.m.; 
 Institutional automatic toilet flushing systems may operate only during business hours; 
 Nonpublic hydrant use permits shall be evaluated and approved only for health and safety reasons; 
 No ornamental uses; 
(d)  Phase III: Emergency water use reduction measures. 
(1)  Triggers. Whenever the manager finds that there is the potential for a water emergency situation to occur or exist or when the flow of the Tar River as measured by the USGS river gauge located in Tarboro falls below forty (40) cubic feet per second (cfs) for five (5) consecutive days, the manager shall declare a water shortage emergency. 
(2)  Response. The manager shall declare a water shortage emergency and shall notify water use customers by any or all methods previously outlined. The manager shall also propose to the council a water rationing plan to be implemented under phase IV conditions and may propose other amendments to this plan that would impose additional water use restrictions or bans applicable to phase III conditions. The council shall also consider enacting advance restriction pricing and/or surcharges with fines for overuse, and shall implement daily household consumption restrictions. In addition to the phase II restrictions, the following requirements shall also be applicable: 
 No Class III nonessential use except as otherwise provided herein; 
 No landscape irrigation (including golf course greens, school grounds, residential lawns); 
 No vehicle washing by vehicle sales dealerships; 
 No nonpublic hydrant use; 
 No topping off pools; 
 The manager shall request such additional conservation from Class I (essential) users as may be possible; 
 Garden irrigation (shall be limited to two (2) days per week between 6:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. by hand or drip irrigation only; 
 No recreational use. 
(e)  Phase IV: Crisis water use reduction measures. 
(1)  Triggers. Whenever the manager finds that there is the potential for a water emergency situation to occur or exist or when the flow of the Tar River as measured by the USGS river gauge located in Tarboro falls below thirty (30) cubic feet per second (cfs) for five (5) consecutive days, the manager shall declare a water shortage crisis. 
(2)  Response. The manager shall declare a water shortage crisis and shall notify water use customers by any or all methods previously outlined. The manager may also propose other amendments to this plan that would impose additional water use restrictions or bans applicable to phase IV conditions. The council shall adopt amendments to this plan that will require additional conservation from class I (essential) users as may be possible, and require all industrial and other large users to follow a set of large water user restriction guidelines. The council shall reevaluate and consider additional advance restriction pricing with fines for overuse, and implement a water rationing plan. In addition to the phase III restrictions, the following requirements shall be applicable: 
 No garden irrigation; 
 Flow to wholesale water customers will be reduced or eliminated as needed to meet demand; 
(f)  Phase conservation measures and restrictions will expire incrementally when the town manager, after consultation with the public works director, finds that the conditions that triggered that particular phase no longer exist. 
(Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 20-81. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Except as otherwise directed by the manager, the provisions of this plan will be enforced by the Tarboro Police Department. 
(b)  Subject to the remaining provisions of this subsection, a violation of the mandatory conservation measures set forth in section 20-80 shall subject the offender to a civil penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) if the violation occurs under phase II conditions, one hundred dollars ($100.00) under phase III conditions, and one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) under phase IV conditions. If within a period of sixty (60) days prior to the violation in question the violator has violated any of the mandatory provisions of section 20-80, then the amount of the civil penalty for the second violation shall be twice the amount that would have been levied had there been no prior violation. For a third or any additional violation that occurs within the prior sixty (60) days, the amount of the civil penalty shall be three times the amount that would have been levied had there been no prior violation. If a person fails to pay the civil penalty within ten (10) days after being cited for a violation, the town may seek to recover the penalty by filing a civil action in the nature of debt. 
(c)  Each day that a violation continues after the offender has been notified of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  Upon the fourth violation of the mandatory conservation measures set forth in section 20-80, the town may disconnect the water utility service from the premises where the violations occurred, in accordance with the notice and hearing procedures and reconnection fees and charges applicable to discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills set forth in section 20-136 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 20-82. - Variances. 
    When practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships would result from carrying out the strict letter of the mandatory conservation measures set forth in section 20-80, the council shall have the power to vary or modify any of those restrictions so that the spirit of this plan shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. 
(Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 20-83. - Effectiveness; revisions. 
(a)  The effectiveness of this plan will be determined by comparing the stated water conservation goals with observed water use reduction data. Other factors to be considered include frequency of plan activation, any problem periods without activation, total number of violation citations, desired reductions attained and evaluation of demand reductions compared to the previous year's seasonal data. 
(b)  The town manager shall propose revisions to this plan as needed at a minimum within five (5) years of adoption and every five (5) years thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 4-12-10) 
Secs. 20-84-20-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER SERVICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to operate water system, G.S. § 160A-312; power to require connections, G.S. § 160A-313. 

Sec. 20-96. - Hydrants. 
(a)  Installation. Hydrants will be installed outside the town limits upon the payment of the actual cost plus overhead, provided the line on which the hydrant is to be installed is six (6) inches in diameter or larger from the hydrant to the water plant or elevated tank. The party desiring the hydrant outside the town will be required to deposit in advance the estimated cost of installation. After installation any excess deposit will be promptly refunded and any deficiency shall be promptly paid to the town by the party requesting the hydrant. Fire hydrants on private property in the town will be installed at the expense of the property owner with payment as provided for hydrants outside the town. The location of hydrants will be determined by the fire chief and the superintendent of the water and sewer department with the approval of the town manager. 
(b)  Use. Water is not to be taken from fire hydrants except by authorized personnel. 
(c)  Area around hydrants to be kept clear. An area not less than six (6) feet in any direction shall be kept clear and unobstructed around each hydrant. 
(Code 1967, § 27-73) 
Sec. 20-97. - Sprinkler systems. 
(a)  Connections outside town. All persons outside the town limits who shall desire sprinkler systems connected to the water system of the town shall pay the town applicable charges in accordance with the rates and fees schedule. 
(b)  Plans and specifications. No sprinkler or other fire system will be connected to the town water system unless and until adequate plans for the system have been submitted to and approved by the superintendent of the water system, and the final tap on the connection will not be made until the entire installation has been inspected and approved by the superintendent. All such installations shall be in accordance with the specifications and requirements of the superintendent and shall include not less than one (1) Fire Underwriters approved check valve at a location to be designated by the superintendent. 
(c)  Inspections. Subject to constitutional limitations, the superintendent of the water and sewerage department, during daylight hours of any day other than Sundays or legal holidays, shall have the full right and authority to enter upon the premises of the person obtaining a sprinkler or other fire system for the purpose of inspecting the connections of such systems. 
(d)  Water to be used for fire protection only. No water supplied for sprinkler systems, passing through the required connections, shall be used for any purpose other than fire protection. No connections other than those required for firefighting purposes will be permitted on any fire system. 
(e)  Penalties for violations. Upon the failure of any person to comply with any of the provisions of this section, the town may, after ten (10) days' written notice, disconnect the premises of such person from the water system of the town. If the premises of any water customer is disconnected for violation of any of the provisions of this section, the town will not reconnect such premises until an approved detector-type check valve and meter has been installed on the fire service portion of the customer's water system at the property owner's sole expense. In such cases the restoration of services may be made as soon as the customer involved has deposited with the town sufficient funds to cover the estimated cost of the installation of an approved detector-type check valve and meter. 
(Code 1967, § 27-74) 
Secs. 20-98-20-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RATES AND CHARGES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to fix and enforce rates, G.S. § 160A-314. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-126. - Service charges. 
(a)  A service charge in an amount determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office, paid in advance, shall be charged for the connection, reconnection, cutting on or transfer, during normal business hours, of electric service and/or water service furnished the applicant by the town; provided, however, that no such charge shall be required for electrical service under the AL rate schedule. 
(b)  A service charge in an amount determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office, paid in advance, shall be charged for the connection, reconnection, cutting on or transfer, after regular business hours, of electric service and/or water service furnished the applicant by the town. 
(c)  A service charge in an amount determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office shall be charged on all checks tendered in payment of utility services, utility deposits or fees which are dishonored by the customer's bank because of insufficient funds or a closed account. 
(Code 1967, § 27-85; Ord. No. 96-18, § 3, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 20-127. - Meters required. 
    Except as may be otherwise authorized by the town council, meters shall be required on all utility connections to measure the consumption of the utility service used by the customer. 
(Code 1967, § 27-86) 
Sec. 20-128. - Separate meters required; exception. 
    Except as provided in this section, each family unit, apartment or separate business operation shall have a separate meter. Except as provided in this section, two (2) or more dwellings, apartments, stores or combination of dwellings, apartments or business establishments will not be allowed on the same meter. For group housing developments, the owner may elect to have one (1) meter for each apartment or dwelling unit or to have one (1) meter per building. If the owner of a group housing development elects to have one (1) meter per building, the owner of such group housing development making such election will be billed as a single customer for each building. Except for a group housing development, where a meter is serving more than one (1) dwelling, apartment or business establishment at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the practice will be allowed to continue, but no additional dwelling, apartment or business establishment may be added to such multiple user's service, and when such multiple service is discontinued at the user's option or the electrical wiring or other utility types of equipment is revised or extended, the service will not be reconnected until provisions are made by the user for each dwelling, apartment or business establishment to be served through a separate meter. Except for group housing developments, where multiple use on one (1) meter is allowed, the usage will be divided by the number of dwellings, apartments or business establishments served and the bill computed as if each were an individual account, and the total amount so computed will be rendered in one (1) bill. 
(Code 1967, § 27-87) 
Sec. 20-128.1. - In-ground irrigation system requirements. 
(a)  All new in-ground irrigation systems installed after the effective date of this section [September 14, 2009] that will be supplied water by the Town of Tarboro Public Water System shall be independently connected to the system and water consumption shall be measured through a separate irrigation meter. 
(b)  An irrigation service line may be installed by a direct tap into the water main serving the property, or by a split line off the nonirrigation service line at a point between the main and the non-irrigation water meter. Either method of connection shall be performed by the Town of Tarboro Public Utilities Department or by a licensed contractor who must obtain a permit from the Town of Tarboro prior to installing an irrigation service line. 
(c)  The irrigation service line, the irrigation meter and all related appurtenances shall be installed in accordance with the same regulations, policies and procedures as applied to nonirrigation meters. 
(Ord. No. 09-11, § 1, 9-14-09) 
Sec. 20-129. - Maintenance of meters. 
    All meters shall be kept in good repair and working order by the town and at the expense of the town. 
(Code 1967, § 27-88) 
Sec. 20-130. - Tampering with meters, connections or appurtenances prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to purposely cut on, cut off or damage any meter, meter box, utility connection or appurtenance or to interfere with any meter, meter box, utility connection or appurtenance belonging to the town. 
(Code 1967, § 27-89) 
Sec. 20-131. - Test for accuracy of meter. 
    Any customer having reason to believe his meter is not registering accurately can have his meter tested by depositing an amount to be determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office, with his request to have his meter tested. If the meter accuracy is found to be within plus or minus two and one-half (21/2) percent of true values, the deposit will be retained by the town to help defray expenses of testing. If the meter is found to be inaccurate by more than two and one-half (21/2) percent, the deposit will be refunded and the meter will be adjusted to register within plus or minus one-half percent of true values. Adjustments of bills and enforcement of this section is provided for under the authority of G.S. sections 160-110 through 160-114. 
(Code 1967, § 27-90) 
Sec. 20-132. - Estimates of readings. 
    The meter reader will not read any meter where he considers a dog not properly confined to be dangerous or potentially dangerous and will estimate the amount used by that customer using his best judgment. Each customer whose meter is not read for this reason will be notified. The town manager will arrange for a special meter reading where the meter reader will be accompanied by the householder for any customer not satisfied with the estimated reading, provided that the customer pay a special fee, in an amount to be determined from time to time by council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office, for each special meter reading. 
(Code 1967, § 27-91) 
Sec. 20-133. - Bills for services. 
(a)  When due. All bills for water, sewer, electric or other utility services furnished by the town shall be due and payable prior to 5:00 p.m. of the tenth day following the date of mailing thereof. 
(b)  When past due. All bills for which payments have not been received in the office of the collector of revenue by 5:00 p.m. on the final pay date shown on the bill shall be considered past due. If such final pay date shall fall on a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday observed by the town, then such bill shall be considered past due if not paid by 5:00 p.m. of the next working day immediately following; provided, however, that payment received and found in the night payment depository box of the office of the collector of revenue at the beginning of business on the first working day following the final pay date or received from the United States Postal Service bearing a postal mark prior to the date of the final pay date and received by the collector of revenue not later than the second working day after the final pay date shall be deemed to have been received on the final pay date and not past due. 
(c)  Penalty on past due bills. Penalty charges computed at the rate of one and one-half (11/2) percent per month or fraction thereof shall accrue on all past due bills for current services or for service discontinued voluntarily or involuntarily; provided, however, that the penalty charges shall not be less than an amount as shall be determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. The penalty may be waived for a customer who has never been late paying a bill within the last twelve (12) months and who has been a customer of the town for a year or more. 
(Code 1967, § 27-92; Ord. No. 91-3, § 1, 1-14-91; Ord. No. 96-16, § 1, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 20-134. - Final disposition of deposit. 
    When a customer has furnished a utility deposit to guarantee payment of bills and service has been terminated, such deposit shall be applied to any unpaid charges or indebtedness due to the town, and the balance shall be refunded. 
(Code 1967, § 27-93) 
Sec. 20-135. - Discontinuance of service-Voluntary. 
    In order to ensure discontinuance of service at a time requested by the customer, notice to the town in advance of the proposed time of discontinuance shall be required. When a customer desires to discontinue service, he shall give notice to the town at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance, and the customer will be responsible for all service consumed during the period preceding the discontinuance. No service will be discontinued on Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. 
(Code 1967, § 27-94) 
Sec. 20-136. - Same-Involuntary. 
(a)  The town sometimes finds it necessary to discontinue utility service to customers because of the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure of a customer to pay any bill for utility service within the time allowed by these rules; 
(2)  Failure of a customer to make a deposit to guarantee payment of charges for utility service or to increase his deposit when required by these rules; 
(3)  Refusal of legitimate access to premises or damage to or loss of property of the town on the customer's premises for which the customer is liable; 
(4)  Failure of a customer to pay the penalty charge on his bill brought about because a prior bill was not paid timely; 
(5)  Using another name or the name of another member of the family in order to avoid the payment of an unpaid prior bill. 
(b)  For the purpose of determining when a reconnection fee and/or deposit shall become due and payable, involuntary utility service disconnection shall be deemed to have been accomplished when the utility serviceman leaves the collector of revenue's office with the written order to discontinue the customer's utility service. 
(c)  When it becomes necessary for the town to discontinue utility service to a customer for any of the reasons stated in subsection (a) of this section, service will be reinstated only after all bills for service then due have been paid, any deposit required has been made and a reconnection fee, in an amount as shall be determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office, has been paid to reimburse the town for expenses involved in disconnecting and reconnecting the utility service. 
(d)  If a customer is receiving service at more than one (1) location, service at any or all locations may be discontinued if bills for service at any one (1) or more locations are not paid within the time specified by these rules; provided, however, that residential utility service shall not be discontinued for nonpayment of bills for other classes of service. 
(e)  It is the policy of the town to discontinue utility service to customers for nonpayment of bills only after notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard on disputed bills. The town's form for application for utility service and all bills shall contain, in addition to the title, address, room number and telephone number of the town official in charge of utility customer services, clearly visible and easily readable provisions to the effect that: 
(1)  All bills are due and payable within ten (10) days after the date the bill is mailed. 
(2)  If any bill is not paid by the final pay date as shown on the bill, service will be discontinued for nonpayment. 
(3)  Any customer disputing the correctness of his bill shall have a right to a hearing, at which time he may be represented in person and by counsel or any other person of his choosing and may present orally or in writing his complaint and contentions to the town official in charge of utility customer services who shall be authorized to order that the customer's service not be discontinued and have the authority to make a final determination of the customer's complaint. 
(f)  Requests for a delay or waiver of payment will not be entertained; only questions of proper and correct billing will be considered. In the absence of payment of the bill rendered or a resort to the hearing procedure provided in this section, service will be discontinued at the time specified. 
(Code 1967, § 27-95) 
Sec. 20-137. - Electric and water deposits-Specified. 
(a)  Along with the application for electric and water services, the applicant shall pay to the town a deposit in such amount and in such a formula as shall be determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. The categories for electric and water service shall be as follows: 
(1)  R-1 electric service or R-1 electric service and residential water service; 
(2)  Residential water service only; 
(3)  G-1, CP-A and CP-B electric service and/or commercial water service; 
(4)  G-3 electric service and water service. 
(b)  The town shall require a deposit from a customer who does not have a current deposit with the town or an increase in the deposit if such customer: 
(1)  Has service discontinued for nonpayment of a bill and has been late in paying a bill within the preceding twelve (12) months; or 
(2)  Has one (1) of his checks given in payment of a bill dishonored. 
(c)  A former residential customer who has a past due bill, regardless of the reason, and subsequently applies for utility service shall be required to make a deposit in such an amount and in such formula as shall be determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(Code 1967, § 27-96; Ord. No. 96-18, § 4, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 20-138. - Same-Waiver. 
(a)  Upon presentation of a letter of good credit from the former utility supplier covering at least twelve (12) consecutive billing periods, the town manager is hereby authorized and empowered to waive the utility deposit. If after having placed a deposit the applicant submits a letter of good credit, the deposit will be refunded. Good credit is defined as being late in payment of a bill no more than twice during the previous twelve (12) months and having no cutoffs for nonpayment. 
(b)  The town manager is hereby authorized and empowered, in the case of any person, partnership or corporation desiring electric services under the G-1, CP-A or CP-B rate and water service under the commercial and industrial rate on a permanent basis, after appropriate investigation of the financial status, real estate and machinery or equipment owned by the customer and located on the premises, to waive that portion of the required deposits in excess of fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00). 
(c)  In lieu of a cash deposit, any customer who is required to place a utility deposit in an amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more may select one (1) of the following alternatives: 
(1)  The customer may assign or pledge as collateral with a local financial institution a certificate of deposit, savings certificate or savings account to the town in the same amount as the deposit. An agreement approved by the town attorney must be executed by the customer, a corporate officer of the financial institution and an official of the town. Interest earned on the pledged collateral will be payable to the customer. 
(2)  The customer may post a surety bond with the town in the same amount as the deposit. The cost of the surety bond must be paid by the customer. It must be issued by a company licensed to transact such business in the state. The surety bond must contain a provision that it cannot be cancelled, terminated, or allowed to expire without thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the town. In the event of cancellation, termination, or expiration of the surety bond, the customer will be required to post a cash deposit unless he/she becomes eligible to receive utility service without the requirement of a deposit. 
(Code 1967, § 27-97; Ord. No. 88-49, § 1, 10-10-88; Ord. No. 92-13, § 1, 9-14-92; Ord. No. 96-18, § 5, 10-14-96; Ord. No. 03-12, § 1, 4-14-03; Ord. No. 03-18, § 1, 6-9-03) 
Sec. 20-139. - Same-Refund of deposits. 
(a)  An existing customer may apply for and receive a refund of his utility deposit by check or have the deposit credited to his account if such customer, during the last twelve (12) consecutive billing periods for prior service, has not: 
(1)  Had service discontinued for nonpayment of a bill; 
(2)  Had one (1) of his checks given in payment of a bill dishonored; or 
(3)  Been late in paying a bill more than twice. 
(b)  The deposit of an existing customer who is not entitled to a refund of the deposit under this rule shall continue to be held by the town until such customer qualifies for a refund or until service is discontinued or terminated. 
(c)  The town shall have the right to refund the deposits of customers who qualify for refunds, but who do not apply for such refunds, or to credit their accounts with the amount of the deposits. 
(d)  The town shall not pay interest on customer deposits. 
(e)  The eligibility of existing customers who do not qualify for a deposit refund under subsection (a) of this section shall be determined on the anniversary date of the deposit. 
(Code 1967, § 27-98; Ord. No. 88-54, § 1, 12-19-88) 
Secs. 20-140-20-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICITY 

Sec. 20-156. - Multiple types of service. 
    When two (2) or more types of electrical service are furnished through the same meter, the higher rate shall apply. 
(Code 1967, § 27-101) 
Sec. 20-157. - Residential service rate, R-1. 
(a)  Applicability. This schedule is applicable to any customer who purchases alternating current electricity through one (1) meter for: 
(1)  Single-family residential use; 
(2)  Single-family residential-farm use; 
(3)  Residential houses used as tourist homes, roominghouses, nurseries, kindergartens or dancing schools, provided such residential house is one which is ordinarily used as a private residence, has only one (1) cooking installation and has no more than ten (10) bedrooms. 
    This schedule is not applicable to any commercial use, standby service or resale. In particular this schedule is not applicable to hotels, motels, trailer camps or any similar establishment. Service under this schedule is not available for separately metered farm operations or farm use other than incidental. "Incidental farm service" is that service used for the lighting of small farm buildings and the operation of miscellaneous motors of one (1) horsepower or less not used in the production of farm products. 
(b)  Types of service. The type of electric service available on this schedule is sixty-cycle alternating current, single-phase, three-wire, 120/240 volts. 
(c)  Rates. The schedule of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(1)  The minimum charge shall be the basic customer charge. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(d)  Special terms and conditions. 
(1)  The type electric water heater approved for service on this schedule is an insulated standard storage-type electric water heater equipped with a heating unit, each controlled by separate thermostats and so connected that the maximum connected load to be supplied will never exceed five thousand five hundred (5,500) watts per heater. 
(2)  Individual motors having a rating of more than fifteen (15) horsepower will not be served on this schedule. 
(e)  Meter reading. Meters may be read in units of ten (10) kwh and bills rendered accordingly. 
(Code 1967, § 27-102; Ord. No. 90-11, § 1, 4-9-90; Ord. No. 96-18, § 6, 10-14-96; Ord. No. 02-21, § 1, 11-18-02) 
Sec. 20-157.1. - Residential time-of-use service rate, R-TOU-1. 
(a)  Availability. This rate schedule is available to customers purchasing alternating current electricity through one (1) meter for single-family residential use, but limited to no more than fifty (50) customers. 
(b)  Type of service. The type of electric service available on this schedule is 60-cycle alternating current, either single-phase, 3-wire, [or] 120/240 volts. 
(c)  Rate. The schedule of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(d)  Classification of energy. The kilowatts per hour (kwh) of energy shall be measured during each fifteen-minute interval in the billing month. The kwh of energy usage by customers under this rate schedule shall be classified for purposes of billing as follows: 
On-peak energy: Energy usage shall be on-peak when it is used during the following times, excluding weekends and holidays: 
Period Months On-peak

 and 
1:00 p.m.- 8:00 p.m. Summer June-September 1:00 p.m.- 8:00 p.m. Fall October, November 7:00 a.m.-10:00 a.m. 
 and 
1:00 p.m.- 8:00 p.m.  
(Ord. No. 94-6, § 1, 4-11-94) 
Sec. 20-158. - Area lighting service rate, AL. 
(a)  Applicability. This schedule is applicable to electric service supplied in the lighting of outdoor areas by means of luminaries mounted on brackets extending six (6) feet or less from a town-owned wood pole on which secondary conductors exist or can be extended. 
(b)  Type of service. Outdoor area lighting service is supplied in accordance with a customer's written application and agreement and under the town's electric ordinance and this schedule. The service supplied by the town will include furnishing and installing the lighting units requested by customers and connecting the lighting units to the town's system, all in accordance with the town's standards and requirements. Such facilities, with automatic controls, will be owned, maintained and operated by the town, and the town will furnish the electricity required for the illumination of the lamps during the hours of darkness. 
(c)  Maintenance. The town will perform as soon as practical, during regular working hours, the necessary maintenance to restore illumination after a customer has notified the town that a lamp is not burning. 
(d)  Monthly rate. For lighting units mounted on a wood pole, the schedule of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees maintained in the clerk's office. 
(e)  Contract. This service will only be provided after a regular contract is entered into between the town and the customer, which contract shall be in the form and with such provisions as may be approved by the town attorney. The contract period shall be not less than three (3) years and shall extend from year to year thereafter until terminated by the customer or the town. If a customer desires to terminate the agreement before the expiration of the initial contract period, the town will agree to such termination, provided the customer pays to the town a sum of money equal to forty (40) percent of the bills which would otherwise have been rendered for the unexpired months in the initial contract period. The contract provided for in this rate schedule shall be signed by the person in whose name the electric service is provided and for the town by the director of electric utilities. 
(Code 1967, § 27-105; Ord. No. 96-18, § 7, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 20-159. - Small general service rate, G-1. 
(a)  Applicability. This schedule is applicable to any individual, commercial or industrial electric customer except that it is not applicable for resale, relay, breakdown or parallel operation. 
(b)  Type of service. The town will normally supply the equipment necessary and will deliver to the customer, at one (1) delivery point mutually satisfactory to the town and the customer, sixty-cycle alternating current electricity at the town's standard voltages. Three-phase service will be supplied where requested, provided it is available generally at the location at which it is desired. 
(c)  Rate. The schedule of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(d)  Determination of demand. The kw demand used in making a determination of rates for this section shall be the highest average kw load measured in any interval during the current billing month. 
(e)  Meter reading. Meters may be read in units of ten (10) kwh and bills rendered accordingly. 
(Code 1967, § 27-106; Ord. No. 90-11, § 2, 4-9-90; Ord. No. 96-18, § 8, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 20-160. - Governmental service rate, G-3. 
(a)  Applicability. This schedule is applicable to electric service supplied to and paid for by any agency of the United States government which is exempt from the three (3) percent state sales tax on electricity. 
(b)  Type of service. The town will normally supply the equipment necessary and will deliver to the customer, at one (1) delivery point mutually satisfactory to the town and the customer, sixty-cycle alternating current electricity at the town's standard voltages. Three-phase service will be supplied where requested, provided it is available generally at the location at which it is desired. 
(c)  Rate. The schedule of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(d)  Determination of demand. The kw demand used in determining the rates for subsection (c) of this section, shall be the highest average kw load measured in any interval during the current billing month. 
(e)  Meter reading. Meters may be read in units of ten (10) kwh and bills rendered accordingly. 
(Code 1967, § 27-107; Ord. No. 90-11, § 3, 4-9-90) 
Sec. 20-161. - Large general service, CP-A and CP-B. 
(a)  Availability. The CP-A schedule is available for electric service used by a nonresidential customer where the contract demand averages between five hundred (500) kilowatts and one thousand five hundred (1,500) kilowatts for any twelve (12) consecutive months. The CP-B schedule is available for electric service used by a nonresidential customer where the contract demand averages more than one thousand five hundred (1,500) kilowatts for any twelve (12) consecutive months. The CP-A and CP-B schedules are available to all electric service of the same available type supplied to a customer's premises at one (1) point of delivery through one (1) meter. These schedules are not available for resale service, or for short-term or temporary service. 
This rate is not available for the addition of new peaking generation after February 1, 2009 or for any customer which does not have peaking generation in commercial operation under this schedule as of February 1, 2009. 
(b)  Rate. The schedules of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(c)  Definitions. 
    Coincident peak (CP) demand shall mean the customer's contribution to the town's sixty-minute clock-hour kilowatt demand measured during the sixty-minute interval which is used by the North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency (NCEMPA) for wholesale billing purposes during the current calendar month. Where the coincident peak period initially identified by NCEMPA is changed, the coincident peak (CP) demand of the customer during the corrected period shall be used for billing and a corrected bill rendered as necessary. 
    Excess demand shall mean the difference between the customer's maximum fifteen-minute demand recorded during the current billing month or minimum contract billing demand, whichever is greater, and the coincident peak (CP) demand for the same billing month. 
    Kwh (of energy consumption) shall mean the total usage of electricity during the current billing month. 
    RKVA demand shall mean the customer's maximum fifteen-minute reactive demand recorded during the current billing month. 
(d)  Notification by town; load curtailment by customer. In an effort to assist the customer in reducing its monthly coincident peak (CP) demand, the town will use diligent, good-faith efforts to identify potential coincident peak (CP) demand periods and notify the customer of such in advance. The town, however, cannot guarantee that identifications of these periods in all cases will be made, or that advance notice will be provided. The customer will hold the town harmless in connection with such failures to identify these periods and/or provide advance notice, or with the customer's receipt of and response to such notice. 
Normally, notice of potential coincident peak (CP) demand periods will be provided by the town to the customer by automated signal; such notifications may be supplemented by direct telephone or other modes of communication as deemed appropriate by the town. 
Upon receipt of such notice, the customer may utilize any means deemed suitable to reduce its coincident peak (CP) demand, provided such means do not compromise the safety and wellbeing of its personnel, town employees, or the public; do not jeopardize or risk damage or harm to town-owned facilities; and do not interfere with or disrupt the provision of service by the town to its other customers. 
In the event that the customer elects to use generation to reduce any portion of its monthly demand, the installation and operation of such generation must be approved in advance and metered by the town. Operation of such generation cannot be initiated directly or indirectly by any automated signal provided by the town; the customer may, however, use any notification information provided by the town to manually schedule the operation of such generation. Any additional costs incurred by the town associated with the operation of such generation shall be passed through directly to the customer. 
(e)  Additional conditions. Where a customer elects to receive service under this schedule, all service to the premises must be provided under this schedule unless approved otherwise by the town. Load Management Rider No. 1 may not be used in conjunction with this schedule. 
Participating customers are required to enter into a separate agreement covering service under this schedule. Except where otherwise provided by separate agreement, the town reserves the right to alter, amend, or discontinue service under the terms of this schedule in accordance with its rate-making and rate administration standards. Where such alterations, amendments, or discontinuance occur, the town will endeavor to provide thirty (30) days' advance written notice to the customer. In the event of discontinuation, the town will provide the customer with an alternative schedule(s) under which to receive service. 
The advance written notice provision is exclusive of tracking adjustments associated with changes in the rates charged [to] the town from NCEMPA; the town will, however, endeavor to notify the customer of such changes as soon as practical after such changes are approved and adopted by NCEMPA. 
(f)  Payments. Bills are due when rendered and are payable within twenty (20) days of the billing date shown on the bill. 
(g)  Term of contract. The term of contract for service under this schedule shall be as mutually agreed upon, but not less than one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 94-6, § 2, 4-11-94; Ord. No. 96-18, § 10, 10-14-96; Ord. No. 09-01, § 2, 2-1-09) 
Editor's note- Section 9 of Ord. No. 96-18, adopted Oct. 14, 1996, deleted §§ 20-161-20-164 in their entirety. Formerly, such sections pertained to large general service rates G-4-G-6 and derived from §§ 27-108-27-109.1 of the 1967 Code; Ord. No. 90-11, §§ 4-6, adopted April 9, 1990; and Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, adopted April 8, 1991. Section 10 of Ord. No. 96-18 renumbered §§ 20-165, 20-166 as §§ 20-161, 20-162. 
Sec. 20-161.1. - Large commercial service with generation-CSR-WG. 
(a)  Availability. The large commercial service with generation-CSR-WG is available for electric service used by a nonresidential customer with generation where the contract demand averages between one hundred (100) kw and five hundred (500) kw for any twelve (12) consecutive months. The CSR-WG schedule is available to all electric service of the same available type supplied to customer's premises at one point of delivery through one meter. This schedule is not available for resale service, or for short term or temporary service. 
This rate is not available for the addition of new peaking generation after February 1, 2009 or for any customer which does not have peaking generation in commercial operation under this schedule as of February 1, 2009. 
(b)  Rate. This schedule of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(c)  Definitions. 
(1)  Coincident peak (CP) demand shall be the customer's contribution to the town's sixty-minute clock-hour kw demand measured during the sixty-minute interval which is used by the North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency (NCEMPA) for wholesale billing purposes during the current calendar month. 
Where the coincident peak period initially identified by NCEMPA is changed, the coincident peak (CP) demand of the customer during the corrected period shall be used for billing and a corrected bill rendered as necessary. 
(2)  Excess demand shall be the difference between the customer's maximum 15-minute demand recorded during the current billing month or minimum contract billing demand, whichever is greater, and the coincident peak (CP) demand for the same billing month. 
(3)  Kwh of energy consumption shall be the total usage of electricity during the current billing month. 
(d)  Notification by town and load curtailment by customer. In an effort to assist the customer in reducing its monthly coincident peak (CP) demand, the town will use diligent, good-faith efforts to identify potential coincident peak (CP) demand periods and notify the customer of such in advance. The town, however, cannot guarantee that identifications of these periods in all cases will be made, or that advance notice will be provided. The customer will hold the Town of Tarboro harmless in connection with such failures to identify these periods and/or provide advance notice, or with the customer's receipt of and response to such notice. 
Normally, notice of potential coincident peak (CP) demand periods will be provided by the town and to the customer by automated signal; such notifications may be supplemented by direct telephone or other modes of communication as deemed appropriate by the town. 
Upon receipt of such notice, the customer may utilize any means deemed suitable to reduce its coincident peak (CP) demand, provided such means do not compromise the safety and well being of its personnel, town employees, or the public, do not jeopardize or risk damage or harm to town-owned facilities, and do not interfere with or disrupt the provision of service by the town to its other customers. 
In the event that the customer elects to use generation to reduce any portion of its monthly demand, the installation and operation of such generation must be approved in advance and metered by the town. Operation of such generation cannot be initiated directly or indirectly by any automated signal provided by the town; the customer may, however, use any notification information provided by the town to manually schedule the operation of such generation. Any additional costs incurred by the town associated with the operation of such generation shall be passed through directly to the customer. 
(e)  Additional conditions. Where a customer elects to receive service under this schedule, all service to the premises must be provided under this schedule, unless approved otherwise by the town. Load management rider no. 1 may not be used in conjunction with this schedule. 
Participating customers are required to enter into a separate agreement covering service under this schedule. Except where otherwise provided by separate agreement, the town reserves the right to alter, amend, or discontinue service under the terms of this schedule in accordance with its rate making and rate administration standards. Where such alterations, amendments, or discontinuance occur, the town will endeavor to provide thirty (30) days advance written notice to the customer. In the event of discontinuation, the town will provide the customer with alternative schedule(s) under which to receive service. 
The advance written notice provision is exclusive of tracking adjustments associated with changes in the rates charged the town from NCEMPA; the town will, however, endeavor to notify the customer of such changes as soon as practical after such changes are approved and adopted by NCEMPA. 
(f)  Payments. Bills are due when rendered and are payable within twenty (20) days of the billing date shown on the bill. 
(g)  Term of contract. The term of contract for service under this schedule shall be mutually agreed upon, but not less than one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 04-01, § 1, 2-9-04; Ord. No. 09-01, § 2, 2-1-09) 
Sec. 20-161.2. - Large commercial service, LGS. 
(a)  Availability. The large commercial service, LGS is available for electric service used by a nonresidential customer where the monthly billing demand or contract demand is between 500 kw and 1,500 kw for any twelve consecutive months. This rate is also available to all nonresidential customers that add town-approved peaking generation after February 1, 2009. 
(b)  Rate. The schedule of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(c)  Definitions. 
    KW demand shall be the highest average kw load measured in any interval during the current billing month. 
    RKVA demand shall be the customer's maximum 15-minute reactive demand recorded during the current billing month. 
    Kwh of energy consumption shall be the total usage of electricity during the current billing month. 
(d)  Notification by town to achieve peak generation KW credit. In an effort to assist the customer in achieving peak generation credits, the town will use diligent, good-faith efforts to identify potential credit periods and notify the customer of such in advance. The town, however, cannot guarantee that identifications of these periods in all cases will be made, or that advance notice will be provided. The customer will hold the Town of Tarboro harmless in connection with such failure to identify these periods and/or provide advance notice, or with the customer's receipt of and response to such notice. 
Normally notice of peak generation credit periods will be provided by the town to the customer by automated signal; such notifications may be supplemented by direct telephone or other modes of communication as deemed appropriate by the town. 
Upon receipt of such notice, the customer may utilize any means deemed suitable to increase its generation credits, provided such means do not compromise the safety and well being of its personnel, town employees, or the public, do not jeopardize or risk damage or harm to town-owned facilities, and do not interfere with or disrupt the provision of service by the town to its other customers. 
In the event that the customer elects to use generation to increase its peak generation credits, the installation and operation of such generation must be approved in advance and metered by the town. Operation of such generation cannot be initiated directly or indirectly by any automated signal provided by the town; the customer may however use any notification information provided by the town to manually schedule the operation of such generation. Any additional costs incurred by the town associated with the operation of such generation shall be passed through directly to the customer. 
(e)  Additional conditions. Where a customer elects to receive service under this schedule, all service to the premises must be provided under this schedule, unless approved otherwise by the town. 
Participating customers are required to enter into a separate agreement covering service under this schedule. Except where otherwise provided by separate agreement, the town reserves the right to alter, amend, or discontinue service under the terms of this schedule in accordance with its rate making and rate administration standards. Where such alterations, amendments or discontinuance occur, the town will endeavor to provide thirty (30) days advance written notice to the customer. In the event of discontinuation, the town will provide the customer with alternative schedule(s) under which to receive service. 
The advance written notice provision is exclusive of tracking adjustments associated with changes in the rates charged the town from NCEMPA; the town will however endeavor to notify the customer of such changes as soon as practical after such changes are approved and adopted by NCEMPA. 
(f)  Payments. Bills are due when rendered and are payable within twenty (20) days of the billing date shown on the bill. 
(g)  Term of contract. The term of contract for service under this schedule shall be as mutually agreed upon, but not less than one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 2-1-09)

(Ord. No. 09-02, § 1, 3-28-09) 
Sec. 20-162. - Traffic signal service rate, TSS. 
(a)  Applicability and availability. This schedule is applicable to electric service supplied to traffic signals and is available for electric service supplied for the operation and illumination of traffic signals installed along public and private highways where the town has an existing secondary distribution line. 
(b)  Installation. The town, for each signal or group of signals operating from one (1) controller, will make its connection to the customer's service wire at a point one (1) foot below the lowest support, carrying existing 120/140 volt conductors, or the equivalent, on the nearest pole. The customer will furnish, install, and maintain all service wires, fixtures, and other necessary equipment, including lamps and lamp renewals, for the installation and operation of all traffic signals. 
(c)  Type of service. [The electric service supplied to the signals will be] alternating current, sixty (60) hertz, single-phase, two (2) wires, one hundred twenty (120) volts nominal. 
(d)  Definitions: 
    One-way signal means a signal with only one (1) face which can bee seen from only one (1) approach. 
    Multi-direction signal means a signal with more than one (1) face, each of which can be seen from only one (1) approach. 
(e)  Monthly rate. The schedule of rates applicable to this section shall be in an amount determined from time to time by the council and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 90-25, § 1(27-103), 8-13-90; Ord. No. 94-6, § 3, 4-11-94; Ord. No. 96-18, § 10, 10-14-96) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-161.
